PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to reports over the weekend that the Keating Government knew about the former Victorian Labor Government's action to breach the Loan Council borrowing limits before it was formally advised on 17 June. I ask: did any Government Minister or any of its officials have any discussions, formal or informal, by phone or otherwise, with the Victorian Labor Government or its officials before 17 June; and, if so, when? Did Treasurer Dawkins or any other Minister or any official receive a draft letter from the then Victorian Treasurer, Tony Sheehan, before 17 June; and, if so, when? Will the Government now release all minutes, notes and correspondence on this issue?

—Together with the Democrats, the Opposition has initiated an inquiry into the question of Loan Council borrowings and the future arrangements which might be appropriate in respect of Loan Council borrowings. That has been the subject of much debate and I suppose Opposition members will get the opportunity to ask questions about this matter at that inquiry if it misdirects itself into questions of the past as distinct from what the appropriate arrangements ought to be.

PARA.TAB: But, having said that, as Senator Short would also have seen, the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Cole, made some comments about this in the press. I have not discussed that matter with Mr Cole but, as I recall, he said that the Treasury officials were handed a copy of a draft letter, undated, from Victoria on 17 June. As I recall the press reports, that is what Mr Cole said, and he dealt with one or two other matters which are the subject of Senator Short's question.

I do not know what phone discussions took place from time to time between various Ministers in the Government and various Victorian Ministers in the period to which Senator Short refers. I know that I have discussions at the present time with various Ministers in the present Victorian Government about various matters.

I suppose that Ministers from time to time had such discussions in the period of the former Government in Victoria but, of course, I could not make any comment about that; I do not know what discussions took place. But the burden of Senator Short's question must be whether any discussions took place about the Victorian Loan Council borrowings. I do not believe that to be the case, but I will check that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. On four separate occasions during the course of answering that question, Senator Button went out of his way to say: firstly, he had not spoken to Tony Cole; secondly, he had only read the newspapers; and, thirdly, he had a rough idea from other things that he had learnt. In other words, in every respect, he is—
—What is the point of order?

—Just a moment, I am just getting to it. Mr President, the point of order is that we are entitled to know the basis on which questions are answered in this chamber by Ministers. Are they here merely to tell us what they might have read in the newspapers, or are they here briefed to answer questions on behalf of the Government? It is a very important matter, particularly in relation to this issue, and I insist that you ask Senator Button to spell out the rules of the game in relation to this matter.
—Order! That is a matter for the Government; it is not for me in the chair to rule on that particular point of order.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's refusal up to date to give any specific response to the specific questions that I have asked him, I ask again—particularly having in mind statements by the Treasurer last week—whether Senator Button will confirm that no Minister or official had any formal or informal discussions with the Victorian Government or its officials about Victoria's breach of the Loan Council guidelines before 17 June, and whether he will confirm that any letter drafted by the Victorians was sighted and whether discussions were held on such letter.

—I am quite happy to obtain a formal briefing regarding those issues. Senator Alston is, as I understand it, a member of the committee which has been established and I imagine he will have plenty of time to pursue any issues he wants to on that committee. I also make the point that this question Senator Short has asked me was based on a press report in the Sunday Age. The fact of the matter is that I do not rush around getting briefings on every press report that appears in a newspaper, particularly, as I was trying to point out, when it seemed to be wrong. It seemed to be wrong on the express statement of the Secretary to the Treasury. That is the context in which I answered the question, and it is the context in which I answered the supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is the Minister aware of recent discussions between Australia and Singapore on future air services? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the outcome of these discussions and the potential benefit for Australia's tourism and trade?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate of the outcome of the very successful negotiations which were held between Australia and Singapore last week. For the first time now, multiple designation has been agreed for the carriers of both countries. As well, airlines of both countries will have the opportunity to introduce an additional 26 services per week by 1995, which represents almost a 50 per cent increase in the capacity on this route.

PARA.TAB: The increase in capacity negotiated will provide significant capacity for allocation by the International Air Services Commission to meet the requirements of new entrants and the future growth on this route. Australian carriers will also be able to operate through Jakarta, with enhanced traffic rights, and to serve Kuala Lumpur en route. Traffic right connections to Vietnam and Cambodia have also been secured.

Singapore Airlines has also been given permanent authority to operate a second weekly freighter service into Australia effective immediately, and a third service from 1994. This is welcome news indeed for Australian export and import industries. With the finalisation of this agreement, Australia now has multiple designation rights under all of its existing air service agreements in South East Asia.

The importance of these new arrangements with Singapore for the tourism industry cannot be underestimated. For example, for the year ended 31 December 1991, Singapore figured in three of the top 10 city pair routes to Australia. Singapore's role as a major transit point in Asia is well known. With the finalisation of this new air services agreement, Australia is well placed to take advantage of the expected large growth in passengers and freight in the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to the Victorian loans scandal. Why is it that although the Treasury was aware from 17 June of the borrowings breached by the Victorians, it was not until 6 July, apparently, that the Treasury bothered to inform the Treasurer or his office? Does the Minister seriously expect us to believe that it is normal practice for the Treasury to wait almost a month before advising the Treasurer of breaches of this magnitude? Finally, why was the draft letter, to which reference has already been made, not included in documents previously released by the Treasurer in relation to the Victorian loans scandal? What other drafts, aide-memoires and documents are yet to come?

—I do not know why Treasury took that time to brief the Treasurer, but I will find out and answer that question. The possibility is that the Treasurer was not in Canberra at that time. I do not know, but I will find out about that for Senator Alston.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Short also asked the Minister whether there was any other documentation. I have asked that. Again, I ask why Senator Button will not inform himself—get a proper briefing—and tell us the full answers to these very important questions.

—I have already indicated that I will not be a sort of arbiter of comments in various newspapers back and forth about this issue. Those opposite will have an inquiry, of which Senator Alston will be a member. He can ask those questions then.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. Has the Minister received any information from the International Labour Organisation about Australian industrial relations law being inconsistent with the ILO convention on freedom of association which has been adopted by Australia? What is the Government's attitude towards ILO conventions? Is the Minister aware of any current proposals on industrial relations that would be in conflict?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Labour Organisation is the oldest agency of the United Nations. As I recall, it was formed in 1917 and has continued in various guises since. It is tripartite in nature. Its conventions have the approval of employers, workers and governments around the world.

PARA.TAB: Australia adopted the ILO convention concerning freedom of association 19 years ago, and has adhered to it ever since. The supervising committee of the ILO—the committee of experts; a body of jurists of international repute—last year asked Australia to re-examine its domestic industrial relations law. It held that the existence in this country of tort law on industrial relations and of sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act were in breach of the ILO convention I have referred to.

As well, it held that the New South Wales essential services legislation was drawn in such a way as to define services that were not essential in the bracket of `essential' and, thus, bring into the coverage of essential services, work and responsibilities that were not properly there.

In order to cut off any interjections or points of order, may I say that the Australian Government is the affiliate of, and has the responsibility of answering to, the ILO on these matters. Given the ILO's expression of view on sections 45D and E, it is interesting to note that in the Jobsback—properly called `Jobsack'—policy announced by the Opposition on 22 October, Mr Howard indicated quite clearly that he would continue the existence of sections 45D and E even though those provisions are found to be in contravention of the international labour law. He has also expressed the view that common law liability would obtain in Australia which, again, is in contravention of international labour law as declared by the ILO, and which Australia is bound to observe, given its adoption of those conventions.

The other area where one needs to look is the essential services area. I have already indicated what the finding of the jurists, the committee of experts, has been with respect to the New South Wales legislation in that area. It is clear that the Kennett Vital Industries Bill is in flagrant breach of most of the provisions of that convention, and Australia would get a black mark if that legislation were carried. If one looks at the `Jobsack' proposal, there is an imitation of the Vital Industries Bill in that being proposed by the Opposition for the national government. If that were carried, that would be in breach as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the Prime Minister's pledge not to oppose the coalition's goods and services tax if Labor loses the next election. I ask the Minister: first, what, if any, is the constitutional basis of Mr Keating's claim that `the Senate has no right to obstruct the principal policies of the government in the lower House in which that party was elected to government'? Secondly, does he agree that the Constitution clearly sets out that that legislation must gain the assent of both Houses before it becomes law? Thirdly, does he further agree that Mr Keating's highly uncharacteristic promise to forgo the use of powers at his disposal is aimed solely at manipulating the Australian electorate in a desperate bid to retain government?

—First, the Prime Minister said that he was not going to have the Democrats running around the country saying they were going to stop a GST if the coalition was, unhappily, elected to office. He was not going to have the Democrats running around the country saying that and making good fellows of themselves because that would be dependent on the support of the Labor Opposition in the Senate. Secondly, he said that he was not going to have members of the Opposition running around the country saying, `Look, don't worry about the GST because—
—No-one has ever said that.

—Yes, they have. They might not do it. The Prime Minister said that the Opposition was wedded to the GST. If people get the Opposition, they get the GST as well. That would be a terrible thing on both counts—getting the Opposition and getting the GST. That is what he said. That is an impeccable statement of the reality of it all. We do not know what the Opposition will do on the basis of the experience in my State of Victoria, where all sorts of things have been implemented which were not contained in the Opposition's policy speech.

PARA.TAB: After the election of 1975 I recall that members of the Democrats in this place, led by Don Chipp, had to sign a pledge not to oppose a principal financial measure or Supply in the Senate. That is what they used to have to do. There is not much technical distinction between the two. We are talking about the Opposition's $40 billion package, including $27 billion worth of new taxes to be imposed on the Australian people. That is clearly a centrepiece of any Opposition proposal. The people of Australia know that if the Opposition is elected here they will cop that in terms of prices of food and clothing and all sorts of things which are not now subject to taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister illustrates an appalling lack of history: the Democrats were not formed until 1977, so how we took that action in 1975 I am not too sure. The Minister has not answered the first part of the question, relating to the constitutional basis. Further, will the Government be issuing a comprehensive guide on how it will vote on the coalition's promised legislation so that Australians are fully informed of the extent to which Labor will wimp out on its principles when and if it is elected to opposition?

—Senator Hill has just reminded me that for some aberrant reason I am weak on the details of the history of the Democrats of Australia. I apologise for that. The moment the 1975 election was over the seeds of distress were sown in the Liberal Party that led to the formation of the Democrats. It was at that time that the Democrats decided to form their philosophy and policy in relation to these matters.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter talks about the Labor Party wimping out on its principles. A fundamental principle of this Party since 1975 has been that we do not see it as the role of the Senate to obstruct the government on its major economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about prior to 1975?
—We never did it before, either.
—You voted against Supply in both chambers.
—Senator Crichton-Browne must not go back that far. That is the point. I would not get too worried about that.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Over the weekend, 113 boat people were removed from Christmas Island and returned to China. Can the Minister explain the basis for this decision? Can he assure the Senate that proper human rights processes were observed?

—It is a fact that 113 Chinese boat people who arrived at Christmas Island on 30 October were sent back to China. They were sent back after being interviewed by experienced and senior officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. During those interviews it became apparent that these boat people had been the victims of a very unscrupulous racket: they had been tempted and duped into believing that if they made their way to Australia they would achieve a better life for themselves by securing employment, perhaps being able to bring their families out and so on.

PARA.TAB: They were not seeking asylum in Australia. The interviews with the boat people led the officers to conclude quite clearly—no claims were made by them—that they were not seeking asylum in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of them claimed refugee status?

—Senator Hill's shadow Minister has put out a press release saying that the Government had acted properly in the decision it had taken in regard to the 113 arrivals on Christmas Island. The way in which these people were dealt with so speedily probably came as something of a surprise to the Australian people, but it happens constantly at airports. When people arrive at airports without proper documentation—with no legal basis for their entry to Australia—they are turned around very quickly through the international terminals, as the Minister for Transport and Communications would know. Where people have no legal basis on which to remain here, they will be turned around as quickly and as practicably as possible.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that the integrity of our immigration laws be maintained and that people cannot arrive here on an expectation that, simply by making our shores, even to Christmas Island, they will automatically secure some sort of entry to Australia. Departmental officials assessed that they were not asylum seekers. The Government cannot condone attempts to enter Australia through queue jumping, and the message to be taken back to those who might be duped into entering or tempted to enter into similar schemes is that they should not undertake such a perilous voyage without the very firm prospect of being turned around as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister just elaborate on the assurances that all human rights processes were properly observed? There have been complaints over the weekend from people protesting about this invasion of human rights.
—Were they verballed?

—Senator Alston asks whether they were verballed. That is a gross reflection on the capacity and integrity of the very senior officers who undertook the interviews. These people made no claim for asylum status. The fact is that the Government acted in a way which the shadow Minister has said to be a proper discharge of the Government's obligations to protect the integrity of our immigration system. I am sorry if Senator Alston disagrees with his shadow Minister in that respect.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is very important that the Minister also received assurances from the Chinese authorities that the boat people would not be punished for their illegal—I presume it was illegal—departure from China. Both governments believed that these people had been exploited by others for the unscrupulous profiteering motives which set these people on that perilous journey. The message to go back is that such boat arrivals will be turned around very promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Industrial Relations confirm reports that CES office staff, Australia Post and Telecom employees will be involved in the protest strike in Victoria tomorrow? Given that these employees are covered by Federal awards and are therefore not affected by the industrial relations changes proposed by the Kennett Government, does the Minister and the Government support their involvement in the strike?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite reasonable that the Opposition should ask the Government a question about industrial relations of this character because the Government's record on industrial relations is vastly superior to that of the Opposition. Indeed, if one compares the level of industrial disputation during the period of our Government with the period of the Fraser Government, one will see that there has been a 62 per cent reduction in industrial disputation in Australia during our tenure of office compared to the Opposition's tenure of office. Indeed, the Australian Bureau of Statistics graph of Victoria is off the bottom of the page, Victoria having enjoyed, up until the advent of the Kennett Government, a very low level of industrial disputation.

PARA.TAB: I can also understand the Opposition asking this question, because only a fortnight ago on the Sunday program with Mr Reith and on the Meet the Press program with Mr Howard, both those luminaries in the Opposition said that Mr Kennett had misled Victorians by saying before the election that no-one would lose a cent and then proclaiming that they would all lose their annual leave loading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is raised under standing order 184, which gives you the power to control debate, et cetera, in the Senate. This Minister was asked a simple question: does he and does his Government support the people covered by Federal awards going on strike in support of the strike against the Kennett Government? He needs to give a simple `yes' or `no' answer. He is debasing this chamber—and you are allowing him to do so—by not answering the question. I ask you to use your power to make the Minister answer the question.

—Order! Senator Cook was asked a question about a protest strike in Victoria and about people covered by Federal awards. He was straying from the subject, but I believe at the end of the answer he was talking about the Kennett Government's policy. I ask him to answer the question that was asked.

—I am answering the question, Mr President, and I will come to the point before my time expires. The clear fact on the political record in this country is that Mr Reith and Mr Howard say that the Victorian Government misled its own constituency by promising before the election that no-one would lose a cent, and then after the election ensuring that everyone does.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Order! I am not helped by some advice that I am getting from my left.

—Mr President, you effectively upheld that point of order because it was a very clear breach. The question was in relation to Federal employees and a State strike. You effectively directed Senator Cook to answer it in those terms. He immediately proceeded to rabbit on again about other matters. I invite you to direct him to answer that specific question.
—Order! I did ask the Minister to deal with that part of the question that dealt with the Federal awards and the Victorian strike tomorrow. I ask him to do that.

—Thank you, Mr President. The Kennett Government has now introduced legislation to which, I understand, it has proposed 58 amendments, thus indicating that its own legislation is grievously flawed. That legislation in part deals with the declaration of industrial action as a criminal act. My advice is that that affects all employees, whether they are covered by State awards or Federal awards in Victoria. Although the officers in the Victorian Public Service have said that that is not the intention, as I understand it the Victorian Government has not proposed an amendment to remove that very clear implication of the Act.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I would much prefer that the unions and the Government in Victoria negotiate to remove the need for a strike at all in the eyes of the unions in that State, and that Mr Kennett stand aside his now flawed Act in order to enable those negotiations to go on. I have no real expectation that he will and, in those circumstances, I believe it is for Victorians to decide.

While I would find it a matter of regret that APS people would go on strike, the fact that they are embraced nonetheless willy-nilly in State legislation whether they like it or not perhaps forms the basis of their consideration of this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from the Minister's answer that he does support these people going on strike, or does he not? That is the first part of my supplementary question which I ask him to answer. What is the bottom line? Does the Minister support these people or not? Since the Minister did not address the question at all, the second part of my supplementary question is: what steps has the Minister taken or will he take to ensure that any such employees, that is, those paid for and protected by the taxpayer, are not paid for the time they take off to support this strike?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that a definition of a strike was to withdraw one's labour without there being any remuneration. If people went on strike, of course, they would not be remunerated. I have answered the first part of this question. I would be interested to know from the Opposition, given the declaration of view by Mr Howard and Mr Reith about the misleading and lying undertaken by the Liberal Government in Victoria before the election, whether in a democracy they support the right of citizens to withdraw their labour when they are injured by a government which promised not to injure them before it was elected. What is the right of citizens in a democracy to protest in circumstances such as this?

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of comments by the shadow Minister for Finance on open skies aviation policies? Will the Government adopt such policies instead of implementing the aviation reforms outlined in the One Nation statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of them, and the Government would not implement them, even if it could. The aviation policy as enunciated by Senator Short, who is a senior frontbencher in the coalition, is totally contradictory.

PARA.TAB: There is some confusion about the Opposition's aviation policy because of a speech Senator Short delivered to an aviation seminar in Sydney, which I have referred to in the Senate before. Senator Short had the Opposition's policy stated as going from open skies at the one extreme, and I have a copy of his speech here in front of me. In the first paragraph of his speech on page 7 he states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Coalition will open up the skies of Australia . . . will allow a very liberal approach to the granting of international air rights.

This is at the one extreme, but three paragraphs later he makes a most extraordinary statement. I would like clarification as to whether or not this is the Opposition's policy. Senator Short says that it is. He stated that the Opposition would give Qantas the first right of refusal before any other carrier gets a crack at an international route.

PARA.TAB: Earlier today at Question Time I described the very successful negotiations we have just concluded with Singapore to open up greater capacity on the Singapore route. This would allow Australian carriers other than Qantas to fly on those routes. In his examples in paragraph 4 on page 7 of his speech, Senator Short states—

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't kicked too many goals yet.
—Senator Alston should listen. Senator Short stated:

ANSWER.PARA: While QANTAS will remain our designated flag carrier and initially have the right to reject operating under any new agreements, the Coalition will be prepared to licence additional Australian carriers for these overseas routes should QANTAS not wish to operate such services.

What an extraordinary mishmash of aviation policy! It is no wonder we were contacted by people in the aviation industry who provided us with this document. They asked us our view on it and whether we would implement it.

PARA.TAB: It is a fair question for members of the Opposition as to how they advocate an open skies policy, which in itself is iniquitous, which would allow untrammelled rights for international carriers in Australia without negotiating reciprocal rights for Australian carriers and without the nonsense of then saying that they will allow only Australian carriers other than Qantas access to international routes if Qantas does not want them. It is an absolute nonsense of an aviation policy and it is about time the coalition straightened it out.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. The Minister will recall that on 24 November 1988 he concluded an agreement, now referred to as the Cook-Groom agreement, in clause 16 of which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Should any financial loss result from any limits placed on the operation, the Commonwealth will pay compensation direct to the company concerned.
Does the Minister recall that comment, and was it his intention that it should be honoured?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I concluded that agreement—Senator Archer flatters me by now giving it the name of the Cook-Groom agreement, but I am prepared to accept his flattery on this subject—in my former capacity of Minister for Resources with the Government. The agreement I think is reasonably or tolerably accurately described by Senator Archer. Comments that he ascribes to me I think I made at the time, and I do believe it should be implemented.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister believe that it is reasonable that the Commonwealth should now be endeavouring to renege on this agreement by trying to adopt some technicality of the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe the Commonwealth is trying to renege on the agreement and the party to the agreement that I understand is at halts, if Bender's quarry in Tasmania be the example Senator Archer is referring to, is the Tasmanian Government—the Groom wing of that agreement. I refer Senator Archer to its actions in recent days as an example of that.

—I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the Minister to consider his response to Senator Coulter's question and a previous question in the same light last Thursday when he refused to give the details of the ALP support for a tax on the necessities of life. What details of the coalition's proposed industrial relations policy will need to be revealed before the ALP tactics are decided? Will other Ministers, employers and employees be involved in that discussion or will the nation have to anticipate another prime ministerial smart alec, tactical bombshell?

—That is a question laced with icy vitriol, and I am taken aback by that. As I said in the Senate last week, the Opposition's proposed goods and services tax is a large measure in terms of economic issues, involving $27 billion in additional tax, for example. That is a large measure and I have indicated our attitude to that. In so far as industrial relations legislation is concerned, I would not fall into the Opposition trap of suggesting, as Senator Bell does by implication, that any industrial relations legislation from the Opposition will be of crucial importance. The thing that can be said most about the industrial relations legislation which has been suggested by the Opposition is that it is chronically out of touch with what has been happening in Australia and will not be, I am sure, if it is of anything of the flavour that has been indicated by Opposition spokesmen, relevant.
—Even if the Australian voter endorses it?

—Senator Macdonald may not understand the difference between a mandate in respect of major financial legislation and the so-called issue of a general mandate. If he hangs around here for a while he will probably cotton on to all of that. I am not proposing to answer in any detail Senator Bell's question about that. That is not a matter which falls into the same category as the GST.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to my question of 20 August regarding unauthorised disclosure of confidential information held by Federal government agencies, termed at the time as trade in confidential information. In his answer, the Minister assured me that the question of relevant prosecutions would be followed up by the Director of Public Prosecutions. That was 10 weeks ago, so I ask the Minister: what progress is the Director making and how many prosecutions, if any, have commenced?

—If this is a reference to material that came out of the Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry into the disclosure by public servants of information which Australians quite properly expected to be held in secrecy, then I have indicated to the Senate that in so far as relevant sections have been made available to the Government they are being dealt with by the Australian Federal Police and will be dealt with by the Director of Public Prosecutions should briefs be handed to the Director. I have not been briefed recently on whether in fact investigations have reached that stage, so I am unable to give the honourable senator any specific information as to whether that has been the case. But there is a very strong determination on the part of the Government that any matters which can be properly prosecuted ought to be, but naturally we are dependent on the independent investigating and prosecuting agencies of the Commonwealth in that regard.

PARA.TAB: In regard to any legislation and change in the statutes which govern the way in which this sort of material can be made available by public servants, in so far as it can be made available, for example, to private investigators at the behest of, and for money provided by, for example, financial institutions, insurance companies and so on, quite clearly there needs to be a comprehensive review of that legislation. Already the first steps have been taken in this Parliament by ensuring that, where such information is received by those third party companies, that should be subject to penalty. Very stringent penalties will be provided for, and have been provided for in some instances, and this needs to be done more comprehensively. In so far as any particular information might be made available to Senator Panizza, I will see whether anything further of a more up-to-date nature can be provided to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations.
—Read up.

—Does the workplace agreement recently achieved in the Australian Public Service provide a model for workplace bargaining in other areas? Does this agreement include agreed initiatives to lift productivity across the Public Service and deliver savings to the Budget which will benefit taxpayers? You would not know anything about that.
—I think you would know something about that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I do know a bit about it, but I think Senator Burns was referring to Opposition senators, with due respect. The answer to the question is yes. When we commenced bargaining with the Australian Public Service unions up to 18 months ago, we declared that our clear objective was to introduce productivity bargaining at agency level into the Australian Public Service and that we wanted a win-win-win outcome. What we have now is not an agreement as such, because it is an in-principle understanding between the negotiating parties in need of ratification by both of us; nonetheless, it is a substantial gain at this point and I expect ratification will follow.

PARA.TAB: It is a win for the Australian taxpayer in the sense that the cost of delivering government services will now be less; it is a win for those who use and consume government services in Australia because it will improve the quality, timeliness and value of those services to them; and it is a win to the Australian Public Service officers who work for the government because, by implementing the gain sharing principle, they will be able to gain as we improve productivity through better remuneration and better Public Service conditions.

So it is a win-win-win outcome for all concerned at this stage and thus ought to be recognised as being some sort of model for employers in the private sector to examine and to implement in order to get into the economy that surge in productivity that we believe it is possible to achieve through our form of workplace bargaining.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten years waiting for it.

—As there is an interjection, I must say that this would not be possible were the Opposition's industrial policy in place because we would have confrontation between the Government and the Public Service, we would not have the notion of gain sharing and we would not have the notion of win-win outcomes. We would just have a win-lose outcome approach which, of course, polarises the community, as we are seeing is the case in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: This is by far the biggest workplace agreement negotiated in Australia. It will cover 150,000 Australians. It is a two-year closed agreement. It will represent savings to the Budget. There are three areas of gain sharing. There is an up-front payment of 2 per cent paid for by across the Service productivity gains. There is gain sharing at agency level as the negotiations move to that level. And there is a provision called foldback which aims to restore the pay classification structure at the end of the two-year period.

There are two increases—1.4 and 1.5 per cent in March 1993 and March 1994—which are characterised as adjustments reflecting changes in the economy. They will be, of course, supplemented. This enables the agencies that make up the Australian Public Service to negotiate direct with their employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to reports that the Prime Minister is anxious to explain the circumstances of his investment in a multi-million dollar pig joint venture. Following the longstanding precedent that House of Representatives Ministers appear before Senate committees and in view of the fact that the Senate and pigs were fresh on the Prime Minister's mind when he called us `unrepresentative swill', will he extend to the Prime Minister an invitation to appear before a Senate committee to explain: why a reputable government agency like AQIS would insert in letters that access for live pigs re-emerged at prime ministerial level and then rescind it and assert twice in ministerial briefings that pig semen was discussed at the Crean-Tornaes meeting and then six months later say that was incorrect; why the Prime Minister told the Age that the joint venture was not the subject of ministerial talks when Minister Crean's recall note stated that he told the Danish Minister he was pleased with the progress of pork joint ventures; and, finally, how he could have an investment in a major business crucially dependent on government approvals?
—Order! The time has expired.

—I know that Senator Boswell's question is about pigs. It is unfortunate to flog a dead horse, as the honourable senator has been doing for a very long time in connection with this issue. Let me again go through Senator Boswell's plot. Senator Boswell has lost his own plot. The first conspiracy that he alleged against the Prime Minister was that the Prime Minister had manipulated the foreign investment guidelines to suit his own company. That was alleged by Senator Baume, Dr Hewson's personal scuttlebutt in the Senate. That was totally wrong. It totally misrepresented the position. It was a total misrepresentation of everything.

PARA.TAB: Then Senator Boswell tried to suggest that the quarantine guidelines had been manipulated for the same sort of purpose. Now Senator Boswell has lost the plot because, as he knows full well, Mr Crean and the Danish Minister met and they talked about issues which were totally unrelated to this particular business project. Senator Boswell knows that to be true. But he is trying to delve, as he has done in the past, into a hopeless barrel of rubbish, which is not getting him anywhere.

In so far as the first part of the honourable senator's question is concerned—it is so thoughtful he must have taken a weekend to write it—let me say this: I think he would probably be better off doing what he announced publicly he wanted to do—go and take his clothes off, wrap himself in the flag and stand up here. But do not ask silly questions in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I never made any such statements, Mr President. I would ask that later you get the Leader to withdraw. But I take it from the Minister's answer that he will not invite the Prime Minister to appear before a Senate committee to explain all of these problems which Australia is facing and for which answers are required.

—As Senator Boswell knows full well, the issue of joint ventures in piggeries has been pushed most by people like his colleague Wal Murray in New South Wales and by Agent-General McVeigh, his former colleague here. These are the people who have pushed the issue, and they have been very dutiful in what they have done because it is an important issue for this industry. But it is very bad for the National Party to abandon that sense of duty on behalf of the people whom it pretends to represent by coming in here and trying to make scuttlebutt out of the same issue. Where is this once great party, the National Party, that we used to know? It is slipping slowly down the plughole, with Senator Boswell sitting there on the flank—Senator Boswell, who gets the right to appoint somebody to the committee of inquiry into the loans and appoints Senator Bishop. What a disgrace!

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the outcome of consideration by the International Civil Aviation Organisation of restrictions on smoking on international air services? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the implications for international air services to and from Australia?

—A resolution, which was co-sponsored by Australia and Canada, on restricting smoking on international air services was agreed at the ICAO assembly held last month in Montreal. The resolution urges all ICAO countries to take necessary measures as soon as possible to restrict smoking progressively on all international passenger flights, with the objective of implementing complete smoking bans on these flights by 1 July 1996. This initiative is a forward looking and responsible approach to protect all operating crews and passengers travelling on international services from the hazards of tobacco smoke.

PARA.TAB: The ICAO assembly vote vindicates Australian and global concern that the need for smoking bans on international flights be addressed as a multilateral aviation public health issue. ICAO has indicated it will play an important ongoing role with the World Health Organisation in promoting a smoke-free environment for all crews and passengers on international air services.

It is to be hoped that the 173 member states of ICAO will encourage the implementation of this resolution by the carriers of their respective countries. Qantas has banned smoking on its flights between Australia and New Zealand and some non-stop Sydney-Los Angeles flights from 25 October. Air New Zealand has also increased smoke-free flights to Australia from 25 October. Singapore Airlines also recently announced smoke-free flights between Perth and Singapore.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aviation: Flight Plans of Private Pilots

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support inform the Senate whether the Government will instigate an immediate review of Civil Aviation Authority regulations which, since being amended 12 months ago, only require private pilots to lodge details of their flight departure and arrival points and not their specific routes? Is the Minister aware that searchers for two Tasmanians tragically lost in a recent light plane crash in northern Tasmania claimed that their lack of knowledge regarding the plane's intended flight path seriously hampered the search? Does the Government recognise that the lack of vital flight path information in the form of a flight plan may mean the difference between life and death during times of aviation emergency and that this position cannot be allowed to continue? Is this the CAA's policy of `affordable safety' in practice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The CAA makes the regulations based on the best knowledge that it has at the time, being the responsible authority in Australia in managing the proper legal and regulatory regime for air traffic control and flying. In the case of the Tasmanian incident that Senator Calvert has referred to, it is my understanding that the pilot of that aircraft made arrangements to radio to the tower, at Hobart I think, when they were crossing from the land in Tasmania over the coast into the sea area.

PARA.TAB: When the radio call did not come through, there was an expectation that something serious had befallen the aircraft and arrangements were then made. So even if a flight plan had been lodged in the case of this incident, as Senator Calvert's question implies it ought to have been, nothing different behaviourally would have occurred in terms of early warning or notice.

To draw a general conclusion from one occasion is not appropriate. Of course, the CAA does keep a constant monitoring brief on the effect of its regulations and whether those regulations are appropriate. I expect it to do that on this occasion. If Senator Calvert wishes me to obtain for him a more detailed explanation by the CAA about what it is doing in response to this particular incident, I will be delighted to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister, but what I was saying is that the criticism of the searchers was that no flight plan was lodged to give them any indication of the direction in which the plane was heading. The Minister referred to the pilot raising the matter when he went across Bass Strait; that was his regular habit. The point I am trying to make is that a flight plan would indicate in which direction the plane was heading. There were several different directions in which it could have been going. I was asking Senator Cook, as the responsible Minister, whether he could look again at the regulations as they stand.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Calvert knows, under the arrangements with the CAA on its commercial footing we do not direct the CAA, nor can we, in terms of how it administers its Act. That is a bipartisan point of view. Under the Opposition's proposals, as I understand them, the same would apply. I will obtain from the CAA an answer in more detail and see whether there is a way of answering the issues that Senator Calvert has raised.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Does the Minister recall Senator Knowles saying last week in this place that the Government should be condemned because it did not accept private health insurance companies' request that people who pay private health insurance be exempt from paying the Medicare levy increase? Is the Government thinking of changing its policy—
—Why don't you quote it accurately?

—I did quote it accurately; I referred to the Hansard to get it precisely accurate because I knew Senator Knowles would say that. Is the Government thinking of changing its policy in this area along these lines?

—I do not have the exact transcript in front of me, but I do believe there was some comment to that effect from Senator Knowles challenging the Government, which seemed to come ill from her mouth. Not only is the Opposition proposing that Australians fund the health scheme through ordinary taxation contributions and the Medicare levy, but also it wishes to add to the tax and Medicare levy contributions the payment of private health insurance premiums as a compulsory feature of the funding of health and hospital care throughout Australia. So there will be three elements which the ordinary person and household in Australia would have to face if Fightback were ever implemented.

PARA.TAB: In order to ameliorate the effect on those in the community earning very low incomes, it is proposed by the Opposition that some sort of subsidy be offered. However, the hundreds of millions of dollars to fund that subsidy will come direct from the cutback in expenditure on the public hospital system which, unfortunately, will also be part of the Fightback policy. If 5 per cent of funds are taken away from the States, the States will find it very difficult to allocate sufficient funds to the public hospital system. The hundreds of millions of dollars that will be saved by the Opposition in that regard may be used to mask the real pain of the compulsory private health insurance premium that the Opposition would require to be paid by every Australian and every Australian household.

We believe there should be direct payment into the public hospital system. That is what is being proposed by the Minister, Mr Brian Howe, by way of the transfer of many tax dollars into the public hospital system to help reduce waiting lists, to help to build up that hospital system to one where all Australians can find equitable access to decent health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President. I refer to your answer last Thursday regarding the action you took as a result of the attacks by Mr Keating on the Senate. You will be aware that in the Age on Saturday Michelle Grattan gave a somewhat different version of events. In your Senate remarks, you said that you had been able to get in touch with the Prime Minister and that you told him of the statement you had made. Michelle Grattan's column suggested that you had previously consulted with the Prime Minister's office about a letter you proposed to write and that the Prime Minister had told you to shove it. I ask you, Mr President, if Michelle Grattan's version of the events is correct, why did you consult with the Prime Minister before determining what action you proposed to take, and do you not agree that consulting with the Prime Minister on this issue is in fact involving your office in politics, which was your justification for doing nothing?
—I have very little to add to the statement that I made last week. When I contacted the Prime Minister I told him the details of the statement that I was about to make. That is all.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will you confirm to the Senate that the Prime Minister told you to shove it?
—I have nothing further to add to the answer that I gave last Thursday.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Will the Government ensure that the Australian Securities Commission and the National Crime Authority liaise with and assist fully the efforts of the Director of Public Prosecutions in Western Australia to pursue overseas financial trails resulting from the investigations by the Western Australian Royal Commission? Furthermore, will the Minister give an assurance that all possible resources will be allocated to the investigation of a black money network that may have been used by some major donors to the ALP, and the fact that there may be sitting senators who are aware of those donations and their trail?

—As always, Federal law enforcement prosecuting authorities are ready to assist, within the limits of their jurisdictional powers, proper investigation of what is alleged to be criminal activity in Australia. So far as the National Crime Authority and the Australian Securities Commission are concerned, whilst, of course, they are independent statutory agencies, I believe that I can indicate on behalf of those agencies their preparedness to engage in such cooperative and collaborative endeavours to secure the integrity of our companies and securities, and general criminal law system.

PARA.TAB: This Government has taken many steps over the last several years to deal with the phenomenon of money laundering, particularly with overseas elements. Indeed, we have introduced legislation which makes it very clear that, not only through the creation of a very stringent penalties regime for the laundering into Australia of black money from overseas, but also through the Cash Transactions Reports Agency, we are monitoring very carefully the sending of money out of Australia in various forms. In this way, we believe we will ensure that the black economy does not get laundered into the white economy, not only in a way which would further allow the accumulation of assets by those engaged in criminal activities, but in a way which would distort the legitimate business and commercial activities of Australians who are honestly trying to run their businesses.
We are very interested in this area, and are quite confident that Federal agencies will assist where practical.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister why, then, have there not been activities undertaken at the moment to trace the whereabouts of the money that was allegedly taken overseas by four individuals in Western Australia?

—I have no knowledge of any particular operations or whether, in fact, investigations are being undertaken. I have not been provided with any briefing on those matters. I do not believe it is appropriate that I follow every operation being undertaken.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 November Senator Chapman asked me a question concerning waterside workers and their redundancy packages. I promised to provide him with further details. I now have an answer. It is quite a long one and I seek leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

On Thursday 5 November, Senator Chapman asked: "How many waterside workers who have retired and taken golden handshakes—in some instances of more than $100,000—under the Government's inadequate waterfront reform program have returned as casual employees to the wharves?
Last Thursday, 5 November, I undertook to provide further details in relation to a question from Senator Chapman concerning the number of waterside workers who have returned as casual employees.
On checking with the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, I am advised that this information is not centrally held.
With the move from industry-wide stevedoring employment arrangements, and industry controls over employment, to enterprise-based employment this type of information is not collected.
This is in line with the aim of normalising employment arrangements within the stevedoring industry and avoiding intrusive oversight by the Government.

The use of former industry employees as supplementary labour is completely valid and was provided for in the waterfront in-principle agreement negotiated in 1989 between the employers, unions, ACTU and the Government.
An important feature of the agreement was the extension of supplementary labour arrangements to all ports.

The agreement specifically provided (in clause 11.4) that the supplementary (or casual) labour lists were determined on an enterprise basis at the conclusion of enterprise agreements and include, but were not limited to, former industry employees.
The use of former industry employees as short term, supplementary labour, to accommodate fluctuating labour requirements because of variations in cargo throughput, was always intended.
The ability to engage supplementary labour is the sort of management flexibility that stevedoring employers were seeking.
Former industry employees are a valuable resource of skilled, temporary labour and to exclude them would impose additional training costs on stevedoring management.

The use of former full time industry employees is not contrary to the intention of the reform program, and I reiterate that there is no reason to require them to repay redundancy payments made under the reform program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aviation: Flight Plans of Private Pilots

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, Senator Calvert asked me a question concerning the light aircraft incident in northern Tasmania. I have additional information which I can provide to him. It is a long piece of information. I do not regard this as exhausting my undertaking to him to provide him with further information, but it will help fill the gap. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: LIGHT AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT IN NORTHERN TASMANIA
ABC News reported that a CAA official had criticised changes to Civil Aviation Regulations on the basis that these changes had hampered the search for the aircraft.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that reports on ABC Radio indicated that a CAA official had been critical of changed reporting arrangements for light aircraft under revised air space management procedures introduced at the end of last year.

I have been advised by the CAA that the official, who is the head of Air Traffic Services responsible for Victoria and Tasmania, did acknowledge that, if the pilot had followed CAA recommended practice to leave a flight plan or details of the track he was proposing to fly with the owner of the aircraft, the Aero Club or simply a friend, it would have assisted in the search.
The pilot had indicated that he would call Air Traffic Services when he arrived at the north coast of Tasmania, at which point he would provide an estimated time of arrival at Moorabbin.

As this call was not received, the CAA concentrated its search in Tasmania, which was hampered by low cloud in the area. The CAA also arranged for aircraft to search the sea north of Tasmania in case the aircraft had proceeded beyond the coast without having made a radio call as the pilot had arranged.

The changes made to air space arrangements last December essentially removed the mandatory requirement for pilots of aircraft flying under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) to lodge a flight plan with the CAA.
Nevertheless, pilots are free to use radio to let the CAA know which track they are using and any other details they may wish to provide.
It is really a matter for each pilot to decide.

Aircraft operating airline services are required to submit flight plans. Other flights carrying paying passengers are required to submit flight notifications either to the CAA or to a responsible person.

The CAA does not believe that the new arrangements introduced last December, which remove the requirement for pilots of VFR aircraft to lodge a flight plan, but which recommend that details be submitted to a responsible party, have diminished the level of air safety.
I am advised that the most difficult aspect of the search was the low visibility in the area.
The Bureau of Air Safety is undertaking a full investigation of the accident.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley this day, relating to private health insurance and the Medicare levy.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion to take note of Senator Tate's answer because of the absolute blatant misrepresentation and the manipulation of Senator Crowley in the question and Senator Tate in the answer of the issues that I raised the other day in my speech in the Senate. The point that I made last week—

TALK.START.PARA: —You sensitive flower.

—I can always rely on Senator West to make the most inane interjections on matters to do with anything, let alone health. The point that I was making last week was that under this Labor Government anyone who chooses to take out private health insurance has to pay four times as much as anyone else because the great Labor lie that has been spread for the past decade is that Medicare was meant to be self-funding.

PARA.TAB: We know full well, as does everybody else who reads the Budget Papers, that the Medicare levy pays for only 20 per cent of the total cost of health. Therefore, anyone who pays the levy, which is virtually every single solitary taxpayer—there is a proportion who do not have to pay it, but that is a very low base—also has to pay increased taxation to pay for the remaining 80 per cent of health costs. If they are privately insured, they have to take out private health insurance. That is the third cost. The fourth cost is the gap insurance, because this Government will not allow the private hospital people to insure for whatever they want.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you self-fund pensions?

—Senator Sherry sits over there thinking that is quite acceptable. We in the coalition do not believe that is acceptable. We will help people take out their private health insurance, which is a darn sight more than this Government has ever dreamt of doing. We will make sure that people on low incomes who take out insurance have tax relief granted to them. At the moment they have to take out private health insurance because their alternative, if they are ill, is to die at the end of the waiting list.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Crowley had been honest in her question today and Senator Tate honest in the answer, they would know that last week in my speech in the Senate I referred to a number of cases where people had died, and to cases where others had taken a very bad turn, had to give up work and go on other forms of benefit because of this Government's inadequate response to the whole question of health. We will find out a darn sight more in the near future about the way in which this Government is dealing with the health issue because I believe there is a case of fraud involving $60m. At this stage we are trying to get that information released.

Anything that is raised on health with this Government is just brushed aside. Only last week the Minister representing the Minister for Health was asked to table a document relating to fraud. That was a request of this Senate chamber. What does the Minister do? He says, `Get lost'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He says, `Shove it'.

—That is right; he says, `Shove it'. Today the Government is trying to stand high and mighty on some pedestal saying what a good job it does. All it does is knock off people at the end of the waiting list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise more in sorrow than in anger to support Senator Knowles's remarks. I do so because in front of me I have the Australian Hospitals Association Hospital Brief for October this year. That association represents all the public hospitals of Australia—and there are more than 600 public hospitals. I will quote from the heading of Hospital Brief:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has admitted for the first time that it has a Medicare problem. . . The major problem with Medicare from the public hospital sector's perspective has been the increased numbers of `free' public patients and the decline in `paying' private patients. . . There are limits to how much efficiency can be forced without affecting patient access and quality of care. . . A fully public funded system controls costs effectively through an explicit cap on hospital budgets. However, the limits on raising taxpayer funds inevitably leads to more service rationing, longer waiting lists and stifles innovation in technology and management.

On the one hand, we get that statement, and, on the other hand, we get the answer that Senator Tate gave today. It defies belief that Senator Tate can get up and give that sort of an answer, totally ignoring what is occurring out there at the workplace in the hospital system. He is condemned by his own public hospital system spokesman, yet he comes along here and gives an answer to a dorothy dixer which totally contravenes what is occurring in the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I do not know where Senator Tate gets that answer from. He is obviously caught up in whatever other portfolios he looks after, but he has no knowledge whatsoever of what is occurring. It is a purely political answer to bolster what is a failed system. The system is broke; it has failed. Fightback has an answer on how to refurbish the system. We will continue with the public hospital system as it exists today and put more money into it. There is no magic pudding. Senator Tate disregards the whole basis of the system, which was invented long before Medicare came into existence and which really brought out the high standard of hospital care that has been afforded to this country, both in public and in private. By continuing the line of garbage that he is giving us now and pretending that there is no problem there at all is a disservice to this Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator West this day, relating to the aviation industry.

The speech was about the GST and its application to aviation, not about aviation policy as such. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about this chamber last week, I want to put on the record the number of people who have expressed grave concern about not only the conduct of the Prime Minister of Australia but more specifically his language. I suppose that the best way to sum that up is by reading a letter that was written to the West Australian in my home State of Western Australia by a Mr Warren Gillespie of Ocean Reef.

PARA.TAB: I will read that letter into the Hansard because it really summarises the situation and the feeling of the people of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who does he speak for, apart from Mr Gillespie? Who is he?

—Senator Button should have heard what I said. The problem is that many people to whom I have spoken have expressed similar concerns. In my opinion, this summarises very well the concerns that have been expressed not only to me but to many—
—That is not what you said. You said that he speaks for the people of Australia.
—That is what I am saying now. If Senator Button cleans out his ears, we will go well. `Senators must stand firm' is the heading of the letter. The body of it states:

SPEECH.PARA: IS THERE no end to Paul Keating's dictatorial arrogance?

PARA.TAB: By calling our senators "unrepresentative swill" (report, 5/11), he defames not only the Senate but the very institution of Parliament as we know it.
The Senate, the house of review, is the only buffer between Keating's bullying, despotic ambitions and our traditional, hard-won freedoms.
As long as we have a Senate, this tin-pot fuhrer cannot further turn this country into the banana republic he seems so keen to rule.
This unelected Prime Minister has made it clear he wants the Senate abolished. To even contemplate this is a national tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Unparliamentary language was used in the letter. I remind honourable senators that the rule has been that it cannot be used when quoting in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to speak to this matter. Mr President, I was surprised that no-one on the other side of the chamber rose to object to the expression `tin-pot fuhrer', but you have taken the matter into your hands.
—Why should we?
—I thought that Senator Button might wish to defend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in some way. Bruce Jones wrote this in the Herald-Sun on 8 November after last week's events:

If that is the sentiment of the Prime Minister's colleagues in this place after the events of last week, at least those opposite are waking up. Perhaps that explains why nobody objected to that unparliamentary comment.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I am disturbed by your answer today. The implication of what Michelle Grattan said in the Age—and I will not read it again—suggests that your explanation to the Senate last week for taking no action was not valid. In other words, you said that you felt that you could not take action because to do so would be to intervene in a political matter.

It appears from her statement in the Age that you liaised with the Prime Minister as to what action you should take. He had later expressed something to you in terms that were, to use her words, `euphemistically described as colourful'. When you then said that you might have to write a letter on behalf of honourable senators and you got a response from the Prime Minister saying, `Shove it', you decided not only not to act but also to put out a statement in this place saying that you could not act because to do so would be to act politically.
