We hold the view that we expressed last week, that the President of this body has a responsibility to uphold and fight for the high standards it has stood for in the past. We regret that last week you were not prepared to do so. It now seems on the basis of what she said—unless you tell us that her report is wrong—that you did not do so because you were heavied by the Prime Minister. Therefore, I am even more disturbed if that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an escalation in the abuse by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this chamber. When he spoke to some school children at his old school in Sydney, he denigrated the Senate. This led to criticism in this chamber of the Prime Minister. Later a Senate inquiry was appointed to look into the misconduct of his Treasurer and his own Government in the loans affair in Victoria. The Prime Minister chose to abuse the Senate by calling it `unrepresentative swill'.

PARA.TAB: This is not coming from nowhere; it is in the context of the Prime Minister resenting the Senate and its powers to investigate his failures and mistakes. I have heard what was written in the Age about your own conversation with him, Mr President. If the Prime Minister dares to say to the President of the Senate anything that is compromising of this Parliament, the constitution of the Senate or respect for you as President of the Senate, then he stands in even worse contempt than the contempt with which the people of Australia regard him at the moment.

It is no light matter for it even to be alleged that the Prime Minister of this country is abusing the President of the Senate when he is approaching him in good faith. No-one has questioned your integrity at all, Mr President, even in the Opposition's questioning of the phrasing of your statement to us on the last sitting day. No-one would suggest that a leak of this kind, right or wrong, could have come from you.

The Prime Minister of this land is constantly leaking material to newspapers. It is in the context of an escalation of his attack on the Senate that he would have the gall to allow such a leak and give such a story to a highly credible journalist, Michelle Grattan, and allow her to write such an article. If any independent witness can show that the Prime Minister tried to make some statement to the President of this chamber that went even mildly in this direction, then the Prime Minister deserves a double censure from the Senate.

I conclude by saying that what Senator Knowles outlined when moving this motion happens to have been my experience at the weekend when I returned to the State of South Australia, which I represent. Senator Button is very interested in this point. I met with hundreds of people during a very busy weekend and attended many community functions and other meetings. Even to my surprise, on the lips of all of them was a knowledge of the Prime Minister's contempt for this Parliament when he described the Senate as `unrepresentative swill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are sensitive about you.

—They are sensitive, and Senator Button should learn to protest his colleague the Prime Minister's behaviour. The people of Australia are fed up with politicians who abuse power and language and bring down the institution of Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button and his colleagues should tell the Prime Minister. He has a chance tomorrow in the Caucus to lay it on the line to the Prime Minister that he is pulling down the institutions of this country and at the same time ruining any chance the Labor Party might have of retaining some seats in the House of Representatives after the next election. There will be a change of government and the Labor Party Government can pin that blame directly on its Prime Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to speak on this matter, but I do object to Senator Teague dealing lightly with the truth when he refers to a Senate inquiry into the `misconduct' of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). There is no Senate inquiry into the misconduct of the Treasurer. That is part of the propaganda that the Opposition has sought to make in respect of this inquiry when, of course, the important comment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was that the Opposition was engaged in a political stunt—which it is.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague is part of that stunt when he comes in here and uses words like `misconduct of the Treasurer' because that is a matter which is by no means established and will not be established. Senator Teague is putting himself into the same category as his colleague Senator Bishop. Senator Bishop says before the inquiry is set up that the whole business is a cover-up. He is making the same sort of judgment before the inquiry is even established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you?

—The onus of proof is on those who allege, and this allegation has been made by a number of people. Senator Teague's putting himself in the same basket as Senator Bishop on this issue perhaps says something about his reluctance to be a member of the inquiry—because he has prejudged it just as Senator Bishop has. She does not have the same sort of reluctance about these matters, but that is a matter of regret to the parliamentary system as a whole.

—The central issue of this motion before the Senate is the excessive use of the Executive power to denigrate a House of parliament, namely the Senate. If democracy is to mean anything in this country, and if it is indeed to survive this generation, it is up to us as parliamentarians to uphold the principle of the supremacy of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Senate may at times be uncomfortable, and at times it may not be easy for governments to get their legislation through. At times it requires skill. That skill is demanded of every person who sits in this place and in the other place. Unfortunately, in recent times we have seen a reduction in those skills. What we see in the other House, which we will not tolerate and should not tolerate in this place, is the slanging matches, the gutter politics and the guillotine.

I put it to you, Mr President, that you are elected to this very high office and that we in here, and the Australian people, expect you to uphold the dignity and the role of this Senate chamber. I ask you to carry out that task to the best of your ability.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the comments made, firstly to Senator Watson: I have always tried to do that, from the moment I was first elected, and I will continue to do it. I am in the process of writing a letter to all senators on this matter, which was the statement I made last week. I promised to do that, I think last Thursday.

PARA.TAB: I would like to point out that a large number of issues were raised in the debate last week and I am attempting to answer all of those issues. I am going back through precedents. I will finish the letter as quickly as possible, but I am not going to rush it out this afternoon.

I would like to point out to Senator Hill that I did not liaise with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in a political matter. I spoke to a senior member of his staff and said that I wished to speak to the Prime Minister. Naturally, I was asked what the issue was. The issue was the fact that Senator Hill and Senator Short had just been to see me and raised an issue with me. I said at that stage that I was contemplating writing a letter in response to the approach they had made, but that I was thinking it over and was seeking advice from the Clerk of the Senate. That is as far as that conversation went. Later that evening—and I have pointed out the functions that I had to attend that night—when I was able to speak to the Prime Minister, I advised him of my statement, and that is all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who as believers in the Lord Jesus enjoy fellowship together and are governed by the absolute authority of God's Word in the Holy Bible.
Your petitioners draw to the attention of the House the following aspects of the Family Law Act which disregard God's law:

1.The non-allowance of adultery as a basis for divorce, when in fact, Scripture teaches that it is the only basis for divorce. "Whosoever shall put away his wife not for fornication and shall marry another commits adultery" (Matthew 19:9).

2.The recognition of de facto relationships as equivalent to marriage. Such sinful relationships are clearly fornication or adultery. According to Scripture "Fornicators and adulterers will God judge" (Hebrews 13:4). Marriage, as an institution of God Himself, is to be held in every way in honour.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Family Law Act be amended to:
1.Re-include adultery as ground for divorce.
2.Uphold the sanctity of marriage and cease to accommodate de facto relationships.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia, who are Christian believers together in the Lord Jesus, upholding in its absolute authority the Holy Bible as the infallible, inspired Word of God.
Your petitioners draw the attention of the House to the widespread and increasing concern, distress and difficulties to many the administration of the Family Law Act is causing.

It is respectfully submitted that the significant omission in the Act of the recognition of God, His Word and Law is contributing to this, specifically evidenced in the `no fault' provision for the settlement of divorce. The only scriptural reason for divorce is adultery; the Lord Jesus Himself saying "Whosoever shall put away his wife, except it be for fornication, and shall marry another committeth adultery; and whoso marrieth her which is put away doth commit adultery." Matthew 19 v 9.
Your petitioners therefore as duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House that:
The Family Law Act be amended to re-introduce adultery as a grounds of divorce, in view of obtaining God's blessing with the stability and prosperity that results from adhering to His Word.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia, who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ . . . one seeks to live a pious and godly life, keeping His commandments, His word and His doctrine, and practice the things which are pleasing in His sight. Therefore each one recognises the absolute authority of God's word as contained in the Holy Bible.

Your petitioners draw to the attention of the House two points of the Family Law Act which has caused considerable burden for many years. It has also contributed to and accelerated the degrading conditions of humanity in this country. These two points are :
(1)Adultery is not allowed as a basis for divorce
(2)De facto relationships are equated to marriage

This is a direct contradiction to the words of our Lord Jesus: "But I say unto you, that whosoever shall put away his wife not for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery; and he who marries one put away commits adultery" (Matthew 19 v 9). De facto relationships are either fornication or adultery and it is stated clearly in Scripture: "Let marriage be held every way in honour, and the bed be undefiled; for fornicators and adulterers will God judge" (Hebrews 13 v 4).

In a so-called Christian country as Australia, and where the Bible is used in commencement of both Parliamentary sessions and in Law Courts as an assertion of truth, we request that the authority of its word be adhered to and that the Family Law Act is amended accordingly.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound pray to this end, and will support in prayer any movement in the right direction regarding this matter.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia. Each signatory has read The Holy Scriptures and accepts the authority of God's Word as contained therein. Belief on the Lord Jesus Christ provides common ground in support of this petition.

Your petitioners are regular in their prayerful support of Government, believing that it is ordained of God (Romans chap 13). For a long time now they have felt that Parliament should accept its responsibility before God and address the serious question of abortion. Your petitioners think quite definitely that Parliament, as a Parliament that is answerable to God, should soberly and honestly act on this issue.

Because life is destroyed when abortion is practised, your petitioners point out that it is thus a sin against the Almighty God Who is the giver of life (Job chap 1 v 21). Is not one of the functions of Parliament to act for the preservation of life? But abortion is murder.
Your petitioners point out therefore the serious nature of Medicare funding of abortion. By doing this, wickedness is being supported and facilitated.

Your petitioners therefore as in duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House, that Parliament will accept its responsibility before God, and cause that Medicare funding of abortion be terminated as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who, as believers in the Lord Jesus Christ, desire to live by the inspired Word of God as contained in the Holy Bible.

The attention of the Senate is drawn to the fact that the practice of abortion as supported by Medicare funding is in direct conflict with the Word of God. God alone has the sovereign right to give life and to take it away. (Job 1 v 21). The infringement of God's rights through the practice of abortion constitutes a sin against God Whose clear commandment is "Thou shalt not kill".

Your petitioners pray that the Senate recognise its responsibility as "ordained of God" and act without delay to terminate the funding of abortion through Medicare. Such action is needed for "the advancement of God's glory and the true welfare of the people of Australia"—as expressed in the Parliamentary opening prayer.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating should be condemned for his disgraceful public attack on our national flag in a foreign country. The petitioners note that his public remarks
discredited our proud history and unique culture
degraded the efforts of all servicemen and women
insulted and embarrassed proud Australians
damaged our international reputation as a united and patriotic democratic nation
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Mr Keating apologise to the Australian people for his demeaning behaviour in a foreign country.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.

PARA.TAB: Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners, concerning parents and consumers respectfully request that the Broadcasting Services Bill which will control Television and Pay Television, will:
prohibit all considerably violent programs,
prohibit indecent and obscene programs, (to protect the young and impressionable),
prohibit blasphemous programs which denigrate religious faith or belief,
establish strict legally enforceable standards for programs and hours,

PETITION.PARA: ensure that "nothing is included that will offend against good taste and decency"

PARA.TAB: ensure that films are judged not as a whole, but each in its several parts,
that the Bill underpins and supports pro-social media in spirit and intent,
reject industry codes that will sell out Australia's defenceless children,
exempt all classification criteria and hours from s149d,
ensure genuine consumer consultation, so that parents can have access to program criteria information, and input into decision-making for their home environment.
Because children are defenceless and helpless, because they have no vote, no power, and no advocate other than you.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the draft Broadcasting Services Bill does not prohibit extremely violent or pornographic films/videos being carried by Pay TV;

That the Bill fails to ensure the permanent removal of blasphemous, indecent or obscene content on television and radio but leaves the ultimate decisions on standards and codes of practice to an unelected Australian Broadcasting Authority.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remedy these defects and to provide for decent standards in the legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Loosley and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, Senator Loosley shall withdraw notice of motion No. 3 standing in his name for 10 sitting days after today for disallowance of the Federal Airports (Amendment) By-laws No. 1 1992 made under section 72 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 17 September 1992
Senator the Hon. Peter Cook
Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT
Dear Minister

I refer to Federal Airports Corporation Regulations (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 255) and Federal Airports (Amendment) By-laws No. 1 1992, which the Committee considered at its meeting of 17 September 1992.
In respect of the regulations, the Committee draws the following matters to your attention:
First, it appears that there are several possible errors in the regulations:

(a)Regulation 9(4) refers to certain actions mentioned in `subparagraphs (2)(iv) to (ix) (inclusive)'. The Committee assumes that the reference should probably be to `subparagraphs (2)(a)(iv) to (ix) (inclusive)'.
(b)Regulation 10(5) refers to
`the area identified as "G" in the dredging area'.

`Dredging area' is not defined in the regulations, but as there is a specific definition of `dredging site' in regulation 3(1), the Committee concludes that regulation 10(5) should refer to `dredging site'.
(c)There appears to be a small typographical error in the last line of clause 8 of the Schedule 1, where `addresses' should probably be `addressed'.

Secondly, regulation 13 gives to the Chief Executive Officer power to delegate his or her powers `in writing to an employee'. The Committee notes that the definition of `employee' in section 3(1) of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 refers to a person employed under s. 61(1) which provides that the
`Corporation may employ such persons as it thinks necessary for the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers'.
As the power of delegation seems to be a very wide one, the Committee would appreciate advice as to its breadth in the present context.

In respect of the by-laws, the Committee notes that by-law 15G.9 enables an airport officer to serve a smoking infringement fine, to be paid immediately, for certain offences. In contrast to the smoking infringement notice system also established by these by-laws, the fines system does not set out the level of the fines or, for example, the currency in which such fines might be paid. The Committee has in mind here transit passengers who may be unable to pay a fine in Australian currency. It would also be interested to establish what steps would be taken if a person were unable or unwilling to pay the fine.
The Committee would appreciate your advice on these matters and also as to whether the system of penalties under the by-laws have been established under other instruments of delegated legislation.
Yours sincerely
Stephen Loosley
Chairman
Senator Stephen Loosley
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Loosley

I refer to your letter of 17 September 1992 in which you drew my attention to a number of matters arising from the Committee's consideration of the Federal Airports Corporation Regulations (Statutory Rules 1992 No. 255) (the Regulations) and the Federal Airports (Amendment) By-laws No. 1 1992 (the By-laws).

I confirm that the matters raised in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of your letter are indeed typographical errors within the Regulations and thank the Committee for drawing them to my attention. Although these matters affect neither the clear intention nor the validity of the Regulations, I would propose that they be corrected when the Regulations are next amended.

As to the second matter you raised in relation to the Regulations, namely the apparent width of the power of delegation, I am advised that the only delegates to date are the General Manager, Sydney Airport and the Manager, Technical Services at Sydney Airport. Both of these people have detailed knowledge of the project, the environmental impact statement and the recommendations of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (as she then was). Due to the environmental sensitivity of this project, the Corporation does not intend to delegate powers under the Regulations to any persons other than senior managers who have direct personal knowledge of the project requirements and environmental processes.

In relation to the By-laws, I advise that the smoking infringement fine and notice systems work in tandem. The various offences and penalties are spelt out in by-laws 15G.2, 15G.4 and 15G.8. Where a person breaches by-law 15G.2 (smoking in a terminal building) the airport officer may proceed by way of a smoking infringement notice only. However, where a person breaches by-law 15G.4 (failure to answer questions relating to identity) or 15G.8 (failure to comply with a direction to extinguish smoking materials) the airport officer may proceed by way of a smoking infringement fine, payable immediately. In each case, the penalties are spelt out in the relevant offence provisions, namely, by-laws 15G.2, 15G.4 and 15G.8. The system of penalties under the By-laws has not been established under any other instrument of delegated legislation.

As with all Australian statutes, the penalties are payable in Australian currency. As you would be aware, all Australian international airports have facilities for the exchange of foreign currency. In any event, the fact that penalties are payable in Australian currency would not preclude an airport officer accepting payment in foreign currency to an equivalent value.

Finally, you have sought my advice as to what steps would be taken if a person were unable or unwilling to pay the fine. This would clearly depend upon the particular circumstances of the breach. However, in the case of a recalcitrant smoker the FAC's ultimate sanction would be to refer the matter to the Federal Police as it would any other criminal act.
I hope that the above information is of assistance to your Committee.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to comment briefly on the state of the program under this heading of `Placing of Business'.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate but I feel I must protest the state of the program and the shambles that is now before the chamber. It really makes it absolutely impossible for the chamber to properly fulfil its scrutiny role. This morning, the shadow Ministry was presented with 46 new Bills that it had to deal with. We have had to call a party meeting this morning to deal with legislation that has only just been received by us but has yet to be debated in the House of Representatives this week. Legislation is being shoved through this parliamentary process with no proper consideration at all. The Government might not worry so much about that in the House of Representatives but we do worry about it in this place because it is an important part of our function.

PARA.TAB: The workload that is now being put before the Senate simply cannot be properly dealt with in the time that is available. We have not finished the Appropriation Bills yet; we have not got to the committee stage of the Appropriation Bills in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they weren't ready the other night when we finished.

—We managed to progress the Government's program towards the end of last week, so we could have had a day on the committee stage of the Appropriation Bills and, for some reason, the Government was not ready. Yet we had these 46 packages of legislation before the Opposition shadow Ministry this morning and we are now presented with eight pages of Bills which have to be addressed in terms of whether they should go to a Senate scrutiny committee before being dealt with here. As I said, all of this is supposed to be dealt with within a further three weeks of sitting after this sitting week.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to unduly delay the Senate. But look at this list of Bills: the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Amendment Bill; the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill, which I should have thought would have required very careful consideration; the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Bill; the Australian National Training Authority Bill; Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill; Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2); Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1992; the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992; Customs Legislation Amendment Bill and two other Customs Bills; the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill, which Senator Patterson would be interested to see, and which needs to be dealt with particularly carefully.

Also on the list are the Endangered Species Protection Bill, which is a major piece of legislation that has recently had a lot of publicity; the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill; the Farm Household Support Bill; the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), and health and community services legislation is always complicated; the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill; the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2); the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill; the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2); the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill; the Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill; the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Foreign Investment) Bill 1992; the Medicare Agreements Bill and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2); the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Bill; and several more migration reform Bills, one specifically referred to as the Migration Reform Bill.

The list continues with the Mutual Recognition Bill; the National Health Amendment Bill; the National Residue Survey Administration Bill, and it seems that there are several pages of those; the Qantas Sale Bill—a major piece of legislation needing to be dealt with within this ridiculous time frame; the National Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill; the National Residue Survey Wheat Bill; the Rural Adjustment Bill; several pieces of sales tax legislation; Sex Discrimination and Other Legislation Amendment Bill; the Social Security Legislation Bill; a series of States grants Bills; Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill; and Taxation Laws Amendment (Car Parking) Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will never get through them!
—This is what we are supposed to deal with properly with full scrutiny in a period of three weeks.
—But this isn't the lot.

—No, this is not the program. Today we have to consider whether these Bills should go to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills as part of the procedure for the proper scrutiny of legislation. There is also the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill 1992; several pieces of veterans' affairs legislation; and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Bill.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the practice has been for the program to get worse with each sitting session during the period of the Hawke Government and then the Keating Government. But it has never got as bad as it has got today. This is a government in shambles; it has not got its program properly together because it is preoccupied with electoral matters and defending the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), abusing the Senate and other matters that the Prime Minister obviously considers to be of higher priority. But unless we put on the record at the moment our protest at the state of this program, we are going to be told in a few weeks' time that we have not been handling it properly. The point is that if we had been handling it properly, we could have got on to the Appropriations debate last Thursday; the Government was not ready and now we are presented with this mass of legislation that it says should be processed properly before the end of this session, in three weeks.

This will be another test for the Australian Democrats. When are they going to join with the Government in passing the guillotine motion this session as they have in all previous sessions after swearing they would never do it? When are we going to come in here one morning and find that the conspiracy has happened? Senator McMullan will get up and say, `With the support of the Australian Democrats, I wish to apply the guillotine motion' which will ensure that legislation in the Senate is not dealt with properly before the Christmas recess. It is not good enough. The Senate should protest about this abuse of the program and it is about time it got its program in order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 November, from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill:

PARA.TAB: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

INTERJECT.PARA: Noting that a Federal election can be called at any time, the need for the Senate to express its support for the Prime Minister's commitment on 5 November 1992 that in Opposition `the Labor Party would not obstruct the passage of the GST legislation in the Senate', in view of the fact that the introduction of a GST will enable:

PARA.TAB: (a)personal income tax to be reduced by 30%;
(b)wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the tax on fuel to be abolished;
(c)family allowances to be doubled for lower income families; and
(d) tax cheats to bear a fairer share of the tax burden.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

Noting that a Federal election can be called at any time, the need for the Senate to express its support for the Prime Minister's commitment on 5 November 1992 that in Opposition `the Labor Party would not obstruct the passage of the GST legislation in the Senate', in view of the fact that the introduction of a GST will enable:
(a)personal income tax to be reduced by 30%;
(b)wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the tax on fuel to be abolished;
(c)family allowances to be doubled for lower income families; and
(d) tax cheats to bear a fairer share of the tax burden.

SPEECH.PARA: This urgency debate today will give Labor senators the opportunity to stand behind the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the decision he made the other day that the Labor Party in opposition would support the key parts of the Opposition's Fightback program, specifically including the goods and services tax. It is important that the matter be debated today in order to give Labor senators that opportunity, as we read that some of them are already suggesting otherwise outside the chamber. I noticed that one senator is quoted by Bruce Jones in last weekend's Sun-Herald. Bruce Jones put the senator's words into quotes; he is a reputable journalist, so I am sure the quote would be accurate. He said that one senator said to him:
If we lose government, Keating—even assuming he is still around—isn't going to have much of a say in what we do.

That comment is said to have come from one senior ALP senator at the end of last week. We know that the ALP Caucus members were taken by surprise in this announcement by the Prime Minister, but this will give them the opportunity to stand up today and say, `We agree with the Prime Minister that a coalition government should be supported in its Fightback program because the people would have given it the mandate to implement that program'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will we hear from Barney Cooney again?

—I am sure Senator Cooney will stand there and support it. Why is it urgent? It is urgent because we are about to have a Federal election and the Australian people are entitled to know whether this is just the view of the Prime Minister or whether the Caucus is going to support him. Why is that important? It is important because tax reform will, as this motion indicates, give the opportunity for personal income tax to be reduced by 30 per cent. Fightback provides for personal income tax in this country to be reduced by 30 per cent—the largest income tax reduction in Australia's history. It will enable wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the tax on fuel to be abolished. The wholesale sales tax, much recognised for its inefficient structure, payroll tax, which is a tax on jobs, and the tax on fuel, which particularly hurts those in rural Australia and small businesses, will all be abolished. That is included in the Fightback program and it is part of the benefit of the restructuring of tax. This tax reform will enable family allowances to be doubled for lower income families and it will require that tax cheats bear a fairer share of the tax burden.

PARA.TAB: That is what the restructuring of the taxation system is all about and that is what can be achieved with an implementation of the coalition's Fightback program. It is therefore urgent that Labor Party senators in this place stand behind the Prime Minister and indicate that in opposition they would be prepared to support the Fightback program. That is why we bring forward this motion today and that is why it is urgent.

It was not really surprising for us to hear that the Prime Minister, in some ways, did not hold such a strong objection to a goods and services tax or to consumption taxes generally because he has previously supported those taxes. I am going to spend a little time today, Mr Acting Deputy President, reminding you of the occasions on which the Prime Minister has supported a goods and services tax in this country because it demonstrates the hypocrisy of this man and it demonstrates really where he does stand on the economic issue of whether this tax reform is in the best interests of Australia.

Is it not amazing? There could be no other person in this Parliament who could get up and say, on the one hand, `In opposition we will support this tax'; yet, on the other hand, describe it as a vile tax. Who else could flick the switch in the way Mr Keating can? We never can be absolutely sure where his genuine belief lies; whatever is most politically opportune at the moment is what we get from Mr Keating. He obviously decided the other day that political opportunism required him to make this statement as to what the Labor Party would do in opposition.

We can go back in history to the time when he was formulating the tax policy and look at what he said about the need for Australia to have a goods and services tax. In 1985 he was taking the running on the issue; he got rolled in the end by the trade union movement in concert with some of the social security lobby groups. Nevertheless, he made it absolutely unambiguously clear that it was in Australia's best interests to have a consumption tax, to have a goods and services tax, to have a VAT, in other words, to broaden the tax base in this way—

TALK.START.PARA: —Without exemptions.

—As Senator Ferguson interjected, Mr Keating wished to broaden the tax base without exemptions. I am going to remind honourable senators specifically what he had to say on that matter. He started this process on the Sunday program on 12 May 1985, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of tax reform is unambiguously to redistribute the burden of taxes, not to facilitate an increase in that burden.
He recognised the need in this country to redistribute the burden of taxes. In an interview on 4 June 1985, he said:
If we don't as a nation adopt this proposal (option C)—
that was his option for a consumption tax—
then you won't see significant reform in this country in taxation for the balance of this century.

He said on 4 June 1985 that unless we implement a consumption tax as part of the restructuring of taxation in this country, then we will not see decent taxation reform for the balance of this century. He went on to say:
This would result in a manifestly fairer tax system, and would create the foundations for a more efficient system to promote stronger economic growth and higher living standards.
This is Mr Keating defending the need—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?
—This is Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, defending the need for a restructuring of the tax system to include a consumption tax because it is necessary to develop, in his words:

SPEECH.PARA: a more efficient system to promote stronger economic growth and higher living standards.

That is everything the coalition is saying which he now condemns because he has flicked the switch of political opportunism. It is now not to his political advantage to support these statements, so he has flicked the switch and taken a different point of view. He said:
. . . we'd use every cent of the proceeds to provide significant tax cuts and to increase benefits.

That is Mr Keating; that is not Dr Hewson. While I am on that subject, it reminds me of the mischief that this Government is talking about our tax proposals as additional taxes. I think we heard it from Senator Button today in Question Time. Fightback is a program that reduces the tax take in this country by about $6 billion. It restructures the taxation system from within, but it substantially reduces taxation. Fightback is a low tax program and it is important that the Australian people know that. They should not believe what Senator Button says, or members of the Government who, for purposes of political opportunism, simply suggest something else.

PARA.TAB: I come back to what the now Prime Minister Keating was saying in 1985. I remind honourable senators of his speech to the National Press Club on 5 June of that year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is now well recognised that the Australian tax system is unfair. It is also widely appreciated that it encourages inefficiency and is extraordinarily complex.
What has changed? Nothing has changed. He went on to say:
Clearly, there is a need for action: for reform.

He said that we must commit ourselves to a number of different propositions, the first of which is that the tax base must be broadened. Here he is again, endorsing the principle of broadening the tax base through some form of value added tax, as practically every other industrialised country in the world has done. It is not surprising that he was standing with all of the rest of the industrialised world. He said:
the ideals of tax reform require us to commit ourselves to lower marginal tax rates.
That is the Fightback program. He said:
we should attempt to use the tax system to solve every problem that looks too difficult to solve in some other way.

He went on to state something which I particularly want to remind the Senate about. He put down what he saw as the third main advantage of Australia's adopting a consumption tax. I remind the Senate that this is Mr Keating, the now Prime Minister of Australia, who was putting down these reasons which he said made out the case for a consumption tax for Australia. He said:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax . . .

He is the one who is now saying the wholesale sales tax is perfect. He was saying in 1985, as we do now, and as every reasonable, objective person says, that it is full of anomalies. He went on to say that it could replace the anomalous wholesale sales tax system which had allowed multiple rates and numerous exemptions and which failed to tax the services sector. He is now going to condemn us for taxing services and in 1985 he was saying it was necessary for Australia to tax services if it was to catch up with the rest of the world in having an equitable and efficient taxation system.

PARA.TAB: He then went on to his second reason for a consumption tax in this country. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax.

This, I remind honourable senators again, is Fightback. If you broaden the tax base, you can get income tax marginal rates down. That is why we can reduce income tax across the board by about 30 per cent—as I said a minute ago, the largest income tax reductions in Australia's history. We are going to broaden the base of taxation and in 1985 Mr Keating endorsed that as the only way to go in the best interests of Australia. He said:
No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
He was right again.

PARA.TAB: The third reason he gave for supporting a consumption tax was that it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax. What have we said? Catch the tax cheats. We have said that in a motion today, and what was Mr Keating saying in 1985? Implement a consumption tax because it will catch the tax cheats. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: That provides a useful "net dividend" for distribution to the rest of the community.
That is what we are all about—redistributing the tax to the benefit of those most in need.

PARA.TAB: I further quote Mr Keating as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: For too long the politically unpalatable decisions have been put off in this country because our politicians have not had the strength of purpose to tackle the hard issues.

Mr Keating was saying then that our politicians had not had the strength of purpose, and yet he condemns Dr Hewson for having that strength of purpose. Of all things, after accusing Dr Hewson of being rigid in wanting to stick to the program, he then tries to justify his statement of last week by saying that members of the coalition are going around secretly saying to Australian voters, `Don't worry, because it won't get through the Senate'. We want to be elected to government in this country because we want to implement Fightback in full. It will give this country a chance again; it will give hope to Australians; and it includes the restructuring of the tax system in a more equitable and efficient way.

PARA.TAB: It was so easy for the now Prime Minister to endorse statements when he was not in the political opportunistic position he is at the moment. He went on to say in 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: The country has not been working to the peak of its achievable capacity because we, as a community, have not been prepared to let it do so.
That was his position as Treasurer of this country and has been as Prime Minister of this country. He said:

I'll be barracking for a broad-based consumption tax at a rate which assesses that income which has been avoided and evaded . . . The consumption tax has been designed with an awareness of the need to ensure that those who are needy and cannot benefit from income tax cuts will receive full, or more than full compensation.

What is Fightback all about? Pensioners, and all those who have a particular need, are fully—in fact, over-generously—compensated in Fightback, which is what Mr Keating said he was going to do back in 1985. We can still give benefit to families, for example, by doubling family allowances for lower income earners; in other words, try to develop the social benefits that are important in this country and that are in accordance with the values that we believe are important.

PARA.TAB: I will go on with more quotes from Mr Keating. On 6 June in the Canberra Times he was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the outcome is concerned, one has to do what one believes is right in the final analysis and I believe this is right—
That is, to implement a consumption tax—
that's why I am doing it. If there are any kicks to the backside to take, I'll take them.

As soon as he saw a political opportunity in ditching it, he ditched it, and forgot the kicks in the backside. There is only one side of Australian politics which is prepared to stand up and take the political heat on this issue because it is in the best interests of the Australian people, and that is the coalition.

PARA.TAB: It is amazing how many times Mr Keating reiterated his views back in 1985. In a speech in Melbourne he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We must all recognise that it would be all too easy in this debate to inflame fears and prejudice.

What is he doing now? He is going around the country inflaming fears and prejudice, and he should be condemned for doing so. Rather than wanting to debate the issue rationally and the merits of the tax that he supported in 1985, he is trying to run a scare campaign by inflaming fears and prejudice.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters should listen to this; this is Mr Keating in 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: The emotive claim of the screaming headline will always be a strong temptation.
He has fallen for it this time. On 10 June 1985, in the Adelaide Advertiser, justifying the tax on necessities, he said:

I think the public understands that they now have to buy all these necessities and they have to buy after they are slugged every week, and if we relieve their tax with large tax cuts they are better off.

What he is saying is that the broader the indirect tax base, the better; give consumers the capacity to pay for it through substantial tax cuts. That is exactly what we have done in Fightback. He ought to have the courage to endorse it in Australia's best interests because in 1985 he said it was in Australia's best interests.

PARA.TAB: In an AAP interview on 13 June 1985, talking again about the oppressive high marginal rates of tax in Australia, he said that that was a reason to restructure the tax and have as broad a base as possible. He said that they were too high—they were very high, in fact. He said that if we could get down marginal rates it would be easier for people to pay for them out of relieved income. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The best way of making these taxes operate effectively and efficiently is with minimum exemptions—
and Senator Kemp should listen to this; Mr Keating said—
and with a single rate; that is the lesson which comes from all over the world.

What has the Fightback! program done again? Exactly that. Minimum exemptions, get big tax cuts of marginal rates and we will be better off and start to have a taxation system competitive with those with whom we have to compete.

PARA.TAB: I could go on. In the Canberra Times he says again how distorted the current wholesale sales tax is and how it has different rates, with some goods being taxed 20 per cent and some at 32 per cent. He says it is an unsatisfactory taxation system. He goes on in the Sun-Herald on 16 June talking about those who are rorting the income tax system and how broadening the tax base through a goods and services tax or a consumption tax will help overcome that. He talks about the slack economic climate and how tax reform can provide more benefit through having a competitive taxation system. He says specifically that it is absolutely important that the necessities of life be included otherwise we will simply be reintroducing distortions back into the taxation system.

On those occasions the Prime Minister has totally endorsed the Fightback taxation program. Now he has flicked the switch of opportunism, abandoned the tax and said that it is vile. In rational debate he is putting down his case, repeating it time and time again, and now all of a sudden because it suits him politically it becomes vile. That is why Australians cannot believe a word that this Prime Minister says. We never hear what he really believes is economically in the best interests of the country as an election approaches. We then hear what is political opportunism.

I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that practically every industrialised country in the world has implemented the reform that we seek to implement. Why have they done it? Because they recognise the need to get taxes off productivity. If we take them off productivity, we obviously have to provide revenue in some other form and consumption has all sorts of other benefits. It encourages saving and so forth. I suggest that Senator Button, who has an interest in these matters, look at the most recent IMF document that I have—I will give him the references if he likes—that talks about the value of this form of indirect tax both to the revenue because of its neutrality and, in particular, because of its efficiency. That is why we are seeking to implement it.

For 10 years this Government has failed the Australian people. The situation in which we find this country now is one of misery. At least one million Australians are unemployed, we have terrible current account figures and a foreign debt that has quadrupled under Labor. It is a shocking legacy to leave our successors. That is the legacy of Labor. That is its record after 10 years of Government. That is what it is going to take to the Australian people. What do we do? We have the courage to put down a comprehensive program that gives Australia the chance to recover and gives young people the chance to get jobs in the future. It gives businesses the chance to expand and employ and, generally speaking, gives Australians hope. That is what Fightback is all about. It has been implemented by a leader who has the courage to stand up and support it, not in the way that the Prime Minister has. As soon as the heat is put on, opportunism drives him down another track. The Leader of the Opposition is someone who will take this program to the Australian people and implement it. Today we have the opportunity for Labor senators to stand behind their Prime Minister and support it also. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —All that that speech by Senator Hill proves is that he has a good research assistant who can read press clippings, which Senator Hill can in turn read to the Senate. I did not take any objection to that speech, which was all read. It just shows that literacy is rising in the Liberal Party. It has an assistant who can read press clippings and Hansards and Senator Hill, who can read a prepared speech. That is all encouraging, I suppose, and for the good. I will be moving an amendment to this motion to delete all words after the word `Senate' in the middle of the motion. I will come to that later.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill give it all away at the end and said that the Opposition has courage to do all those things. There is no suggestion of brains, intelligence or anything like that. That was what was historically lacking in previous conservative governments—courage. That is why this Opposition sees itself as being different. It keeps screwing its courage to the sticking place on these issues because it is recognised by these people in 30 years of coalition governments that they did not have the courage to do any of these things.

Senator Hill quotes from a whole lot of statements by the Prime Minister, as former Treasurer, made in 1985. They are all irrelevant quotes. In 1985 the top marginal rate for income tax was 60 per cent; it is now 47 per cent. The corporate tax rate was 47 per cent; it is now 39 per cent. Since 1985 this Government has engaged in a whole range of taxation base broadening measures to which I want to refer the Senate. For example, we introduced the prescribed payments system to reduce the potential for fraud in the building industry and other subcontract industries. We introduced a capital gains tax—opposed by the Opposition—designed to underpin the integrity of the taxation system. We introduced a fringe benefits tax, opposed at the time by the Opposition. We introduced overseas tax haven legislation, opposed at the time by the Opposition. We introduced a tax file number, opposed at the time by the Opposition. We introduced an assets test to more fairly administer the pension system, opposed at the time by the Opposition, except Mr John Elliott, the President of the Liberal Party at the time, who was concerned with bigger numbers rather than those which involved pensioners and was able to see his way clear to support the base broadening of the tax.

To come in here today and make a speech prepared by some research assistant from extracts from Hansard and press clippings of 1985 without having any regard to the enormous changes which have been made in the Australian taxation system since then is really a bit of a furphy.

The GST is all about ideology in the Liberal Party and an essential ideological mix which involves higher taxes and lower wages. It involves higher taxes for everybody except those on $100,000 a year, the top income brackets. I will come to that in a moment. There is a pretence put in all of this that somehow it will be dealing with tax cheats. Mr Reith, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer, frequently refers to how the GST will deal with tax cheats. I remind Mr Reith and all Opposition senators here that the countries with the smallest black economy in the world per capita are the United States of America and Switzerland. Neither of those countries has a goods and services tax of this kind. To pretend that the goods and services tax will collect all sorts of items of revenue which are now not collected is a furphy of the first order.

The issues which confront this country today of most importance are not broadening of the taxation system. They are issues of longer term concern about employment—employment for young people and employment generation—the future structure of industry in Australia and what can be generated further by way of exports. These are all the issues which confront every Western democracy at present. President Clinton has arrived in the United States over Senator Bronwyn Bishop's dead body. She said that she could not contemplate him as President of the United States. Well, he is President of the United States and she will have to contemplate him. What are his major programs? Exactly those sorts of issues which are of predominant concern in the United States, to which one would add health. The United States will be about building a Medicare system of the kind we have in Australia at the same time as the Opposition is dismantling it. The United States will be doing that because 25 per cent of its population who get ill are not properly catered for or covered by the system in the US. That is the sort of thing President Clinton will be about.

In Britain we see the end of the Thatcher era falling apart in the hands of John Major. We see the end of the ideology of the conservatives of the past at exactly the same time as the Opposition wants to introduce that ideology into Australia. Over the weekend I was looking at a book by Sir Ian Gilmour, a former Minister in the Thatcher Government, who said that the only element of continuity in Thatcher Government economic policy was persistent self-congratulation. That was written by one of Mrs Thatcher's former Ministers in that Government.

There is plenty of self-congratulation by those in the Opposition in finding they have courage. Even if they have courage, the question is whether it is directed in the right way. The goods and services tax has nothing to do with the efficiency of the Australian economy, nor with the broad tax base we now have. It has nothing to do with fairness in our community. It has nothing to do with making this economy operate better in the ways which are vitally important to the Australian people and which I have already mentioned.

Of course, it is an inequitable tax. Let me deal with the question of equity. The Opposition claims that personal income tax cuts will be made. Those tax cuts do not compensate people with incomes under $40,000 for bracket creep and the price effects of the GST. The Treasury analysis of the distributional impact of the GST and the associated changes is that 70 per cent of households of full time wage and salary earners and about 60 per cent of self-employed people will be worse off under a GST. However, the Treasury analysis—and, indeed, Fightback!—shows that very high income households are made better off.

If we look at table 6.3 on page 43 of Fightback! we see that a person on $7,000 a year will receive $6.10 a week in tax benefits. A person on $100,000 a year will receive $159 a week. A person on a medium income of $25,000 to $30,000 will receive $22 up to $30 a week. If one's salary goes up to $80,000, one gets $140 a week in tax benefits in the tax package offered by the Fightback package.

The tax benefits all go to the very wealthy. To pretend that there is equity in all of that is very hard to deal with when one looks at the tables in Fightback!. The Treasury analysis shows that very high income households are better off—and too right they are. Not only will they get huge personal tax benefits of the sort I have read out; a goods and services tax on clothing and footwear and food does not bear nearly as much on high income earners as it does on low income earners. Low income earners spend more of their budgets on food, clothing and things of that sort than do higher income earners. So the poor and middle classes are made worse off. A household with children and one full time wage earner with an income of up to $57,000 a year would be $400 a year worse off. Similar situations apply with self-employed and farm households with incomes of up to $61,000 a year.

When we look at the impact of this proposed goods and services tax on business we see the same message. The switch from personal tax to a GST raises the compliance costs of the whole tax system. Costs paid by government and taxpayers in administration of the GST are higher per dollar of tax paid than for income taxes. A New Zealand study shows that compliance costs were much higher there, but the Opposition's GST will impose a massive burden particularly on small business. The GST will reduce the competitiveness of small business relative to larger business. This is a point which some Opposition senators have made here in the past.

There are 700,000 businesses in Australia which will become tax collectors for the Government under a GST. Small businesses which have exemptions from payroll tax will be forced to pay the GST. This means that their costs will be increased relative to large businesses. The fact is that there are 600,000 small businesses in Australia which do not pay payroll tax. What benefit is the Opposition offering them? The benefit it is offering them is a GST with all the paperwork associated with it and no payroll tax exemption.

Small businesses that do not pay wholesale sales tax will be forced to become tax collectors for the Government. There are 75,000 wholesale sales tax payers in Australia. There would be 800,000 payers of a goods and services tax. The administrative burden of all that will be massive. A recent independent study for the New Zealand Institute of Policy Studies of tax compliance costs in New Zealand showed that these costs are much higher for small business. The firms interviewed said:

SPEECH.PARA: The GST is the largest time consumer for small business.
I quote again:
The big problem is GST. This requires approximately one full day per two monthly return.

That is a country with a unicameral, unified system of government. There are not six States in New Zealand which administer separate taxes, separate laws and have special burdens imposed by the structure of Australian government on small businesses in New Zealand. Those things do not exist there. They do not exist in many of the other countries that have goods and services tax of some sort. Of course, they exist to some degree in the United States, which has no goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: The study in New Zealand showed that the compliance costs for the smallest firms were $26 per $1,000 of tax while for the biggest firms the corresponding figure was 5.4 per cent. Again, the GST is imposing burdens on small firms, imposing burdens on lowly paid people, rewarding the rich and rewarding the larger firms. That is particularly true in respect of the payroll tax set-off to which I referred a minute or two ago. The GST is more expensive to collect than PAYE tax and, therefore, it is an inefficient tax.

On this motion, Senator Hill devoted his time to talking about what Mr Keating said in a totally different environment in 1985 when there was no capital gains tax, no fringe benefits tax, when the corporate tax rate was much higher and when the top marginal rates were much higher for personal tax. Senator Hill spent all his time addressing that sort of irrelevant stuff. But I am concentrating on this motion, and the fact is that, if we look at the claims relating to family allowances being doubled, families will be made worse off by the GST. The Opposition does not compensate families for the taxes that it will impose on them. The Opposition, for example, will impose a tax on child-care. A conservative estimate is an extra $300 a year for each child.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is all very well for Senator Calvert to say `Rubbish'. Out there, nobody is satisfied with the blandishments which Senator Calvert's colleagues have put to them about these sorts of issues. For example, The Australian Catholic Welfare Committee report said:

SPEECH.PARA: From the point of view of its effect upon the poor and families . . . the dignity of the person and meaning of family life, one must question the moral legitimacy of the GST.
One must do that because baby clothes, prams, cots and car safety seats are currently all wholesale sales tax exempt—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that? Senator Short is in politics. I know I must not say `Boo' to him about anything. The GST will raise their prices by about 15 per cent.

—It is not my burden to do that; that is the Opposition's burden. Senator Hill has come here and moved this motion. Those opposite should put their money where their mouth is. The GST will raise the prices of all those things currently exempt from wholesale sales tax by 15 per cent. Books are currently wholesale sales tax exempt, but their prices will rise by about 15 per cent. All this adds up to costs which are a burden on the family.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I will deal with the question of the black hole in the costings of the goods and services tax. There is a $6 billion hole in the cost of the goods and services tax as estimated by the Opposition. How will it fill it? It says that it will catch all these tax cheats. An analysis of that scarcely bears examination.

A Treasury analysis shows that the Opposition has overestimated the effects of the GST on the black economy. In fact, Treasury says that the Opposition has a $1.9 billion hole in its package because it fails to account for the avoidance of GST and it wrongly assumes that the black economy will be caught by the GST. So much for the bumblings of the shadow Treasurer around the country when talking about the black economy and all of that.

The GST package has a total $6 billion hole in its financing. Revenue has been overestimated by $3.6 billion and expenditure savings have been overestimated by $2.6 billion. The overall $6 billion hole means that one would have to raise the GST, or abandon the promised tax cuts, as the Opposition did in 1977 when its previous Government went to the people of Australia promising tax cuts and never delivering them—fistfuls of dollars. Those opposite would have to abandon the promised tax cuts, reduce government services or drop the already hopelessly inadequate compensation packages. The whole question of compensation in this alleged package and new tax is a very vexed one indeed.

In order to cover up all these deficiencies, the Opposition talks about the black economy as if it were some magic pudding in which Mr Reith sticks his finger now and again, has a taste and comes up with a different result every time. It is a magic pudding which compensates for all the deficiencies in the financing of the Fightback package.

I conclude my remarks on this matter by referring again to the inequity. I draw people's attention to the special nature of the tax cuts which are offered in this document. Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) moving an amendment to the motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after " `the Labor Party would not obstruct the passage of the GST legislation in the Senate' ".

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill made some trite and silly points about this matter at the beginning of this debate. We are implacably opposed to a GST, but we do understand something about Senate principle. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us be quite clear about what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did in the House of Representatives last week. What he has done, as was further amplified by Senator Button a few moments ago, is to identify this absolutely horrible tax on food, clothing, perambulators, baby clothing, baby food and a number of other things which Senator Button has just identified—this GST on these necessities of life—as one of the worst things that could befall the Australian economy and one of the most disastrous things for the life and welfare of ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: But then Mr Keating petulantly said, `If you don't vote for me at the next election, even though I have the power after the election to block this iniquitous tax, I will simply not lift a finger to attempt to assist the Australian people and the Australian economy. I will simply stand aside and let this terrible tax be imposed on my fellow Australians'. That is what Mr Keating has done. In my view, anyone who will act in such a fit of pique to further his or her own power ambitions—and let us make no bones about it, that is what is involved here—does not deserve to be a representative of the people of Australia, much less the Prime Minister.

Two words stand out in my mind quite clearly as identifying the coming program for the next election—integrity and compassion. One thing I will certainly give to the Opposition is that at least throughout this lead-up to the election it has behaved with integrity. It has announced its Fightback package and stuck by its guns. However, I do not believe that it has acted with compassion because, as Senator Button said a moment ago, the GST and other parts of the package will impose difficulty upon the Australian public. I do not believe that the Government, particularly the Government as led by Mr Keating, has acted with either integrity or compassion because, having identified this terrible tax, the Government has said that in opposition it would support it.

It is now very clear that Mr Keating's interest is not in issues which vitally affect the Australian people. His interest is merely in using the Australian public as a pawn on the chessboard of Australian politics to advance his own personal ambition. Mr Keating says that he will support the GST in the Senate if Dr Hewson wins the next election because Dr Hewson would have, as he says, a mandate. We have tried to identify through questioning exactly how far that mandate extends, but so far without success.

This logic should also be applied to the rest of the Fightback package. The Opposition has clearly stated where it intends to take this package after the election, should it win government. The present Government's support for the GST portion of Fightback should also, by logic, be extended to the Opposition's industrial relations policy and to its attack on workers and unions, the health and social welfare system and this country's education system.

Mr Keating appears to reserve the right to vote against these other issues in the Senate. As Senator Hill said a few moments ago, this clearly identifies that Mr Keating still secretly supports the GST and is not only doublecrossing the Australian public in this double switch but the Australian Labor Party. I invite members of the Labor Party—not many are present—to take membership forms for the Liberal Party of Australia and join the Liberal Party, because I believe that that is where they should honestly reside.
Over the weekend there have been several comments in newspapers about this switch by Mr Keating. I will mention two in particular. The Telegraph Mirror of New South Wales said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter knows that Mr Keating's pledge will affect the Democrats' vote considerably. His complaints are self-serving and unjustifiable.

I want to lay that assertion to rest immediately. Our position in relation to the GST has been consistent all the way through. We are opposed to the GST for many of the fundamental reasons that have been identified by Senator Button today. Our position is that we will go into the election offering to oppose the GST after the election. The article goes on:
Mr Keating's pledge is a sign that at last Australia's politicians are treating voters with honesty . . .

We do not believe that it is treating voters with honesty to say that one will take a particular position before the election and offer it to the Australian voters and then simply reverse it after the election and vote against it. The article continues:
. . . if Dr Hewson wins the next election his reform program must be allowed to go through the Senate largely unchanged, for he will have a mandate from the people for his radical reforms.
The Canberra Times said similar things:
It is good policy—
this is the switch by Mr Keating—

because, whatever Labor might think of the GST, it is plainly a platform article for the Coalition; if it won a majority at the next election, it would have an undoubted right to claim a popular mandate to put it into effect.

It may be that the editors of some of our newspapers are literate, but they are quite innumerate. It is a matter of record that, at the 1990 election, the Labor Party obtained 39.4 per cent of the vote in the House of Representatives. When, I ask those editors, is over 60 per cent of voters voting against a particular party not a majority? A majority of people in Australia voted against Labor at the last election. I believe that at the next election a majority of voters will vote against the coalition parties; they will not get over 50 per cent of the vote. Therefore, simply getting a majority of the seats in the House of Representatives does not constitute a mandate for Labor to carry out either some or all of its program.

PARA.TAB: The Constitution says quite clearly that the Parliament consists of two Houses, a House of Representatives and a Senate. With only a few exceptions, the powers of those two Houses are identical. All legislation must pass both Houses of the Parliament before it becomes law, and to try and argue that one House is more important than the other and that one House takes some sort of primacy simply does not find its origins in the Constitution.

The powers of the Senate are set out in the Australian Constitution. Apart from differing powers with respect to money Bills—and I will come back to that term in a moment—the two Houses are equal in power. The differences in respect of money Bills are technical in nature and reflect the merging of two systems of government, the Westminster system and the US federal based senate system.

The Constitution limits the power of the Senate in two ways only: by prescribing that certain legislation must originate in the House of Representatives—which surely does not impact in any way on the power of the Senate to modify that legislation—and by limiting the power of the Senate to amend some forms of legislation.

The two types of Bills which must originate in the House of Representatives are the Appropriation Bills and the Bills imposing taxation. With respect to taxation, I point to section 55 of the Constitution, in case there are some journalists listening, which says that taxation Bills cannot be linked to other pieces of legislation. It would be impossible to obscure the GST by linking it to some other piece of legislation. Section 55 says that that would make those other sections invalid.

Appropriation and taxation Bills which must originate in the House of Representatives simply reflect the right of the Government to frame its Budget and impose new taxes. This does not in any sense limit the power of the Senate to modify those things. It simply refers to the piece of legislation which creates the liability, not the huge number of Bills that we deal with in every session which are collection and other machinery Bills. A very recent example was the abolition of sales tax on recycled paper products. This was a taxation measure which the coalition initially was minded to oppose, but in the end supported. Clearly, the Opposition recognised that it could modify, amend and change that legislation.

There is one further qualification on the powers of the Senate. The Senate may not amend any Bill to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people. This provision under subsection 53(3) of the Constitution in effect reinforces the rule that laws imposing taxation should originate in the House of Representatives, but its scope has never been tested. However, although the Senate does not have the power to amend these limited categories of Bills, it specifically does have the right to reject them or to request the House of Representatives to amend them so that they can then be passed.

The Australian Democrats have pledged, and repeatedly pledged, that we would never interfere with Supply or Appropriation Bills.
