It is a pledge which has been honoured, and this Government, and indeed other governments from 1977 onwards, have been allowed to govern. Ever since we have held the balance of power or the balance of reason this has never been an issue as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned. The Opposition did make some noises about the postal allowance issue, but we dismissed its proposal because it may have led to a Constitutional crisis.

The Senate does have an important role in all proposals put forward by government, including taxation proposals and that is its role as a house of review. The Prime Minister is running the line that, since the Senate is not a States' House, it is not a house of review. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Senate is constantly reviewing hundreds of issues which traverse the whole gamut of government.

While it is true that some Opposition senators do abuse the mechanisms of the Senate to attack and defame members of the bureaucracy, from time to time the same can be said of the House of Representatives. For the Prime Minister to imply that the behaviour of some senators reflects glowingly on the House of Representatives is simply a non sequitur.

Thus, under our bicameral system, the Senate is here as a check and balance against executive government. Mr Keating defines a mandate as winning a majority of seats in the House of Representatives but, as I have already said, the Labor Party obtained less than 40 per cent of the vote at the last election yet won more than half the seats. That is not a mandate. In any event, even if it were, that mandate was for a Hawke-led government and not a Keating-led government.

It appears that Labor is conceding that the future Hewson government will be allowed all its money Bills with respect to Supply and Appropriations. The Democrats agree with this proposition, but we do not accept that with respect to all fiscal measures. Indeed, Senator Schacht and others were on radio this week claiming that this principle of not interfering with Budget measures is a longstanding Labor principle. That is absolute rubbish.

During the last period that Labor was in opposition, it successfully combined with the Democrats to defeat Mr Howard's proposed sales tax on the necessities of life. The issue of the right of the Senate to request such an amendment to the Government's tax proposals was debated in the House of Representatives in 1981 and both Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins voted expressly for the Senate's right to improve the legislation. The present exercise is simply an exercise in vote buying at the forthcoming election.

In addition, the Opposition has frequently opposed Budget legislation, mostly taxation matters, during the Hawke-Keating years. Examples are the capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax and superannuation. This so-called principle has been ditched by both sides whenever it suits them, and by both sides quite frequently. It is simply an argument of convenience.

Recently we have seen the superannuation guarantee levy, taxation legislation and privatisation legislation, all of which have been enunciated with respect to the Opposition. Is Labor going to fall in behind the Opposition should it form government and acquiesce with all these measures? Dr Hewson has also said that the Franklin Dam in Tasmania may well be built under a federal Liberal government. Will the Labor Party also support that? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the motion of urgency moved by Senator Hill today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

Noting that a Federal election can be called at any time, the need for the Senate to express its support for the Prime Minister's commitment on 5 November 1992 that in Opposition `the Labor Party would not obstruct the passage of the GST legislation in the Senate', in view of the fact that the introduction of a GST will enable:
(a)personal income tax to be reduced by 30%;
(b)wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the tax on fuel to be abolished;
(c)family allowances to be doubled for lower income families; and
(d)tax cheats to bear a fairer share of the tax burden.

PARA.TAB: Last Thursday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a quite extraordinary statement in the House of Representatives in response to a question asked of him. The goods and services tax that the coalition is proposing after the next election will enable it to fund a 30 per cent cut in income tax. It will double family allowances for lower income families who have been so battered by the policies of this Government over the past 10 years; and it will completely abolish some of those major taxes on the cost of doing business in Australia, that is, those taxes which make us high cost, less productive and less competitive than we otherwise would be, could be and should be. I refer to the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax—which is simply a tax on jobs—and the tax on fuel which is no less than 26c a litre nowadays.Fuel excise has increased from the figure of 6c a litre that applied when this Government came in almost 10 years ago. It is an absolute rip-off and an enormous cost burden on business, private consumers and motorists alike.

The Prime Minister said that even though a tax of the nature we are proposing, the goods and services tax, does all of those things—even though it gets at some of the tax cheats in our economy and even though it is a much fairer system of tax—it was a quite inequitable, vile and vicious tax. He went on to say in the very next breath that although it is such a terrible tax, if the Labor Government is defeated and is therefore in opposition after the next election, the Labor Party Opposition would not obstruct the passage of the goods and services tax legislation in the Senate.

I put it to the Senate that the Prime Minister cannot have it both ways. If the goods and services tax is the dreadful tax he claims it to be, he must oppose it because one cannot describe a tax of the nature of the goods and services tax in the way the Prime Minister has and then say with any credibility that he will not oppose it in the Senate. One must have it one way or another; one cannot have it both ways.

I believe that the fatal mistake the Prime Minister made last week was that he gave the electorate a very confused message indeed. The bottom line of the message though is that Labor wants a GST just as much as the coalition wants a GST. I will give some examples in a moment of why the Prime Minister has always believed that.

Let me say a couple of other things by way of response to the quite misleading, and in several aspects totally wrong, comments Senator Button made earlier in this debate. I preface them by pointing out that Australia is one of the very few countries in the whole world that does not have a tax of the nature of the goods and services tax that the coalition is proposing. We are, I think, the only OECD country that does not have such a tax or one very similar to it and most of the fastest growing nations on earth are now adopting such a tax. Most of the South East Asian giants have such a tax and they are leading the world in economic growth. Most countries in the industrialised world have had such a tax for almost 30 years. Some of them have had it for more than 30 years. Anyone from those countries coming to Australia and listening to the debate that is going on in this country about a GST must find it quite amazing.

Indeed, if the Prime Minister were prepared to be honest about this and stick with the comments he so rightly made in 1985 when he was Treasurer and when he attempted to have such a consumption tax or broadly-based consumption tax implemented only to be rolled by the trade union movement—by Bill Kelty, Simon Crean and then his own Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, pulling the pin on him and cutting off his plans and indeed the Government's plans—we would now have a goods and services tax of the type the coalition is proposing.
In 1985, the then Treasurer said some very sensible things firstly about the need for tax reform in Australia and secondly about the nature of the desirable tax reform. In May 1985 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax reform cannot be regarded as optional for Australia. Despite its difficulties, the cost of not beginning a substantial reform program are now unacceptably high.
Less than a month later he said:
If we don't as a nation adopt this proposal—
that is, the proposal for a broadly based consumption tax or, in today's language, a GST—
then you won't see significant reform in this country in taxation for the balance of this century.

He would have been right had we not had a coalition now with the courage to get up and take the ball from where the then Treasurer Keating dropped it in 1985 because the trade union movement and his own Prime Minister deserted him. Again in June 1985 he said:
If this sort of proposal doesn't get up—
That is the GST proposal—
one has to decide if there's much point in someone like me worrying about the Australian institutional process, and in Australian institutions, very much longer.

So Prime Minister Keating, then Treasurer Keating, was a very articulate and correct exponent of the need for major tax reform in this country in 1985. The basis for his reform proposals was the introduction of a broadly-based goods and services tax, or consumption tax. He spelt out very clearly in an address to the National Press Club on 5 June 1985 what the main advantages of such a tax were. He said:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector.
Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax. That provides a useful `net dividend' for distribution to the rest of the community.

In other words, he was saying quite rightly that a goods and services tax gets at the tax cheats in the community. It does not eliminate—no-one has ever suggested it eliminates—the black economy, but it does get at those tax cheats who are not paying their fair share of tax because they will be taxed when they spend. The Prime Minister also said:
. . . The virtually zero exemption, single rate structure of the tax—
which is of course very similar to ours now—
is a crucial design feature. It will assist both administration and compliance.

That is why Senator Button was so totally wrong today when he claimed that small business was going to be disadvantaged by a huge amount of administrative cost and administrative compliance burden with the goods and services tax that the coalition will be introducing on 1 October 1994 in government. It is a very simple, equitable, efficient tax which is very inexpensive to comply with and to administer. The amount of paperwork involved with it for business people is minuscule compared with the amount of very complex, time-consuming and costly paperwork involved for all those businesses that nowadays are involved in the monstrously complex area of the wholesale sales tax.

PARA.TAB: The wholesale sales tax will be totally abolished by a coalition government because the goods and services tax will enable it to be so abolished. Similarly, this will occur with payroll tax. Payroll tax nowadays rips off something like $6 billion from employers. That is a tax on jobs. At a time when we have one million people officially unemployed in this country and another million who are either underemployed or whose unemployment is hidden from the statistics because they have simply dropped out of the potential work force, because they have lost all hope of ever getting a job, it is just lunacy to continue with a tax in the nature of payroll tax which is a straight tax on jobs. The goods and services tax will enable that tax to be abolished. As I mentioned earlier, the goods and services tax also will enable there to be a total abolition of the tax on petrol in this country—a tax which is now 26c a litre, which is an enormous cost burden not just on business but also on private motorists.

Bearing in mind that the goods and services tax is only one element of our tax reform and that tax reform, whilst being an essential part of the reform, is only one part of the much wider Fightback package, Senator Button asserted that the Fightback package was designed amongst other things to dismantle Medicare. That is an absolute untruth; that is not true. The Fightback package, very importantly, retains Medicare and improves the health system in many very important ways. Senator Button also said that there would be no bracket creep or price effect compensation in the Fightback package. That too is simply an untruth, and my leader Senator Hill reflected on and answered that in his comments. Senator Button said that the GST would not touch the black economy. That also is simply not correct, and Paul Keating himself was a very substantial and articulate exponent on the reasons why it would tackle the black economy.

Family allowances will be doubled under the coalition's policy. People on lower incomes, particularly single income families with young children, have been absolutely slaughtered by the tax system and the economy in the last 10 years under Labor. We will double family allowances to help meet the costs and disadvantages that they have suffered. That, again, can be financed only through the introduction of a goods and services tax. Senator Button said that we were going to do dreadful things to child-care. I do not know whether he has read Fightback!, but in fact we are going to spend an extra $90m on child-care. For all those reasons, this is a very important urgency motion. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate about the goods and services tax. It is clear from the debate so far that there is a very clear distinction between the position of the coalition and that of the Government. The clear distinction to be drawn from the debate is that the Government, the Australian Labor Party, opposes a goods and services tax and does so most implacably; the coalition embraces it and does so enthusiastically. What the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said is this: taking note of the way the Constitution has been written, particularly section 53, if after being fully informed through proper debate the Australian people come to the conclusion that the GST package put forward by the Opposition is the one they want and they vote for it, this Party, if it is in opposition, will not oppose it in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: But that by no means can be taken to mean that the people on this side of the chamber in any way endorse a goods and services tax. It is quite clear from the whole course of debate over many months now, from Question Time, from public statements outside, that this Government, this Party, is absolutely opposed to the goods and services tax. What the Opposition says is, `Well, look, the person who is now Prime Minister of this country supported a goods and service tax in 1985'. But, of course, a lot of history has passed since then.

President Reagan was in power in 1985; Prime Minister Thatcher was in power in 1985. They pursued an economic course that the Opposition proposes to pursue—and I ask honourable senators to look at where their countries are now. In both countries there is dissent and division, and there are disputes within their respective communities. However, in Australia—while I concede that that it has high unemployment and economic hardship and that the country could be better off, and I take all that into account—the fabric of our society, the ability of our people to get on together, is much better than it is in either of those two countries of which I have spoken. It is the division in those countries, the awful riots that we have seen, for example, in Los Angeles, that must be avoided at all costs—and the program that will be able to achieve that is one of conciliation. That is not the sort of program that is put by honourable senators opposite. The Government has shown over the last few years through its policies, particularly its industrial relations policy, that it is capable of keeping the community together.

What sorts of policies would the coalition pursue if it got into government? As has been made clear by those opposite, the goods and services tax does not stand on its own. As you well know, Mr Acting Deputy President, given the great service you have given in the union movement in the past, the goods and services tax as proposed by the Opposition requires awful changes—and I use that word advisedly—to the industrial laws of this country. Why do I say `awful'; what sorts of changes would we get? We would get the sorts of changes that the Victorian Government has introduced in Melbourne which have denied people their vested rights—rights that they had—to claim for compensation. The Victorian Government has retrospectively taken those rights away and has introduced industrial laws that tomorrow will have many, many people in the streets of Melbourne. That sort of thing has not happened for a long, long while. If the cost of this goods and services tax as proposed by the coalition is to get back to the awful periods of industrial chaos that we used to have in the late 1970s and early 1980s before the advent of this Government, then it ought to be avoided at all costs.

I will just go through what this urgency motion says would happen under a goods and services tax. First of all, it says that personal income tax would be reduced by 30 per cent. Nobody would oppose a reduction of tax if it were to be made responsibly. In other words, if we as a community could reduce our taxes without throwing onto the community generally all sorts of pressures that lead to injustice, disputes and dissent, we ought to do it. But we should not reduce taxes, or introduce other taxes, if it would cause those things to happen.

The urgency motion also says that the introduction of a GST will enable wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and the tax on fuel to be abolished. Mr Acting Deputy President, payroll tax is a State tax and, as such, this Parliament does not have the power to abolish such a tax. If the State governments are persuaded to take away payroll tax, they will have to introduce a tax of their own to compensate. The sort of tax that they would have to introduce could well be a tax of the type that has been introduced by the coalition Government in Victoria. That tax is, in effect—and I am sure that Senator Watson does not like this sort of tax—a poll tax. To compensate for a lack of money, the Victorian Government has imposed $100 on each household—

TALK.START.PARA: —You will get pimples on your tongue.

—Senator Knowles says that I am wrong. She should ring her colleagues in Victoria. The reality is that a tax of $100 will be imposed on every householder. It will be imposed no matter how big or small the house is or in what area it is situated.
—The same for a pensioner.

—As Senator Cook says, it is the same for a pensioner as for a millionaire. I have nothing against millionaires, but let us be clear about this: the $100 tax that is going to be introduced in Victoria does not take account of people's ability to pay.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying, Senator Knowles, is this: if wholesale taxes, payroll taxes and taxes on fuel are abolished, State governments will have to look for other avenues of revenue. On the evidence, a tax of $100 will have to be paid in Victoria by everybody, irrespective of a person's ability to pay, irrespective of the size of the house and irrespective of the size of the land. That is a matter of concern.

The people of Australia have to ask themselves, `Yes, some taxes are being reduced and some taxes are being abolished but what is being put in their place?'. Is it fair to abolish the tax on fuel and, as has been said again and again—it has not been denied—put a tax on essentials such as bread, butter and jam? I say that the tax on bread, butter and jam—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are already there.
—Not on the bread, Senator Watson.
—Yes.

—Honourable senators opposite are saying that there is a tax on bread that is sold in shops. I just simply say that that is not so. This is why we have to be a bit careful. We are talking now about the goods and services tax and the abolition of the wholesale tax. We are talking about a tax on a commodity. The Opposition is saying that at this point of time there is a goods and services-type tax, or a wholesale tax, on bread, milk and butter. I simply say that there is not.

PARA.TAB: The urgency motion also states that the introduction of a GST will enable family allowances to be doubled for lower income families. Who could dispute that it was not a good thing to double family allowances? Of course, they will have to be doubled because people will have to be compensated. I say—and honourable senators opposite disagree with me on this—that bread, milk and butter will be made more expensive because of the goods and services tax. The Opposition, as I understand its argument, says that they will not be made more expensive. It is extraordinary to say that. What is the point of applying a goods and services tax if, as is inferred by honourable senators opposite, such a tax is already in place? I think my proposition about taxes on all of these basic commodities is probably correct and Opposition senators are wrong. That is why a coalition government would have to increase allowances for lower income families. Those families would have to pay more.

Would it not be better to allow people to keep their money so that they can buy the essentials of life at a cheaper price? Would it not be better to allow them to have control over their own destinies rather than, as a government, taking money from them and then giving it back to them? That is paternalism at its worst and this is another problem that we find with the goods and services tax.

To lower costs and to make this scheme work the people opposite will have to suppress wages. To do that they will have to take away the right to strike. They will have to take away the means by which workers can engage in industrial action. The fault and the vice of such an action is well illustrated in a statement by Archbishop Little—a man who has not entered the political arena on this or any other occasion. This morning's Age had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne, Sir Frank Little, has waded into the political debate—
I think that is over stretching it because he is not a man who does that—
with a strong defence of the role of unions and the right of workers to take industrial action.

That has been said in the light of events that are going on in Australia at the moment. The real problem with the program that has been put forward by those opposite, the real problem with the goods and services tax, is that it strikes at the very foundation of what society should be all about. In society there certainly should be differences between people. People who go into different endeavours and work hard should be rewarded for what they do. But we should not allow society to become so uneven that terrible injustices and degradation of certain sections occur. No doubt it was with that in the back of his mind that Archbishop Little said that people who are wrongly used ought to have the ability to protest and, if needs be, to protest in a collective way. We can see by the way in which laws have been undeniably rushed into the legislature in Victoria that workers are going to be strongly denied the ability to do this.

PARA.TAB: Let me give an illustration of what would happen. A person in Victoria whose leg is cut off beneath the knee will get workers compensation for up to two years but no more compensation than that. One will not be able to sue for damages, no matter how negligent one's employer has been at work. If a worker sustains a back injury at work, he will be required to have an operation within two years and two weeks of the accident occurring. Even though his injury may be caused through his employer's negligence at work, he will have to pay for the operation and for the six months that he is off work.

The program that has been put to us by the Opposition can be made to work by bearing down upon those least able to sustain a loss. It is a question of where the cost will be put, and it will be put on the most vulnerable part of this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the likeable and knowledgable Senator Barney Cooney, who we all know is not only a deeply religious man but also a man not given to superstition. Indeed, he is a most enlightened senator. Might I remind him that when he was making some of his dire predictions this afternoon, some of the lights surprisingly went off in the Senate chamber. Interestingly enough, some of them are now starting to come on. I leave it to the Senate to interpret the significance of that.

PARA.TAB: When Prime Minister Keating announced to a shocked House of Representatives that an ALP in opposition would not oppose the passing of the GST in the Senate, he was merely repositioning the ALP in line with the ALP manifesto of 1975. Is that right, Senator Cooney? It is 100 per cent right. While some Labor senators were outraged and went so far as to indicate that it may not be Mr Keating's decision in 1993, others said it was merely an acknowledgment of Keating's 1985 support for a GST.

If this rage of Gough Whitlam and the ALP is to have any continuing substance, a Liberal-National Party coalition government in 1993-94 would not be denied Supply and would not be denied a major source of revenue from a GST—the GST proposed in the Fightback package—that would form such a major part of its election platform and would be central to the new government's mandate from the Australian people.

Governments are formed by majorities in the House of Representatives, and revenue raising measures which are appropriately announced prior to an election or, indeed, within the context of an annual Budget should be acknowledged by the Senate. There is no doubt about that. We honour it on our side, and we know that the Labor Party will honour it too. So the question is: why has the Keating Government hung on to such an anachronistic tax, such as the wholesale sales tax, and a host of others, which the Liberal-National Party coalition will abolish?

When introduced in the 1930s, wholesale trading was prevalent in most industries, but nowadays wholesale trading is disappearing. I put it to the Senate that this wholesale sales tax regime, particularly with its broadening base and escalating rates under this Government, is encouraging the demise of the wholesale traders. That is a tragedy. This tax is driving people out of business.

Why is it such a problem? The rates today are very much higher than they were in the 1930s. The base is very much wider, and widening every day—$3.5 billion raised when Labor came into government, but almost $10 billion revenue raised today. It is a hidden tax, a cascading tax and a tax that, in most cases, has to be paid before the debt is collected.

Let me give the Senate an example of how this iniquitous tax is driving a lot of wholesale traders out of business. Let us say, for example, that Senator Cooney and Senator Loosley are electricians. Senator Cooney goes to K-Mart to buy his fittings and cables to do a job. Senator Loosley goes to a wholesale merchant. The price that Senator Cooney has to pay for his goods includes the wholesale sales tax, which is based not only on the wholesale price but on his margin. Senator Cooney goes along to K-Mart, and K-Mart has paid its tax because it buys directly from the manufacturer at a very much lower quantum.

Technically, Coles-K-Mart cannot distinguish the people who go through the checkout aisles, whether Senator Cooney is an electrician or I am a final consumer. We all know that sales tax is paid on the final price before the retail price. So this very process arithmetically is driving small wholesalers out of business. No wonder they are suffering. No wonder all those associated with sales tax have problems.
Let us see how this will impact on another industry. Mr Ken Traill, who is the group tax counsel for Coca-Cola, states in the New Accountant:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that Fightback! is "absolutely" more positive business than Keating's "One Nation" and Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT) proposals to start on April 1, 1994.
He said of Mr Keating's One Nation:
The proposed FBT changes spell an increase in cost . . . Our FBT liability will nearly double.
But the important thing Traill states about wholesale sales tax is:
There are four issues associated with the wholesale sales tax—1) the deferral techniques; 2) whether an item is taxable or exempt; 3) the rate of tax; and 4) basic compliance cost.

PARA.TAB: "Under GST, there's only the basic compliance cost to collect tax at a single rate.
He acknowledges—

SPEECH.PARA: for some firms—
that the changeover from one tax system to another can be costly.

PARA.TAB: "But that is a once-off cost," he says. "Once your computer systems are set up to handle it, it becomes a piece of cake, it's like riding a bike.
With a simpler tax, a large part of the administration cost and independent consultant fees paid to ensure compliance with WST—

SPEECH.PARA: wholesale sales tax—
would also disappear . . .
He should know because they pay tax on fast foods and beverages at the 20 per cent rate. The New Accountant report, to which I refer, states:

PARA.TAB: Traill plays down the fear that GST would generally raise retail prices. The 20 per cent WST on beverages and snack foods equates to 15 per cent of the retail price . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is something that the Labor Party will not appreciate. Then there is also the GST on the packaging. Traill goes on to say that under Fightback:
Fuel prices will come down, excise and levies will fall, payroll tax will be abolished . . .

We remember that almost two-thirds of people in New Zealand were against a GST before it was introduced. Within a month of introduction that percentage had turned around and two-thirds were in favour of it.

PARA.TAB: This Labor Party talks about the need for tax simplification. We will introduce tax simplification on both direct and indirect taxation. Mr McKenna, the Chief Executive Officer of the Certified Practising Accountants in Australia, states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . 88 per cent of CPAs spend valuable time satisfying compliance demands . . . nearly a quarter of CPAs spend more than half their time on compliance work.
The coalition will simplify not only wholesale sales tax by replacing it with a GST but also income tax.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that the overriding purpose of the Fightback program of reform is to provide a generational change in policies and attitudes. Our aim is to give individual Australians greater control over their own lives by creating more incentives and opportunities for all Australians to work harder and to be rewarded for it, and thus to be able to save and invest. But these objectives can only be achieved if a national government, such as a Liberal-National Party government, sees its proper role as providing a framework of policy and equal laws within which individuals, families and businesses are allowed to fulfil their potential and to plan with certainty and confidence. We believe that such a program is the essential feature of the Fightback proposal.

We will abolish the $9.4 billion wholesale sales tax and the $5.9 billion payroll tax. Fancy in these recessionary times having a tax on employment! And that is what payroll tax is. We will abolish the $6.6 billion excise on petroleum products—about 55 per cent of which falls on business. Prices for private fuel will drop by 19c a litre. The coalition will abolish the $3.3 billion of customs duties; we will abolish the training guarantee levy; we will limit the superannuation guarantee charge; and we will reduce the tax on exports by $1.7 billion.

What will be the result of all these changes to the economy? Costs in the agricultural sector will fall by $1 billion; in the transport economy by $2 billion; in the finance industry by $860m; in the manufacturing industry by $5.4 billion. There will be more jobs because the GST is not a cascading tax. Costs in the electricity industry will fall by $526m, and in the mining industry costs will fall by $677m.

The essential feature of the Fightback proposal is the family, because it is the essential building block of society. It provides the most effective means for the care and development of children. It is a source of security, stability and values, both personal and social.

Let us look at some of the personal income tax proposals that will be associated with the Fightback package. Income tax savings of 30 per cent will return $13 billion to taxpayers. We will raise the tax-free threshold from $5,400 to $7,000.

What will this mean? It will mean that 320,000 Australians will then pay no tax at all. It cuts the marginal tax rates and puts more money back into taxpayers' pockets. The coalition's tax policy will enable many Australians to double their income and still pay only 30c in the dollar. There will be an income tax saving of $1,585 for those on an income of $30,000. All those whose income falls in the range of $5,401 to $20,700 who currently pay tax at the rate of 20 per cent will continue to pay that rate of tax under the Keating Government, but under the coalition it will drop significantly to 16.2 per cent for the income range of $7,001 to $20,700.

I remind the Senate that excluded from the goods and services tax are a number of important family expenses: the family home, education, school fees, health expenses including visits to the doctor, prescriptions, medical aids, wheelchairs, hearing aids, dentures, spectacles, hospital and nursing home services, local government rates, insurance, rent, financial services and transactions. Also exempt under the coalition's proposal are financial services, gambling and lotteries, land, residential and commercial rates, building and construction services. A number of things are zero rated: health, education, government provisions, charities and religious institutions, exports, and taxable activities sold as going concerns.

The important thing is that the abolition of the petrol excise, as I mentioned earlier, will reduce the price of petrol by 19c a litre, a saving of approximately $11.40 every time senators and all others fill up their cars. Australia is a big continent. Long distance travel is associated with distance and size. We hear of the tyranny of distance. A lot of the costs that go into everyday consumable items bear a significant petrol cost. At the moment, these items bear a very significant tax component from the sales tax on trailer rigs, tyres and so on. We will scrap this ramshackle sales tax that adds up to 30 per cent to the price of hundreds of everyday items. This tax is hidden; it is not seen. No wonder Senator Cooney made such an oversight. He forgot it was hidden. If Senator Cooney cannot see that, the others are also mistaken.

We will introduce a new tax-free savings scheme so the taxpayers will pay no tax on interest income, on new savings up to a limit of $2,000 a year for couples. We will abolish anti-business taxes—not just payroll tax, but also the training guarantee levy and so on. The coalition's policies under Fightback will enable Australian industry to recover from the recession. Family allowances will be doubled for families with a combined income below $30,000. What does this translate into? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of the debate on this urgency motion, Senator Hill said that this debate would enable Labor senators to come to the defence of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I am delighted to do so in these concluding remarks. It is instructive to analyse with some precision the terms of an urgency motion, because it is always of some fascination to try to determine the motivation and the driving forces behind the minds of the people who put these propositions together. It is therefore unusually instructive to look at the terminology that begins this urgency motion this afternoon. The motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the following is a matter of urgency:
Noting that a Federal election can be called at any time . . .

The fact that the Federal Opposition has been predicting, throughout 1992, that a general election will be called at any time says far more about the instability existing within its ranks than any observation about the current state of electoral play in Australia might suggest. The fact that an urgency motion would begin with those words underlines both the instability and the lack of confidence within the coalition as it approaches a general election.

PARA.TAB: It is a pleasure to follow Senator Watson in this debate. As with Senator Cooney, he is a likeable person; he is knowledgeable on matters of tax. But it was significant that he skated over the issue of constitutional impropriety in 1975, of the malice with which the coalition dealt with the Constitution in 1975, of the havoc wreaked upon the system of Australian Government in 1975. Senator Watson in no way conceded that the episode of 11 November 1975, the incidents that led up to it, and the course of action which followed 11 November 1975 still exist as a jagged scar across the cheek of Australian democracy. There is no question about that. I will come to that a little later.

On the matter of the coalition's lack of confidence and uncertainty concerning a general election—and Senator Bolkus as the Minister responsible would know this better than I—if one looks at the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 September this year, in incident after incident, Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, is quoted as predicting elections almost from the beginning of the parliamentary term. In March, for example, Dr Hewson is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I think Mr Keating will go as soon as he can, and we've put ourselves on red alert from July 1.
Within a matter of weeks, the quote changes. Dr Hewson, talking this time to Paul Lyneham on the ABC, said:
. . . a couple of State elections got in the way—
That was explaining why his earlier prediction did not come about—
and so their first clear run—
he was referring to the Government—
. . . is late November, early December. I still think that is a realistic possibility.
In July, Dr Hewson said:
He'll probably go in September or October . . .
Now we come to the end of the parliamentary year and coalition senators are approaching Government senators about when the Prime Minister will be going out to Yarralumla. What is the concern?

TALK.START.PARA: —He'll get it right the last time.

—Absolutely. As Senator Bolkus says, on the final occasion, he will get it right. The turn of mind that that reveals is related to the coalition's failures in 1987 and 1990 where the election on both occasions should have been won by the Liberal and National parties, but on both occasions opportunity was squandered. That is now recognised by those opposite.

PARA.TAB: What makes it particularly germane in this debate is that, because of the impact of the goods and services tax, those opposite will squander the opportunity again. It is impossible to walk away from it now. Why has it become impossible? Because the Prime Minister made it crystal clear in the House of Representatives, just last week, in answer to a question, that in the unlikely and unpalatable event that a coalition forms government after the next poll, the Labor Party would not obstruct the imposition of a goods and services tax. To paraphrase the very generous remarks made by US President George Bush the other day, the majesty of the democratic process can be respected. The people on this side of the chamber have an infinitely better track record, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, than those opposite on matters of constitutional propriety and respect for the democratic process and respect and acknowledgment for the parliamentary system.

We are now in a circumstance whereby the coalition actually goes into electoral free fall. There is no doubt at all, as the Prime Minister made clear in the House of Representatives just a few days ago, that certain coalition strategists were, with a nod and a wink, saying, `Well, it is safe to vote for Liberal and National parties, safe to vote for the coalition in general election because there is no real chance of a GST being passed by the Senate'.

Alternatively, it could be suggested that the Labor Party would allow itself to be placed in a circumstance whereby a double dissolution could be called for at the whim of a conservative prime minister. Neither of those eventualities will come about. We have taken the deliberate step of making it absolutely clear that a GST, as part of an electoral mandate, will come about if a coalition government were to be elected. I think that event is unlikely, but if it comes about, then the coalition goes into free fall.
Why the division on the GST? Why the division in electoral opinion? Why the division between the parties now? Why the division amongst the commentators on the impact of the GST?

It is true that a variant of a goods and services tax was supported by the then Treasurer and sections of the Labor movement in 1985. It was a very different proposition from the one that we have now. Times have moved on; they have moved on in a dramatic sense electorally; they have moved on in terms of management of the economy; and they have moved on in terms of political perceptions.

What happened subsequent to the tax summit in 1985 when the goods and services tax was first canvassed? Five major steps within the tax system were taken by the Labor Government to make the system better, fairer and more equitable. Five deliberate steps were taken. They were taken on a fringe benefits tax; by closing overseas tax havens, which made it much harder for companies and wealthy individuals either to avoid or evade tax; by making certain that an enhanced tax file number tightened income tax and made certain of collections from PAYE sources and went about attacking the black economy—the cash economy; by having a prescribed payments system; and, of course, by moving on the issue of capital gains tax which proceeded systematically to tax windfall profits. That is one explanation.

The second explanation of equal significance is that if one looks at the coalition's proposal for a GST, which lies at the core of the Fightback package, one will see that it is an absolute certainty that it will increase prices across the board on a range of goods and services; it will make absolutely certain that people on the lower end of the socio-economic scale pay comparatively more than those on the top end of the scale; and it will increase inflation. It will increase inflation at a time when the battle against inordinate increases in the cost of living has largely been won; when Australia has the best record on inflation in the OECD.
There is the answer in terms of why the division now? The Government is implacably opposed to a GST; the Opposition has embraced it. Let the general election be fought on those parameters.

Internationally, let us look at movements in opinions. Let us look at movements in terms of comparable Western democracies. In the United States, the Bush Administration has been rejected by the American people, overwhelmingly in the electoral college, convincingly in terms of popular vote. Governor Clinton—now President-elect Clinton—and his new Administration are coming to office on the basis of commitments to do more; to intervene to a greater extent than was apparent under 12 years of his Republican predecessors; to intervene more in terms of industrial policy; to intervene more in terms of economic management; to do more in terms of assisting those on the lower end of the socio-economic scale.

In the United Kingdom, in the wake of the fiasco of British Coal's decision to close more than 30 pits, the Government of Prime Minister Major is in very serious trouble. The inheritor of the Thatcherite tradition, which is embraced so enthusiastically by those opposite, is in deep electoral trouble and very serious parliamentary trouble.

The simple point to make is that internationally the trend has moved against those who developed the Fightback proposals in 1990, announced them in 1991 and are now manacled to them as we go to a 1993 general election. International opinion has moved against the coalition decisively and demonstrably, and that will be a useful point to be made by the ALP at the time of the general election.

We have the circumstance in which the coalition, in political terms and in terms of a policy framework, has gone into free fall. There is no restraint. The GST has actually moved to the very centre ground of the electoral debate as we move into the new year. That is not an argument which the coalition can win. That is not an argument which the coalition can sustain. That is why there are so many people opposite who are edgy on this issue. That is why, in terms of the public platform and the political debate, it is much easier for those in the Government to find weaknesses, flaws and failures in Fightback than it is possible for those opposite, as they now realise, to argue any perceived strengths.

As for what ought to happen in this chamber, if the coalition had taken the view that Senator Watson expressed quite reasonably towards the end of his remarks about a government being legitimised by majority status in the House of Representatives, and money Bills not being tampered with, frustrated or defeated in the Senate, then, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you are aware, and as everyone in this chamber is aware, the Whitlam Labor Government would have gone on to May 1977 and faced a general election at the time that was appropriate, rather than being forced to the polls for a second time in some 18 months.

We took that view in 1974 and in 1975, and we take it again now. The Senate is not a body that was designed by the constitutional forebears to frustrate, delay, harass or destroy governments made in the lower House. It is a pity that on money Bills, in particular, that view was not taken by those opposite in 1974 or in 1975. To quote the Prime Minister in the remarks he made on the 7.30 Report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we want the battle for the GST to be fought out in the House of Representatives. We are opposed to a GST, Dr Hewson is in favour of one.
Nothing could be clearer; it is crystal-clear in terms of the battle lines being drawn. I quote the Prime Minister again from the same program. He said:

I don't believe that it is legitimate for an Opposition and in the Senate to deny the principle element of what is a clearly articulated mandate. I notice George Bush yesterday talked about the `majesty of democracy' in his very eloquent speech where he accepted defeat and said he would cooperate in handing over the mantle to President-elect Clinton. That sort of respect for the democratic process is something my party has always had. We are not the constitutional wreckers of this federation—that we have left to the Liberal Party. They are the people who hold up supply, have Governor Generals appoint Opposition Leaders as Prime Ministers, all that sort of nonsense and risk is taken by them.
That is an eloquent summation of the constitutional history of this country. The battle lines are drawn. We welcome the battle.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly in this debate to record my opposition to the matter of urgency, whether or not it is amended by the Government's amendment. In the end, there is no validity at all, in all equity and justice, for any form of goods and services tax as proposed by the Opposition. Should the coalition win government—and I find that an extraordinary concession by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in any case, in the present situation—it is important that the public is assured that such an iniquitous tax will not pass this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: There is no way at all that it would be a responsible position for this chamber to endorse what I consider to have been irresponsible remarks by a prime minister. The Prime Minister is quite clearly playing politics as, I suppose, is his right and certainly is his wont, particularly as we come towards a Federal election, however near or far that might be in the future. Nevertheless, he is playing politics with issues of gross injustice and inequity, as are represented by the goods and services tax.
I simply take this very brief opportunity to place on record my opposition to this motion in the event that it is, or is not, amended in the debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—From listening to Labor senators today, it is clear that the major parties—the alternative governments—in this country are poles apart. There is no doubt about that at all. Labor is standing on its record. It is going to the people in this forthcoming election with the economic model that it has had for the last 10 years and which has failed. It is a model which has resulted in one million Australians being out of work and the disastrous situation in which we find this country. It is appalling for a country with so much potential, so much in the way of natural resources and such great opportunity to be brought to its knees by an incompetent government and an incompetent economic management.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, the Government offers nothing new and no reform of its program. That is what it is taking to the Australian people. We have put down an alternative. It is an alternative that can put incentive back into the economy and give businesses the chance to thrive, grow and employ again. We will do it by taking $6 billion off the total tax bill and by restructuring within the taxation system. That restructuring, like all other industrialised countries in the world, includes a goods and services tax or a form of consumption tax in order to get taxes off production. This Government is not prepared to face up to that necessity as other industrialised countries have done. The result is that it makes our businesses less competitive and therefore they are unable to grow and employ in the way we want.

This motion is in such a form that it endorses the benefits of the package. It states at least some of the benefits that would come out of that tax restructuring, including the personal income tax cuts of 30 per cent, getting rid of the wholesale sales tax, the payroll tax—a tax on jobs—and the fuel tax, which is also a tax on jobs. We mentioned that we will double family allowances for those who are less well off in this community and that tax cheats will at least have to pay some tax.

We have set out the benefits of the program—the restructuring of the taxation system—and we have said to the Labor Party, `Come in and in these terms endorse the Prime Minister's statement that it will support our reform package from opposition'. This Government is now about to be put to the test. Will it vote in support of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), in support of this motion that we have moved today and in support of the reforms and the benefits of the reforms, or will it wimp it, try to amend the motion, as apparently Senator Button wants, and then vote with the Australian Democrats again? It will further confuse the picture and end up in a muddle again.

What Senator Button really said is that the Government will endorse the Prime Minister on principle but it will not endorse him on the package. It cannot have it both ways. If it is going to vote for the Fightback package in this chamber, as the Prime Minister was saying, then it will vote for the benefits of the Fightback package—that is, such things as income tax being reduced by 30 per cent. Let us see what the Government does today. Let us see whether it has the courage to stand up to the Prime Minister with all the ramifications of what he has said. (Time expired)
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Button's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to this motion, I wish to congratulate the Australian Dairy Corporation on its annual report and the work that it does to improve the profitable structure market of Australian dairy produce.

PARA.TAB: There have been some interesting developments in the dairy industry in the past 12 months, the period covered by this report. As the Chairman notes in his foreword, the results for the year were better than expected, reflecting improved trading conditions. He notes:

SPEECH.PARA: The industry's performance is closely linked to the international market and in the latter half of 1991/1992 international prices rose significantly, which has caused a renewal of confidence in future prospects, although with a degree of uncertainty engendered by the US Presidential elections, the delayed resolution of the Uruguay Round, and political uncertainties in Eastern Europe.
He also notes:

The recently announced market support arrangements which followed the Industry Commission report and extensive government/industry consultations, have played an important part in contributing to industry confidence.

The culmination of those developments in the industry was the dairy produce amendment and levy Bills which we debated in this chamber in June this year. That legislation represented tremendous change for the dairy industry. This industry has been determined to restructure, to become more efficient and be able to compete on world markets. This has been very noticeable, because at one stage the dairy industry was really in the doldrums. All the people in the dairy industry wanted to get out of it and get into beef cattle. It is now nearly a complete turnaround, so much so that the dairy industry is one of the really good industries for rural people.

PARA.TAB: The industry has had no choice but to become more efficient because, if it had not rationalised and restructured, it would not have been able to compete in the way it was required to. In those Bills, the Government basically followed the recommendations of the Industry Commission report, with a number of exceptions.

One of the main arguments in that report was that Australian consumers would get cheaper milk if controls in the Australian dairy industry were removed. It is said that `further reductions in assistance must take place if the dairy industry is to maximise its contribution to national welfare', adding that the Australian industry had to prepare for increased competition from New Zealand dairy products.

In addition, the report recommended that assistance to the industry should be phased out in the next two to 10 years and that the Commonwealth should phase down maximum market support payments from 20 per cent of average export prices to 5 per cent by 1996. Instead, the Government recommended a 12 month delay or holding at the present 20 per cent level, down to 10 per cent by the year 2000.

Indeed, if the Government had accepted the Industry Commission's report in its totality, I ask honourable senators whether they honestly believe that the whole community would have benefited if, in the long run, its proposed changes resulted in decreased production, a significant reduction in jobs and the industry unable to compete on world markets.

So often now the Industry Commission seems to believe that it is acceptable for Australia to become a dumping ground. It is asking Australian farmers and manufacturers to accept, as right and proper, prices which are based on the world market's dumped prices. We have seen this asked of producers in other rural industries. These prices are the result of political decisions in Brussels and Washington. They do not reflect retail prices in the exporting countries where consumers are paying more for their produce than Australia.

The Australian dairy industry is alive with innovation, technical progress and a driving will to compete. Our dairy foods are as good as, and in many cases better than, any in the world. Dairy food exports earn more than $700m each year. The industry's major investments in research, technology and market development will see these export earnings grow. Dairy farmer productivity is increasing by 5 per cent per year, as it has for the past decade. The industry's willingness to adapt to change means that it will benefit from even minor reforms in the international trading environment.

Australians already buy premier quality dairy foods at prices as low as anywhere in the world. Australian dairy farmers produce milk at a lower cost than those in Europe, the USA, Canada or Japan, thanks to our pasture-based farming. In fact, few countries can produce quality dairy products as cheaply as Australia.

It is good to know that more than 100,000 Australians have jobs thanks to the dairy industry. The industry provides about 20 per cent of employment in a number of important dairying regions. This is particularly important in light of the difficult times that rural Australia is now experiencing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to both the Australian Dairy Corporation annual report and the Dairy Research and Development Corporation annual report. In so doing, I compliment Senator Bjelke-Petersen on her remarks, because I am not left with very much to say—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Senator Archer, if you wish to address both reports at one time, you need to do so by leave. You might like to consider whether you want to address one report and then take your chances at getting a further five minutes to speak on the other. I am just not sure which option you are after.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that I did not make myself clear. As I said, I wish to speak to both and I wish to take note of both. I thought I intimated that in the first place. I seek leave so to do.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to fully appreciate where the dairy industry now is, it is necessary to look back to 1975-76 when I first became politically involved with the industry. In those days, the farmers of our area were being paid something like 40c a pound for butterfat. The herds were small, the production was poor and there was little concerted research. In my area there was a multiplicity of small processors who were quite weak in respect of technology. The States generally, from one to the other, were in total disarray.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the work that has been done, the current situation is totally different. I am very pleased to see the position that Ken Baxter now holds and the work that he has done. In those early days, we dealt with Ken Baxter in the Parliament when he was working for the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Ken Wriedt. Of all the jobs that he has been involved in since then, I am very pleased to see him back in the dairy industry where he did well in those very difficult days.

There is now very good research. There have been many factory amalgamations and herd build-ups. There has been much improvement in the machinery, buildings and plant used and in artificial breeding. Production per cow is up about 50 per cent on what it was in those days. The quality is better than we ever imagined was possible, and it is uniform.

The industry has changed so much in terms of what it now produces. In those days it was basically a butter industry. It then went through the phase of being a cheddar cheese industry. The main parts of the industry are now built around the fancy cheeses and the various powders—whole milk, skim milk and whey. The organisation has done very well.

I have to give great commendations to the work of Pat Rowley and John Frearson. Pat came into the operations at a time when the major dairying States were having difficulty getting agreement. After years of work, Pat has been able to get the industry into a very solid position. With the more recent approach of Ken Baxter, I am very hopeful that the industry can do well in the years ahead.

In particular, Tasmania has done very well with its dairy farmers. The factories concerned have made products that have put Tasmanian dairy industries on the map. United Milk Tasmania Ltd, the Lactos company and the King Island company are all now very famous for their excellent products.

The dairy farmers have also been able to make dairying highly competitive as far as land use is concerned. In a State where there is not a lot of first-class land and where that land is now in high competition with vegetable growers, the dairy farmers are now able to compete and are doing very well. I congratulate the farmers and the industry processors on the results that they have had in shows around Australia and overseas. I look forward to a continually improving dairy industry in the years ahead.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the order of the Senate of 5 November 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make one brief remark. This report relates to the release of a report on Medicare fraud to the Committee. In accordance with Senator Tate's motion earlier today, that report has now been provided to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments about this. I first asked Senator Tate, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, about this report over three weeks ago. I subsequently made it public last week by seeking to have it tabled in the Senate. When he expressed concern that there might be information contained within that report that could be used by those who are trying to defraud Medicare, I changed the notice of motion and sought to have it referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

PARA.TAB: That was meant to be done by the Minister by last Thursday evening. The Minister sought to not comply with the request of the Senate, which I believe is a very serious matter. The motion was passed formally by the Senate. In fact, there was not even any debate on whether this matter should go through. Yet, come 11.30 last Thursday evening, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) decided that the Senate was not trustworthy and could not be relied upon to keep the matter confidential.

I find that offensive to the Senate, particularly given the fact that we had been given a blast by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) only the day before, on previous occasions and on the same day again. This Government is showing absolute and utter contempt for the Senate. The mere fact is that we had courteously and respectfully requested this document to be released on a confidential basis so that any material of a sensitive nature would not be put on the public record, and possibly jeopardise prosecutions or anything of that nature. Yet the Minister, Mr Howe, said, `Get lost'.

I am a bit concerned because it now seems to be becoming the trend of this Government to tell the Senate to `get lost'. Fortunately, sanity has now prevailed and Senator Tate has been able to convince Mr Howe—who incidentally is not only Minister for Health, but also the Deputy Prime Minister and a person who should have a bit more respect for the Parliament and the Senate—that the whole idea of getting this report on Medicare fraud was designed to inform us as to what the Department was doing and, if there is anything of a confidential nature, that would be respected and certainly not released.

There has been much work done, particularly by Minister Tate's office, by the coalition benches and by Senator Lees on behalf of the Democrats on this occasion, to make sure that the Senate is informed exactly what the Department is doing about Medicare fraud. I understand from the information I have been given—and obviously I have not yet seen a report—that this report involves something like $60m worth of Medicare fraud. That is quite a substantial amount.

It also involves what the Government has or has not done when it comes to trying to detect fraud in various areas. One of the matters that I am concerned about is that there is an indication that the number of investigators into Medicare fraud has been dramatically reduced. If on the one hand we are talking about a $60m fraud and yet on the other we are reducing the number of investigators, then what is this Government doing?

Obviously it is up to the Senate to decide what is going on, because clearly the House of Representatives will not do anything. I have known of the existence of this report for six to eight weeks, and yet Mr Howe has continued as of today to say, `We have to rush it together, rush it together, rush it together'. That is simply not on.

The matter I really want to highlight is the contempt in which this Government appears to hold the Senate. The Deputy Prime Minister of this country, following fast on the heels of the Prime Minister of this country, is insulting the Senate to that degree. Madam Acting Deputy President, you are a member of a committee which has had particularly confidential information provided to it from the National Crime Authority. It is a shame that members of the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister of this country do not appreciate the fact that there should be proper scrutiny of government, of departments and of where the taxpayers' dollar is spent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the Committee: Report No. 10—Facilities for an increased Army presence in the North; Report No. 11—Redevelopment of Larrakeyah Barracks, Darwin, Northern Territory; and Report No. 12—Defence Logistics redevelopment project—Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The first report I have just tabled relates to facilities for an increased Army presence in the north, stage 1. The proposal relates to the Defence Force structure review announced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) on 30 May 1991. One of the findings of the review determined that a regular Army brigade be permanently based in Darwin by the end of the decade. This will be achieved by the staged relocation of southern based units to Darwin. Approximately 2,200 service personnel will be relocated under stages 1 and 2 which will take place between 1994 and 2001.

PARA.TAB: This report relates to the need to provide suitable working, training and accommodation facilities for personnel relocating under stage 1. The proposal consists of the construction of new facilities on the Defence property near Palmerston, 20 kilometres east of Darwin; the construction of new facilities and refurbishment of existing facilities at RAAF base Darwin for an aviation squadron; acquisition and development of an additional close training area; and acquisition of a commercial property for logistics functions.

As regards the new facilities on the Defence property near Palmerston, it is not a Club Med, but the construction, design and architecture of that facility is second to none. Having seen it, I believe it is a very wise and efficient use of resources and it is certainly a very visually pleasing and functional structure.

Related to this proposal is the provision of an additional 350 married quarters by the Defence Housing Authority, for which furniture is to be provided out of this proposal. The estimated total cost of the proposed scope of works in outturn price is $199.74m. This equates to $173.95m at February 1992 prices. It is proposed that the stage 1 works will be contracted in a number of separate contract packages of varied sizes to optimise local industry involvement. Subject to all necessary approvals, current plans envisage the commencement of construction by the end of 1997.

The second report relates to the redevelopment of Larrakeyah Barracks in Darwin. Although there has been a gradual increase in Army strength in the north since the 1970s, there has been little development of facilities within the barracks. There is a shortage of suitable working accommodation and existing facilities are in poor condition. Although maintenance has been carried out, there has never been an upgrade of the type proposed in this referral.

The objectives of the proposed redevelopment are to provide suitable working accommodation for units located within Larrakeyah Barracks; provide suitable living-in accommodation for personnel posted to units located within Larrakeyah Barracks; provide suitable accommodation for transit and headquarters NORCOM augmentation personnel; replace the large number of temporary facilities within the barracks with permanent facilities; and incorporate elements of the Darwin Naval base redevelopment stage 2.

Two Aboriginal sacred sites exist within the site, namely, the Emery Point precinct and a sacred tree adjacent to the guardhouse. The Committee was advised by the Department of Defence that discussions have taken place with guardians of the site. As a result of these discussions, power lines will remain above ground and the Committee is pleased to note that the Aboriginal guardians have been issued with passes which allow them access to the area at any time.

The heritage value of building 27 on the site continues to be a matter of discussion between the Department of Defence and the heritage authorities. Although the Committee doubts the heritage value of this building, it acknowledges the Department of Defence's policy of liaising with environmental bodies until differences are resolved.

The estimate of total project cost in outturn price is $28.629m. This equates to $26.4m at January 1992 prices. It is proposed the works will be contracted with a number of separate contract packages. Subject to the necessary approvals, it is proposed that construction will commence in late 1992 and will be completed by mid-1995.

The Committee's twelfth report concerns provision of new and refurbished warehouse facilities for the Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre (DNSDC), primarily at Moorebank, New South Wales, and a number of other centres. The project examined by the Committee is a significant part of the Defence logistics redevelopment project which will implement a centralised strategy of wholesale storage and distribution for the Australian Defence Force.

The Committee has recommended that the project, which is estimated to cost $100m, should proceed. The Committee believes that the concept of a Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre would result in manpower savings and savings in recurrent expenditure, and would avoid duplication and double handling of stores items.

At the Committee's public hearing into the proposal, the Zetland unions put forward an alternative proposal which would involve retaining the naval stores at Zetland as part of the centre. After careful consideration of this proposal from the unions, the Committee has concluded that the location of the centre at Moorebank offers the advantages of reduced costs and recurrent expenditure, increased efficiency, capacity for expansion and improved security over the Zetland alternative.
I seek leave to incorporate the remaining paragraphs of my speech concerning these reports in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Nevertheless, because the completed project will involve manpower savings which will be spread over a number of years, the Committee has recommended that there should be continuing consultation between Defence and the workforces at all establishments at which redundancies are programmed to occur to ensure that the personnel involved are assisted in finding alternative employment. A formal mechanism to achieve this objective should be established.

The Committee's inquiry also focused on fire detection and prevention measures to be provided at the Centre. The Committee has recommended that during the development of the proposal and after the work has been completed Defence should continue formal liaison, including site visits, with the NSW fire brigades. The Committee has also recommended that as part of the study of fire risks throughout all Defence installations currently being undertaken, a formal risk management analysis of existing and proposed facilities be carried out by an independent professionally qualified fire safety consultant.

Defence acknowledged that the tri-Service warehousing operation proposed for the DNSDC is dependent on the Supply Systems Redevelopment Project—SSRP—being delivered on time. The SSRP aims to create a common core computing system to cater for the supply needs of the Australian Defence Force. The SSRP has had a chequered history and was the subject of a report recently by our colleagues on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The Committee has recommended the DNSDC project should proceed on the assumption that funds and other resources required to complete the SSRP on time will be provided.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
