SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 gives effect to a number of changes in the social security system.

Before I discuss the major aspects of the Bill, let me first say that I am aware of criticism that has been levelled at this sort of Bill in the past where, apart from changes to a number of social security programs, a significant number of minor and technical amendments are also included. In relation to the latter amendments, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill has a new format in which the Schedules introducing so called "minor and technical amendments" itemise each amendment. Senators may be aware that it has been past practice to insert technical amendments without any numbering; simply grouping them in Schedules.

I understand that the format in this Bill may become an approach adopted by other portfolios where a large number of minor and technical amendments is included in a Bill. Apart from providing the item numbers, the Explanatory Memorandum gives a detailed explanation of items considered to be of particular interest. This is in answer to criticism that too many technical, but important, changes are `buried' in the Schedules. This approach has not added to the size of the Bill but, of course, has resulted in a longer Explanatory Memorandum. However, that is the price I believe we should be prepared to pay to ensure an adequate explanation of the changes is given.
I will now discuss some of the more important items in this Bill.

The compensation provisions in the Social Security Act 1991 will be extended to cover Carer Pension. At the moment, partners of compensation recipients are already covered and it is logical to have the provisions apply to carers who themselves receive compensation payments. The provisions will also be extended to cover Carer Pensioners irrespective of for whom the care is being provided. Carers who receive a lump sum compensation payment will be treated in the same way as other pensioners who are subject to the compensation provisions.

The Bill will clarify the nexus between entitlement to Family Allowance (to be called Family Payment from 1 January 1993) and Child Disability Allowance and Double Orphan Pension. Put simply, a person with a child who attracts Child Disability Allowance or Double Orphan Pension will not attract Family Payment for that child unless the income and assets tests for Family Payment are met. The amendments will, however, make it clear that neither Child Disability Allowance nor Double Orphan Pension is subject to any income or assets test.

There are two amendments to the Pharmaceutical Allowance provisions. The first is a technical amendment to include Pharmaceutical Allowance as part of the rate calculators in the Social Security Act. The second is more important in that it will ensure that a social security recipient who is qualified for the allowance will not receive less than the full Pharmaceutical Allowance rate even if the application of the income or assets tests would otherwise reduce the rate to less than the full rate of allowance (but more than nil). This is consistent with the proposition that the allowance was introduced to compensate social security recipients in full following the initiative to remove access to Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme items free of charge.

The social security system is both complex and sophisticated in that it tries to target assistance to those most in need. Part of the running of a system which helps millions of Australians involves the extensive use of computers. The Bill will ensure that decisions which might look like `automatic' decisions made by force of law (ie where there is no discretion involved) and put into effect by a computer—for example, to cancel a payment—will still be subject to the full review rights embodied in the Social Security Act.

The Act at present provides that Newstart Allowance, Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance are not payable to a person if the person has not given the Secretary of the Department of Social Security his or her tax file number. The Social Security Act is amended in this Bill to enable the Secretary to request a tax file number as a condition of qualification from claimants of those payments I have mentioned. There is nothing untoward about this amendment. Similar provisions already exist for other payments but I mention this change as I am conscious of the sensitivities involved in tax file number matters.

Consistent with my firmly held view that personal information provided to the Department should be protected to the greatest extent possible, this Bill introduces amendments which will make it an offence for any person, including an officer of the Department, to access client records unlawfully, for example to "browse" paper files without authority, and a further offence to disclose or deal with information which has been accessed unlawfully. Browsing of computer records is already an offence under the Crimes Act.

Special Benefit is a discretionary hardship payment and payment is usually limited only to persons in Australia. This Bill will enable payment overseas where there are exceptional circumstances but only for a period of up to 13 weeks. This discretion will cater for very unusual situations, like having to visit a seriously ill relative, but limit overall the amount of payment available to a person outside Australia. I emphasise that payment overseas is to occur only in a very few exceptional circumstances.

I am pleased to say that this Bill also includes, by way of a Schedule, the International Social Security Agreement between the Republic of Cyprus and Australia. The Agreement is expected to come into force on 1 January 1993. It is another Agreement to add to our growing list of such Agreements with other countries which protect social security payments for persons who have had residence or made contributions in either country.

In recognition of the value of Australian Defence Force reservists, the Social Security Act currently allows reservists in training camps to qualify for Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance if those camps are inside Australia. The Bill will extend this concession to include reservists attending a training camp overseas.

A further concession to recipients of Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance who are under 18 year olds will be to exempt child maintenance payments to their parents from the parental income test. This is an acknowledgment that child maintenance is directed at assisting children and only maintenance paid to a recipient's parents which is not for children should be counted under the parental income test.

The Bill provides for limited relaxation of the Sickness Allowance rules. These will include provisions which allow for a discretion to backdate payment for up to four weeks following failure to lodge a medical certificate because of the person's medical condition or where there may have been delay in processing a medical certificate; to allow for payments, in certain circumstances, to 15 year olds undertaking a rehabilitation program and to allow for payment where a person might be in full-time education as part of a rehabilitation program.

Other areas covered by the Bill include the repeal of certain superfluous offence provisions and to limit to 3 months the period within which to lodge a claim for payment when a person's payment is cancelled overseas, without the need to return to Australia.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

This Bill introduces the substantial enhancements to the social security system announced in the Budget. It continues this Government's responsible and soundly based social security programs which continue to deliver support where it is most needed, but within Budget parameters.

Rate increases in pensions and benefits as a result of indexation will be available two months early by advancing the 20 March 1993 indexation to 28 January 1993. This means a maximum rate increase of $6 a fortnight for someone who is single and $5.00 a fortnight for each member of a couple. This will ensure that the Government's commitment to maintain the basic pension rate at or above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings is sustained.

A series of reforms of Rent Assistance will target those who most need support in the rental market. The flat $25 a week rent threshold which applies at present will be replaced with four different thresholds based on family situation and marital status. These thresholds will be indexed to CPI movements. The rate of Rent Assistance will increase from 50 cents to 75 cents for each dollar of rent paid above the threshold and the maximum rate of Rent Assistance paid to someone with no partner or dependent children will increase by $2 a week. This will mean an increase in Rent Assistance of up to $8.50 per week for a single pensioner without children. Existing Rent Assistance recipients who would be entitled to a lower Rent Assistance payment as a result of these changes will continue to receive their current level of Rent Assistance.

A range of measures aimed at Carer Pensioners reflects the Government's commitment to support these people who fulfil such an important role in our community. Carer Pension will now be available to people caring for severely disabled people aged 16 or over who are not pensioners because they cannot meet the full residence requirements. Under current arrangements, payment of Carer Pension continues while the carer temporarily stops providing care for up to 28 days. This respite period is to be increased to 42 days and carers will not need to remain in Australia during the period. Furthermore, carers will be able to participate in employment, education or training for up to 10 hours per week without affecting their payment, the earnings credit provisions will be extended to them and the bereavement provisions which apply on the death of the person being cared for will be applicable where the person was not the carer's partner.

Mobility Allowance assists people with disabilities with the costs of transport if they are engaged in employment or vocational training and are unable to use public transport without substantial assistance. This Bill will index Mobility Allowance in line with the CPI from 1 January 1993 and will also increase Mobility Allowance by $10 a fortnight. People who are undertaking job search as part of a Disability Panel activity plan will now have access to Mobility Allowance, as will people working for at least 8 hours a week in a voluntary capacity for charitable, welfare or community organisations.

To reduce the pressure on our young people who live away from the family home, a young person under 18 falling within the definition of "independent young person" will need to have lived away from home for only 18 weeks (rather than the current 6 months) to attract the higher rate of Job Search Allowance or other payments payable in these circumstances.

Full-time voluntary work is a useful vehicle for unemployed clients, especially those who are long-term unemployed or in particular age groups, to gain work experience, update their skills and make useful employer contacts. The system is being relaxed to allow clients to participate more in voluntary work without affecting their payments. Job Search Allowance recipients for 3 months or more and aged under 18 will now be able to undertake voluntary work for up to 30 days in a year, rather than the current 20. Recipients aged between 18 and 49 will have a similar concession extended to them. The modified voluntary work rules currently applying to over 55 year olds which allows up to 65 days of full-time voluntary work in a calendar year without affecting payment, will now apply from age 50.

People aged 50 and over on either Job Search or Newstart Allowance will benefit from the relaxed reporting requirements which currently apply to the over 55 year old age group and benefit from the rule for the same age group that the activity test is satisfied if the person earns at least 35% of average weekly earnings from employment entered into on or after 1 January 1990.

The Bill introduces several beneficial changes to Employment and Education Entry Payments from March 1993. The Employment Entry Payment for Disability Support Pensioners is being increased from $200 to $300 and qualification for it will no longer depend on continuous receipt of payment for at least 12 months. An Education Entry Payment of $100 will be introduced for Disability Support Pensioners. Widow B Pensioners and sole parents who are Special Beneficiaries rather than Sole Parent Pensioners because of lack of residence, will now also have an Employment Entry Payment and an Education Entry Payment available to them.

Permanent Australian residents and holders of certain temporary entry permits who arrive in Australia on or after 1 January 1993 will have to serve a 26 week waiting period before Job Search, Newstart or Sickness Allowance is paid. For permanent residents special benefit would be available if they satisfy the hardship test. The new restriction will not apply to people granted permission to enter Australia before the announcement of this measure in the Budget on 18 August 1992 or to people entering Australia as the partners of Australian residents of more than 26 weeks' standing, or for people entering under the Refugees, Humanitarian and Special Assistance Program, or people who are accepted as refugees under a Domestic Protection (temporary) Entry Permit. A Migrant Access Package will improve services for clients of non-English speaking background.

The existing three-tier social security appeals system of internal review, Social Security Appeals Tribunal and Administrative Appeals Tribunal is to be streamlined. People will no longer have access to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal unless they have first gone through the formal internal review mechanism which involves review by an Authorised Review Officer.

Several amendments taking effect in March 1993 deal with managed investments as they affect the operation of the income test. The rules governing managed investments will be simplified by removing the categorisation of these investments into accruing return investments and market-linked investments. Income for income test purposes will be calculated by multiplying the current value of the investment by its growth rate over the previous 12 months. Any losses assessed on managed investments may be offset against gains during the same period on other managed investments. Offsets will also be available against gains on listed shares and other listed securities from September 1993 when the managed investments rules are extended to listed shares and other listed securities. The income test will take account of growth on the managed investment only for the period during which the investor was a social security client.

Superannuation benefits are also dealt with in this Bill. Money in a complying superannuation or rollover fund will be disregarded for income test purposes until Age Pension age or until an annuity or pension starts to be paid. Once the person reaches Age Pension age, the investment will be handled under the managed investment rules. If an annuity or pension becomes payable, the rules on annuities or pensions will apply. If a withdrawal is made before Age Pension age, that part of the withdrawal representing growth while the investor was receiving pension, benefit or service pension will be assessed as income for 12 months.

From Royal Assent, allocated pensions and other pensions and annuities where the payment can be varied at the recipient's discretion, will be subject to the assets test and will be income tested by multiplying the current asset value by the earning rate of the fund.

As from April 1993, Commonwealth Fringe Benefits currently available to pensioners who satisfy the Fringe Benefit income and assets tests will be available to all pensioners and to long-term beneficiaries or allowees aged 60 or more. Eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits will be extended to recipients of mobility allowance from March 1993.

There are other initiatives in this Bill in such areas as the maintenance income test, indexation of the parental income threshold, Job Search and Sickness Allowances for certain 15 year olds, review of Special Benefit, Remote Area Allowance and service of notices of decisions under the Act.

The Bill will also make some minor and technical amendments to social security and related legislation, including consequential changes arising from the introduction of Family Payment from 1 January 1993.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill was initially introduced in November 1990 by my predecessor Senator Jo Vallentine. I am reintroducing it because of the continuing need to address peace and non-violence within the defence agenda and to support defence personnel's right to make decisions according to their consciences.

This Bill is based on the notion that major changes have occurred in all matters pertaining to war. War has changed—the days of face to face combat between huge forces of foot soldiers have gone forever. War has become increasingly dependent on high technology weapons systems, as a result of which we are supposed to become accustomed to such terms as "collateral damage"—meaning civilian deaths, and "surgical bombing"—meaning maximum damage for minimum bombs. With the change in warfare, there have been many effects which make people think of war in a completely different way. We are now in an age in which the scope of military activity inflicts unintended casualties and damage simply because of the nature of warfare.

With these changes to the nature of war, and there are many more, there has come a change in many peoples' attitudes to the possibility of their participation. For some, that would preclude any idea of serving in the armed forces at all, and it is pleasing to note that earlier this year the Parliament passed the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill, which will allow people subject to conscription into the armed forces to declare a position of conscientious objection for particular wars.

However, it is also clear from the experience of the Royal Australian Navy, and the American armed forces at the time of the Gulf War, that some serving members of those forces regarded the war as unjustified and that their consciences could not allow them to serve.
This Bill would allow serving members of the Australian Armed Forces to refuse to serve in a particular conflict on the grounds of conscience without incurring a charge of breach of discipline.

As Senator Vallentine said in her Second Reading Speech in November 1990 . . . "It is not a question of discipline. It is an issue of selective objection. It will not undermine the Australian Defence Force because I doubt if many serving military personnel will feel the need to avail themselves of it, but we should recognise the right of those who choose to do so.

It has been suggested that such a provision would make planning and training difficult, but in fact it should be obvious that to have a situation as confronted the Navy during the Gulf War, the disruption caused by a sailor refusing orders is infinitely worse than being prepared beforehand that some serving personnel will not be available for the particular tour of duty.

The ability of military authorities to be more certain of the state of readiness of their forces when committing troops to battle will be enhanced if mechanisms exist for dealing with CO status people before embarkation.

War, if we are to tolerate it at all, should be the preserve of those who agree to participate. No person should ever be placed in a position of having to fight against their will and against the dictates of conscience.
It is appropriate to reiterate comments made in my May 1992 speech in relation to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1992.

The Government's amendments to the Defence Act of 1903 took a most enlightened step in relation to the right of conscientious objection, namely that people who are conscripted into the ADF should be able to claim objection on grounds of conscience to particular wars or acts of war.

The government recognised that the nature of international relations has changed, and that warfare has changed, and that there are people in our society, indeed in all societies, who may not have an overall objection to war, but may believe sincerely that a particular war is morally wrong and that they would not be prepared to be involved. I congratulate the government on this move.

However, this enlightened move should also be extended to serving members of the armed forces. How can we say to the people of Australia that they are to take their place in the world fully recognising their responsibilities, and then tell members of the armed forces that they are not adult enough to decide for themselves whether they will fight in particular war operations.

Can we, as a society, claim the power to force a person to engage in war? For many years, the overwhelming response to that question has been yes—at least for the vast majority. It has been assumed that when the dominant groups of forces in society have decided to take up arms, offensively or defensively, then all "able bodied men" were required to follow suit to indicate their solidarity.
In some ways, it was easier in years gone by. It was easy to divide the world into "good and bad" or "them and us". But the world has changed, societies have changed, and individuals have changed.

The disintegration of the superpower polarity in the world has made the world less subject to cataclysmic acts of war but more subject to regional conflicts—precisely the types of conflicts in which peoples' ethnic and religious loyalty is likely to be a factor in determining whether or not they are prepared to fight.

In the past 50 years the international community has created numerous covenants and instruments to express a range of rights, privileges and responsibilities which have come to be regarded as essential for the pursuit of normal and fruitful relations within societies and in the international community.

These covenants have contributed enormously to peoples' sense of their place in society—people are more aware of their role as shapers of their society. In western societies like Australia, people have come to the realisation that citizenship requires more than following the herd.

People have come to realise that the onus of decision-making rests with them in so many areas of life. The ballot box is not the only point at which people express their thoughts on national directions and issues. Recent history has shown that Australians do not unquestioningly accept governments' views on a range of issues.

In this environment it makes no sense to suggest that people cannot and will not make up their own minds, based on the dictates of conscience, about the rights or wrongs of war and individual acts of war.

Furthermore, if life is a fundamental human right, then we must accord each person the right to choose which circumstances will induce them to place their life on the line for their country or any other cause.

The government, having recognised these issues in relation to conscripts, cannot now claim that those who are members of the Australian Defence Forces are endowed with less humanity, less ability to weigh up the morality of certain wars, or that they should be accorded less rights than potential conscripts. It is ultimately beyond the power of any government or military authority to force a person to fight; it is a mark of a civilised and mature society that it will not place an individual or a military authority in a position in which the individual will feel compelled to take unlawful measures to follow the dictates of their conscience.

In passing this legislation, the Parliament would be indicating that Australia is a mature nation, that it takes its place in the international community with a sense of self-assurance and pride in its people. It would be saying that we have shaped, and are shaping our national values on the basis of mature reflection on our place in the world, and not on some jingoistic browbeating of those to whom we would look in time of conflict.
This Bill asserts the fundamental right of members of Australia's armed forces to make their own decisions about those situations in which they are prepared to put their lives at risk.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Committee, it might be best if we go according to the running sheet. The first item on that sheet is program 1, Clerk's Office.

—Is the efficiency dividend which will have to be found likely to impair the work of the committee system, particularly in light of the fact that there is more work that has just been taken on in the immediate past?

—In that regard, I ask whether or not the additional committee to inquire into the loans affair, which has just recently been established, will be able to draw on full resources and be able to carry out its work?
—Yes, we do not expect to have any difficulties.

—What resources can we expect to be able to call on, including the number of staff that may be made available, and any consultancies that we may wish to draw upon, including witnesses expenses and so on?

—We should be able to have the usual staff of four for a committee. On any consultancies that might be needed, recommendations will be made to me. I will have to decide, in conjunction with the Clerk, whether the funds are available.
—I also asked about witness expenses because it may well be necessary to call witnesses from other States.
—I trust that we will deal with that in the usual way and, again, I do not foresee any difficulties at this stage.

—I would make the point that I think it is most important in a committee which is going to be the subject of much attention by the public and others alike that we know there are going to be full resources available for the committee to do its work efficiently, promptly and to the best of its ability, and to have the best witnesses present and the best advice available should we need it.
—As I said earlier, we do not anticipate any difficulties and we hope that we will be able to satisfy the points that Senator Bishop has raised tonight.
—On program 4 there was a reservation from Senator Crichton-Browne. Does any other senator wish to speak to that matter?

—I would ask, for the benefit of Senator Crichton-Browne, that we move on to program 5—and my colleague Senator O'Chee is here as well now—and then perhaps come back to program 4. Would that be in order?
—It would be a very bad way of starting our Estimates, but we will see what happens. Are there any matters to be raised on program 5?

—Could I ask a question relating to the details of fringe benefits tax paid by the Department of the Senate and whether or not any provision has been made should the Tax Office subsequently rule that fringe benefits tax would be payable for employees who work in this building to park in the car parks under this building? If there is to be no fringe benefits tax payable in respect of this select few, could Mr President advise the Senate of the basis of their understanding that no fringe benefits tax would be payable?
—We have made no provision in this budget for such an occurrence. I am not sure when the legislation comes into effect.

—As I understand it, there was to be a date which would fall within the current financial year, but that for political expediency it may well be deferred to 1 July 1993. Irrespective of whether or not that is the case, I would like Mr President's understanding of whether people who are employed in and park in this building are to be subject to that fringe benefits tax for parking like every other ordinary Australian or whether there is again some form of selectivity.
—I have been advised that at this stage we do not think that anybody who is parking here will be affected. However, I will check on that and let Senator Bishop know if I am wrong.

—Once again, this seems to be a most inequitable tax which is to be imposed on ordinary Australians where some will be favoured and some will not be favoured. I understand that even in the university environment people who are at the ANU will be treated in one way and those who are at the Canberra University will be treated in a different way—again, a most unsatisfactory arbitrary, unfair, inequitable tax.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. This is a speech which is not related to the Estimates, and I think Senator Bishop should return to the Estimates.
—It might be related to the Estimates somewhere else, but the nature of the tax itself is not related to the estimates of the Department of the Senate. I would uphold the point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Methinks Senator Childs protesteth too much. Methinks that the point has hit home. Would the President perhaps go away and come back to the Senate and advise us what his understanding is of the way the tax is to be administered by this Department of the Senate?
—Yes, if I am able to obtain any information, I will certainly bring it back and give it to the Senate.

—At page 36, I dealt with the problem of consultancies awarded to Mr Donovan. I think that point related to the nature of those consultancies and the need for that consultancy. My recollection is that that is the same Mr Donovan who did the so-called qualitative research for the Australian Tax Office to tell them what good folk they were.
—I have been advised that we do not have any contracts or consultancies with Mr Donovan.
—I asked a general question regarding the value of the consultancies used by the Department of the Senate. I wonder whether an answer could be provided.
—Are we talking about the whole of the Department of the Senate?
—Yes.
—I think it is a value judgment that individual senators have to make. Is the honourable senator asking for the total monetary value of the consultancies?
—I would like to know two things: first, the total value of the consultancies; and, secondly, the breakdown of which consultancies were used by which committees.
—I believe that the total figure was $594,698. I will try to get a breakdown in regard to the committees as soon as possible.
—If there are no further questions on program 5, we will move to program 6.

—Mr Chairman, I have a number of very brief questions on the reference in the report of the Committee in relation to security in Parliament House. On page 7 the Committee notes that the President informed the Committee that there would be a wider review of protective security at Parliament House, which had commenced at the time the report was put together. Could the President be kind enough to advise the Committee when that is likely to be completed now that there has been some opportunity to make some headway on it?

—As Senator O'Chee would probably be aware, the ANOA recommended the creation of an interdepartmental committee on which all parties with a role in the security of the parliamentary precincts would be represented. That body was set up. The Speaker and I established the Presiding Officers Advisory Group on Security chaired by the Security Controller and comprising representatives of each of the parliamentary departments, the Department of Administrative Services, Australian Protective Service and the Australian Federal Police. That advisory group is to report to us on protective security issues which extend beyond the responsibilities of the individual departments which may impact on security arrangements affecting the precincts as a whole.

PARA.TAB: On 14 October, following our consideration of the assessment of the security risks, threats and vulnerabilities, the Speaker and I directed the Security Controller, in consultation with the Usher of the Black Rod and the Sergeant-at-Arms, to prepare papers which listed the identified threats, vulnerabilities and risks and suggested means to deal with them, including cost estimates, and which dealt with the difficulties which have arisen in having the Australian Protective Service involved in the security of Parliament House. We have asked that these papers be completed by 26 November this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the President for his answer. My concern remains. As I expressed during the Committee hearings, we seem to have a very large number of APS officers costing an awful lot of money who are really responsible only for the security on one side of the building. We have attendants in the rest of the building but they are not armed in the same fashion as are APS officers. Clearly, there are two levels of security within the building. It may be that it is rightfully seen that there are two different levels of risk. But I think the incident in question with the four-wheel drive vehicle and also other incidents would demonstrate the fact that the risk is not perhaps as easily delineated as has previously been the case. Have discussions already addressed the role of the APS and whether a more uniform security arrangement can be applied to the building?

—Yes, that has in fact happened. I think the Speaker and I share some of the concerns that Senator O'Chee has mentioned. As I said, one of the main parts of the report is to deal with the difficulties that have arisen in having the Australian Protective Service involved in the security of Parliament House. I must point out, however, that if we were to change the situation, it would have to be in conjunction with the Minister for Administrative Services.

—My concern still remains the fact that we are paying a lot of money for the APS officers. I cannot remember the exact figure off the top of my head but it is quite substantial. We did not seem to be getting what I would consider to be terribly good value for money from the relevant department in terms of the amount of money that the Senate or the Joint House Department was forking out for this. I think this is one of the areas that we need to look at as well. If the assessment is made that we are going to have APS officers, I think the Committee would have to be satisfied that we are getting value for money out of those officers. During the hearings, it certainly did not seem to be the case that for the enormous amounts of money being expended we were getting the appropriate number of officers on the deck at any one period.

—It is approximately $5.2m. It is a lot of money. It is a matter on which the Senate Committee on Appropriations and Staffing has expressed concern in the past. I can assure Senator O'Chee that it is something we are going to look at very closely.

—I want to refer again to the security question. We had a lot of discussion during the hearing about a new plan and strategy being developed so that the security in this building is more satisfactory. We heard a good deal of evidence about how it is impossible to have a satisfactory system of security when the responsibility is split and nobody is really very sure who is finally responsible. Could the President tell us how far that new plan and strategy has developed? What are the names of the people who are going to be responsible and answerable? That will do for a start.

—As I just said to Senator O'Chee, this is a matter that concerns us. It is a matter which was pointed out in the Auditor-General's report. It is one of the main things that are being dealt with in the report that we have asked to be completed by 26 November. I believe that the people who are going to be directly involved are the Security Controller, the Usher of the Black Rod and the Sergeant-at-Arms.

—Does that mean that all of those divisions between the 24-hour watch, the people who are answerable on the Senate side of the building and the people who are available on the other side of the building, are going to come under the command of one person, who is going to be answerable?
—Yes, that is right—the Security Comptroller.
—Mr Curtis?
—Yes, that is right.
—How is that to be formalised? My recollection of the evidence given in the Estimates hearings was that Mr Curtis's evidence was not very satisfactory.
—What I do not want to do, Mr Chairman, is get too far ahead of the report. The papers are not completed at this stage. They will be looked at closely by the Speaker and me when they are available.

—These hearings were held some considerable time ago. This is now November. An election could be called tomorrow. There has been nothing done about security in this building other than the erection of those stupid kitty litter boxes. Quite frankly, the word around is that one might not get a Pajero in but one could get the Harley Davidson in.

PARA.TAB: If that is to be the final and arbitrary decision on security in this building, that is not good enough. If I understand your answer to me, Mr President, we are still looking at the paperwork which we were doing two months ago. Could you possibly give me a summary of how far we have progressed and when we can expect to see the definitive plan? We could then discuss the question of whether the appointment of Mr Curtis is to be finalised and formalised?

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it difficult to answer all of Senator Bishop's question because, as I said, the papers are not to be completed and given to the Speaker and me until 26 November.
—Why?
—That was the date that was set. I have read out a full statement about the security, and I am not in a position to add anything further to it until after that date.

—My feeling was—and if I go back to the Hansard, I am sure that the feeling that I had then will be confirmed—that I thought we were going to make real progress, and that I thought that you, Mr President, were of the view that what was going on in this building about security simply was not good enough and would not do. Quite frankly, I am disappointed that two months down the track we are sitting here and still waiting for more paperwork and the same players are all going to be in the same positions.

PARA.TAB: I would like you to confirm for me whether it is your belief that they are the same players, including the one particular man of authority in this building who has been subject to quite a lot of discussion in another context and who has been reprimanded and yet has not suffered, in any way, any lessening of his powers. We have all put up with this situation for some considerable time, but it cannot go on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that there are three people dealing with the situation at the moment. Until we get a copy of the report, which is not that far off, I am not in a position to say what the Speaker and I are going to do when we see the full report.

—We are all aware of the speculation about an early election being held, and I find it totally unacceptable that you have set a timetable with the Speaker that we are all going to put it off until the end of November, when we might not even get to the end of November in this session, and then the question will go unresolved again. This is simply not a satisfactory timetable. When was the deadline of 26 November confirmed as the deadline you were going to adhere to?

—We set the reporting date of 26 November when we got the report on 14 October. I am concerned about the security in Parliament House, and I am sure the Speaker is, too. We shall do everything we can to ensure that we get the best security possible.
—Is 26 November a sitting day?
—I am advised that it is; it is a Thursday.
—So you will be reporting to the Senate on that day, will you?
—I think that will be extremely difficulty if I only get the report that day. But we will report to the Senate as quickly as possible afterwards.
—Are you involved in any consultations or discussions that are going on in the preparation of that report?
—No, I have not been, not at this stage.
—So you will know absolutely nothing about it until the report is delivered to you on that date?

—Technically, that is correct. But I think all honourable senators would realise that since the events of 12 August, the Speaker and I have been involved quite heavily, firstly, in the commissioning on 13 August of the consulting firm to examine and report on the incident. That report was given to us on 17 August. On 18 August we announced a wider review of the protective security of Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: On 8 September we announced that Mr David Bell, a Director of Protective Security and Policy Training at the Federal Office of Justice, and Superintendent Curtis had been commissioned to conduct a comprehensive assessment of the threats, vulnerabilities and risks within and immediately adjacent to Parliament House. On 12 October the report of the assessment was presented to us. On 14 October we considered the assessment that was given to us, and we have asked for a final report to be given to us by 26 November. We have been well aware of the problems that have faced us since 12 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me get this right. By what you had to say there, I can only gather that the assessment that was given to you in the middle of October was unsatisfactory.
—No, it was not. We are now looking at remedial measures: how we answer the issues that were raised in that report—how we deal with them.

—With respect, my recollection of the questioning that we went through in the Estimates hearings was as follows: we considered that Mr Curtis was not adequate to do the inquiry and the report because of his behaviour with regard to the time that elapsed between the vehicle entering the parliamentary precincts and the building itself and his failure to have the vehicle searched in any way and the building cleared. From all those things I thought we had concluded from reading the Hansard that Mr Curtis was to have nothing to do with that report at all. If I heard your answer before the last one correctly, I think you said that Mr Curtis was part of the reporting team. Was that correct? If so, when was it decided that he was to be added to that team?
—The opinion of Mr Curtis that has just been given by Senator Bishop is Senator Bishop's opinion. It is not necessarily my opinion or the Speaker's opinion or other senators' opinion.

—Again—and I will see whether I can find the exact page reference—I think something like a quarter of an hour or 10 minutes went by before anything was done. There were a whole lot of concerns about the way in which the matter was handled. Also, if I recall, the whole justification for spending additional taxpayers' dollars in having an outside consultant involved in this was that it was considered that the people who are on the payroll, as it were, could not adequately do the job. If my understanding is not correct, would you mind telling me why we then used external consultants if these people were judged to be quite sufficient?

—As I understand it, I think the first report which we got from Price Waterhouse Urwick, which was done by a Mr Dixon, cleared Mr Curtis of a lot of the points that you are making against him this evening.
—Have we seen that report?
—No.
—Could we have that report tabled in the Senate?
—I am getting too much advice at a moment. I do not think it would be at all in order to table a confidential report in the Senate on the security of Parliament House.

—Then I am afraid that your statement that the report, which we are not allowed to see and may not read, which we have paid for, which allegedly clears somebody of not carrying out his duties satisfactorily, is just not good enough. I can see no alternative to your either making that report available to the Senate, so we can make a judgment ourselves, or providing some other evidence in relation to Mr Curtis. Any reading of the Hansard will show that the time that elapsed was not good enough. You still have not given me a good reason why we went to external consultants if the people in-house were good enough to carry out the job.
—The firm that we employed was quite critical of certain aspects of the security of Parliament House.
—Good.
—The report that it wrote was made available in confidence to all of the party leaders.

—That still does not solve the problem. We have conflicting statements. First, it was necessary to get an outside consultant; and, secondly, you tell us that the outside consultant cleared Mr Curtis of the discussions we had in the Estimates committee and our view that his handling of the matter was simply inadequate. Yet you tell me the same report was critical of him and what transpired. Those statements do not hang together. But we are not allowed to see the report in the Senate because you gave it to the party leaders.
—I did not say it was critical of him at all. I said it was critical of certain aspects of security in Parliament House.
—Could the President be very specific as to what precise things it was critical about?
—No, Mr Chairman.
—On the basis of this, I take it that Mr Curtis is to be installed as the man who is going to have complete and utter authority over the security of this building. Is that an accurate statement?

—Mr Curtis is on a two-year secondment which I believe ends in July next year, and I am going to wait until I get a copy of the report on 26 November before I say anything more about the position and who will occupy it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just so we can recollect what was said in the Estimates hearings, let me quote what Mr Curtis had to say, and then look at the way the matter is being dealt with. Mr Curtis said:

SPEECH.PARA: The evacuation in this case was only a precautionary measure.
I had asked the question why an announcement was not made to clear the building. Mr Curtis continued:

I had spoken to the offender, Moss, shortly after the incident; ascertained from him that there was a firearm in the vehicle; questioned him as to whether there were explosives in the vehicle; satisfied the advice that he provided me that there was only a single firearm and some ammunition in the vehicle.

In other words, I go back to the proposition that the entire building and people in it were placed at risk because Mr Curtis decided he believed Mr Moss, who was the man who had broken into this building with a firearm on board. Mr Curtis went on to say:

The evacuation continued simply as a precautionary measure, I guess to eliminate the risk of his not having provided me with the correct information and there being some form of incendiary device contained in the vehicle.
Pardon me and the general public for not, shall we say, being made to feel secure by this security which, I think at the last count, was costing us—was it $5 1/2m?

TALK.START.PARA: —That's just for the APS.

—That is just for the APS. Perhaps the President could refresh our collective memories on the total cost of security for this building where we rely on Mr Curtis's opinion that Mr Moss, who was found to be somewhat unstable, had told him a nice truth.

—I believe the figure is in excess of $10m. Senator Bishop might have a copy of the Hansard there; I do not have one at the moment, but I think Mr Curtis said he made a professional decision on the way he dealt with the person concerned and it proved to be correct.

—Lucky, were we not? What would have happened if he had been proved to be incorrect? Would that still have been a professional decision? The point is that there was a considerable risk in the strategy that he undertook. He was lucky; we were all lucky. But I am afraid we cannot afford to spend $10m a year and hope that somebody guesses right. The fact of the matter is that there is provision in this building to have it evacuated in a proper and systematic way. If that is not the case, we should hear about that as well. But, in the interim, for 10 million bucks, I do not think we are getting too much value for money.

—That is Senator Bishop's opinion. I have also tonight expressed some concern over the security arrangements, but I will have a much more detailed and final statement when I get a copy of the final report.
—Are there any further matters in relation to program 6?

—Just that I am not sure what the sitting pattern is after 26 November. I do not have the timetable with me. Could the President advise me? How soon after 26 November could the Senate expect to be apprised of the situation?
—If the Senate is not sitting—and I know there is always some doubt at this time of the year about whether we will be sitting in that next week—I will let honourable senators know in writing.
—Mr Chairman, do we sit the following week after 26 November?
—Which date are we talking about?
—We are talking about the date of 26 November, being the reporting date to Mr President.
—The 26th is a sitting day; the next week is not supposed to be a sitting week. There are two sitting weeks after that.
—If you would like to sit to discuss the security in Parliament House, I am sure Senator Knowles would agree.

—I am glad Senator Faulkner finds amusing the fact that had Mr Curtis's judgment been wrong, people in this building—the general public—would have been dead. It is interesting that he finds that amusing. I happen to find the question of the security in this building quite serious and I would be very pleased if the President would tell us that he will make that report available to us on the first sitting day after he has received it.
—I will make a statement.

—I have a question of the President, bearing in mind that the eighteenth annual report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing contains a comment that the Committee considers that the Department of the Senate should be able to cope with this decreased level of funding. Given that we are now into this running costs based system of departmental budgeting, that for the Department of the Senate a 1.25 per cent efficiency dividend was applied, and that therefore, in real terms, the appropriation was $423,000 less than that which was appropriated in 1992-92, in regard to program 6 and the Senate services of printing and transport, is there any difficulty in maintaining the framework of the appropriation for salaries?

—I did answer a question a little bit like this earlier. There are not any problems this year, but certainly this is a matter that the Senate Staffing and Appropriations Committee is going to have to look at for the next financial year.

—Without asking a rhetorical question, do I understand that there are no problems with the salary and wages appropriation for both transport and printing? I do not ask that in any sense other than that my understanding is that some ceiling has been placed on the overtime available in printing and the work is being contracted out because the wages ceiling, I think, has been breached by about 20 per cent. With respect, notwithstanding my views about the contracting out, the only example of outside printing I have seen was deplorable. Having said that, I refer more to the difficulty of containing salaries.

PARA.TAB: It was inevitable that, with the increase in postage granted to the House of Representatives and the Senate, there would be an increase in printing; and that with the increase in printing there would be an increase in wages. That is posing some strains on the wages and salaries component. I am trying to get very clear in my own mind whether there is a difficulty. That is what I understand to be the situation, but I have gone to the bother of discovering that for different reasons. While I am not conscious of it in any way impinging on the services of the transport section of the Department of the Senate, does the same thing apply there? I ask that in the context of what was a grave reservation of mine at the time, as the President will remember, when we said that the Committee considered that the Department of the Senate should be able to cope with this decreased level of funding—despite the cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation, as I understand it, is that there is a monitoring on overtime throughout the whole Department of the Senate. There is a ceiling, as far as the Printing Office is concerned. Some work has gone out to contract but I do not believe that there has been any diminution in services to honourable senators throughout the Department.
—Is the wages and salaries bill running 20 per cent above budget, or is it not?
—I am told that that is not correct, and we are hoping to come in on budget at the end of the year.

—I will be forgiven for never being able to understand the bookkeeping of bureaucracy. I understand that some of the printing is able to be contracted out because it comes from another section—administration, or whatever—and that offsets the difficulty of the increase in wages. Life is always more simple for me if I can see the figures as they really are, and not what clever bookkeeping does for us. That is why I am asking: is the printing being put out because there is a ceiling on wages which the Department is trying to put the lid on in respect of printing?

—Apparently, some of the printing was put out because it had to meet senators' demands at the time, but the running costs system is the system that Senator Crichton-Browne is describing. I do not know when there will be an election but, of course, that will also have some effect on what the final salaries and wages bill will be, because of sessional attendants and other things.

—What I am asking, obviously in a circuitous way, is whether we are finding that those in printing are not doing that which they are capable of doing. Putting aside the question of the number of hours that they can work—with health and safety considerations being embraced—is work being sent out to artificially keep the lid on wages? In respect of the transport section, are there restrictions on overtime which may impinge on services for the same reasons?

—At this stage, as far as the transport section is concerned, I do not believe there have been any difficulties. As far as printing is concerned, no artificial situations have been created by sending out printing.
—In other words, printing has been sent out because of time considerations rather than wages and salaries considerations?
—Yes.
—There being no further matters in relation to program 6, we will go back to program 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Program 4 refers to Committee Office. I ask the President again whether he perceives any problems in meeting the running cost base system of departmental budgeting to the extent that it has provided us with the appropriations which we presently have.

PARA.TAB: This is not meant to be a trick question, and I will explain my reason for asking it. I have raised this before. In order to refresh the President's memory, on the occasion that the Appropriations and Staffing Committee looked at this budget, I expressed reservations about one or two matters. The President will recall that in our report it was resolved that we could meet the budget. Subsequently, a committee, of which I have the dubious distinction of being a member, wrote and asked for additional staff, and a response came back from Mr O'Keeffe. Amongst a number of other things, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the running-cost base system of departmental budgeting introduced by the Federal Government and accepted by the Senate through the Appropriations and Staffing Committee, the Department of the Senate, like all executive departments, is subject to an annual budget reduction of 1.25% as an efficiency dividend on existing programs. Within this Department, the Committee Office is funded on a similar basis. It is, therefore, becoming—
not `may', not `expected'—
progressively more difficult to maintain existing Committee Office staff levels, let alone increase them.
Is the problem as I perceived it from the outset a reality, as Mr O'Keeffe says, or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —In the case that Senator Crichton-Browne refers to it was the decision of the Clerk and Mr O'Keeffe that sufficient staff was available to do the work for that Committee. It was an individual decision for that particular case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really do not want to get into a dispute—I will save that for another time if I think it is appropriate—about whether the decision made without consultation with the Committee was the right one. The question I was really asking concerned the words used by Mr O'Keeffe, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, therefore, becoming progressively more difficult to maintain existing Committee Office staff levels, let alone increase them.

He was referring to the budget, and the 1.5 per cent efficiency dividend. I am not talking about whether it was a right or wrong decision in respect of increasing the staff. I am simply talking about a reflection of Mr O'Keeffe's correspondence on the capacity, rightly or wrongly, to fund additional staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that in this particular case the decision that was finally made was also the decision that the Secretary of the Committee recommended. Earlier I was asked whether the committee system would be able to operate properly this year, and the answer that I have been given is that it will be able to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to get involved in what the Committee did or did not do, but now that it has been raised I want to put on the record that the Committee unanimously resolved to ask for additional staff. The Secretary did not demur from that view. Contrary to the knowledge of the Committee, he wrote recommending that there be no increase and the decision was made, without consultation with the Committee, except that Mr O'Keeffe, in acknowledging what the then Secretary said, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted your own assessment, as a resource manager well placed to judge the matter, that no additional staff resources are required . . .
To me, that is a very unsavoury, subjective judgment made unilaterally, and independent of the Committee.

PARA.TAB: I am not asking these questions in respect of that particular matter. I had not intended to raise them, but I will raise them in great detail if it helps anybody in this chamber. I was really talking about Mr O'Keeffe's words—not about this or any other committee. Mr O'Keeffe happens to be, as I understand it, Clerk-Assistant (Committees). He talks about the 1.25 per cent dividend. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is, therefore, becoming progressively more difficult to maintain existing Committee Office staff levels.
That is what I am asking about. I am not asking about any decision to increase or decrease staff anywhere. I am asking about a set of words which, to me, are graphically clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is becoming increasingly difficult to find sufficient staff, but resources will be made available from other areas of the Department to ensure that the committee system continues to operate efficiently.

—Unless some artificial fat has been built in somewhere else and has been transferred to make up for a shortfall of necessary funds for the committee system, clearly the Budget is less than is necessary and clearly the words used—`the Committee considers that the Department of the Senate should be able to cope with this decreased level of funding'—are in error. They are fundamentally wrong. The truth of the matter is that Mr O'Keeffe tells us in his letter to the Committee that it is becoming progressively more difficult to maintain existing committee levels—not that it may become more difficult, not that we have to watch out for it, but that it is becoming increasingly more difficult. That is what Mr O'Keeffe is telling us. That contradicts the view of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee that the Senate should be able to cope. They are the words—`the Committee considers that the Department of the Senate should be able to cope with this decreased level of funding'. We are told by Mr O'Keeffe that it is becoming progressively more difficult to maintain existing committee office staff levels.
—All I can say is what I have said previously. If the committee system requires more money, it will be found from somewhere within the Senate Department.

—I acknowledge that, but I take it that the President is saying that he also acknowledges that the present appropriation with respect to the committee level is not satisfactory and that it is becoming progressively more difficult to maintain existing committees.

—As I said, we will find the resources to do the job. It is becoming more difficult. Quite obviously, it is something that we will have to look at carefully in the Senate Appropriations and Staffing Committee when it comes up in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge what I understand to be the situation—that is, that the funding is not that which is necessary to have these committees function in the way which is considered by the Senate to be desirable and it is becoming progressively more difficult to maintain present services.

PARA.TAB: I turn to a further matter relating to committees—that is, the question of part time staff. I refer to correspondence between me and the Mr President, and specifically to his response, which was stimulated by some deliberate questions I asked of the Clerk at the meeting of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee relating to the circumstances in respect of part time staff. The Clerk informed the Committee, in what I thought was a very logical way, that part time staff would be provided to committees where it was desirable, on the part of the Committee, and where it best served the interests of the Committee. He did not say that we would have imposed on committees some bureaucratic system whereby, because the Public Service had decided it would have part time staff, the committees would have to wear them. I was quite deliberate on that in a number of questions I asked and I was assured that such staff would be provided only where it was compatible with efficiency for the Committee.
The question of part time staff was subsequently raised by the same Committee to which I referred earlier. Mr O'Keeffe, in his correspondence, to which I have previously referred, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, in view of the committee's objections to officers in such circumstances—
referring to part time staff—

I must carefully examine the position. Nevertheless, I would have to seek advice from the Department of Industrial Relations and the Public Sector Union before even considering whether it would be proper to recommend the removal of the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee secretariat from the permanent part-time scheme and before examining the position of the partially incapacitated officer.
With respect, that is not a reflection of the advice that the Committee received at the time the appropriations were being contemplated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that part time staff will not be used if it will affect the efficiency of the Committee.

—Ultimately, the written word seems to have more weight in bureaucratic circles than the spoken word. What is the status of the words used by Mr O'Keeffe when he said he would have to seek advice from the Department of Industrial Relations and the Public Sector Union before even considering whether it would be proper to recommend the removal of the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee secretariat from the permanent part time scheme? Does that mean that it is not a question of whether it is in the interests of the efficiency and effectiveness of the committee but rather of whether the Public Sector Union agrees and whether there are any problems for or disagreement from the Department of Industrial Relations? Rather than ask a separate question, I ask: what role do they play in deciding whether the Committee will have part time staff and how it affects the efficiency of the Committee?
—They have to be consulted if there is any general objection to part time staff being used.

—Perhaps Senator Sibraa could clarify `general objection' for me. The correspondence to Mr O'Keeffe did not talk about any general objection to principle. It was quite specific. When I asked the question, I gave the example of having two references running at the same time, two part time staff and a three-hour time difference between Western Australia and Canberra. If I want to speak to the man who is handling reference A, who goes home at lunchtime, I have to get up at 3 o'clock in the morning to ring him.
—The Senate officers believed that there were no problems with the efficiency of the Committee in the circumstances that Senator Crichton-Browne has stated.

—That has always been a source of fascination to me. I do not know who is in the best position to make a judgment. The Committee unanimously resolved that we needed additional staff and the Secretary, on his own initiative, wrote to Mr O'Keeffe and told him we did not—without raising his hand and saying, `Mr Chairman, I do not agree', `Can I suggest you consider the following propositions', or `This is a matter that perhaps I can do a paper for you on'. In his correspondence, Mr O'Keeffe said to the Secretary of the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted your own assessment, as a resource manager well placed to judge the matter, that no additional staff resources are required at this stage of the committee's inquiries.

That might be fine and dandy, but perhaps I can save myself some trouble, as can everybody else on the Committee, by thinking about these things. In the same way, the Committee as a general principle was not opposed to part time staff. It was opposed to part time staff in a quite specific, clear and detailed circumstance. Without wishing to probe the point to anybody's embarrassment, perhaps Senator Sibraa could point to the fact which led anybody to believe that there was a general objection by that Committee to part time staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question gets down to whether the work is being done. The Secretary of the Committee said the work was being done.

—Senator Sibraa is really inviting me to take a completely contrary view, including the tabling of some documents, which I do not think would be helpful to anybody. That is why I make the point: who decides whether the work has been done, the Committee or the Secretary?
—I am aware of this correspondence with Senator Crichton-Browne. All I can say is that I will have another look at it for Senator Crichton-Browne.

—I do not wish to pursue the matter past that which is necessary, but to the extent that the Committee is in receipt of correspondence which is quite contrary, not in general terms but in specific terms, to the advice given by the Clerk—the better advice, with respect, without making a judgment about Mr O'Keeffe's advice; it stands on its own without my comment—the Committee ought to have the flexibility to decide its required staffing arrangements within the constraints of the global Budget, within the constraints of discussions with Mr O'Keeffe and perhaps with Mr Evans and the Secretary of the Committee. Surely, these decisions should be made not in splendid isolation by the Secretary of the Committee in consultation with nobody else.

PARA.TAB: I would be very disappointed, not having pressed home some points on this matter—which I am very reluctant to do in this forum or anywhere else—if I did not take advantage of the Committee of the Whole discussion to nail this right down. If, ultimately, the advice is that the Committee or any other committee does not want part time staff, for the only reason that committees never want part time staff, they will not have part time staff. No nonsense of a suggestion is ever put that there is some subliminal, hidden reason why any committee would in some general way oppose part time staff, any more than we oppose smokers or non-smokers, women or men, those over 40 or those under 40 or those fat or thin. It is a nonsense to suggest there was any general disapproval of them. The matter was first raised by me in very specific and clear terms in the way I have outlined them tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop asked me earlier about the cost of consultancies for committees. The cost of consultants employed by Senate committees in 1991-92 was $117,659.

—I thank Senator Sibraa for that information. I wonder if he could break it down further to how much was spent per committee. I note that the vast amount of money for consultancies was spent not on committee work. That must have been consultancies in the general work and business of the conduct of the Department of the Senate. Would that be correct?
—In appendix 13, there is a list of external consultants engaged in 1991-92. If there are any further details that Senator Bishop wants, we will try to get them for her.
—The earlier figure was $179,000, was it?
—Out of $594,000, which is the figure I was given earlier.
—Yes, approximately.

—It seems to me that the servicing of committees by consultants has been the minor part of the expenditure. I would be interested to know which committees used or chose to use consultants—not in a critical sense but just for information. I presume that the remaining consultancies were used for the running of the Department of the Senate per se. I wonder whether I could be told if that is because the Department of the Senate believed that it was understaffed in certain areas or they were one-off specific items and if the Department would expect to spend a similar amount on general running costs in the next financial year.

—I will get Senator Bishop a detailed reply. I believe that in excess of $200,000 of those consultancy costs was associated with the Parliamentary Education Office. But I will obtain the full details that Senator Bishop has asked for.

—In relation to the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department, there were no matters raised in the Committee's reports. There were no unanswered questions or reservations relating to those Departments. So that concludes the examination of the Department of the Senate. Before Mr President leaves, I thank him for his assistance this evening.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill agreed to.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to Appropriation Bill (No. 1), be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We start with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: program 1—Departmental policy advising.

—I am still very concerned about the ecologically sustainable development policy as well as the legislative arrangements regarding the Wet Tropics Management Authority Bill, which is one of the first of these Bills to have been put before a State parliament. From what I can understand of the hearings, the Wet Tropics Management Authority Bill was never actually discussed at all with the relevant section of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

PARA.TAB: Since the date of the hearing we have moved on. Parliament is now sitting again in Queensland, and I would be grateful to know, to start with, whether the Bill has in the interim been discussed with the relevant advising section of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or whether this will just be a case of the legislation going through without discussion, without input, notwithstanding the fact that the Commonwealth foots half of the bill for the Wet Tropics Management Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has not been any discussion between the Prime Minister and Cabinet and those responsible for the relevant legislation. I understand that discussions on behalf of the Commonwealth are being undertaken by the appropriate Department, which is the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

—In other words, the relevant part of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, which has a responsibility in relation to ecologically sustainable development and advising the Prime Minister on such matters, has simply been bypassed by Minister Kelly. Is that what Senator McMullan is telling the Committee?
—No.

—Could Senator McMullan then advise the Committee what role the relevant portion of this Department has had in relation to the formulation of that legislation, because we are trying to work out how these people justify their existence as public servants on the public payroll?

—The last remarks were somewhat gratuitous. My understanding, and I do not think it is different from the one we had when we discussed it at the Committee, is that there are important functions for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in coordinating the development of ESD. That involves more than matters that are solely the responsibility of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. A number of agencies are involved. Therefore, there is an important coordinating function.

PARA.TAB: There would be some concern if any of the agencies with a particular brief—DASET, Primary Industries and Energy, whichever it were—were to chair the group because it might be felt that it indicated a lack of balance between the competing interests. There is also an influence on the level and intensity of involvement of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet in any issue, including this issue, depending upon whether it is likely to come to Cabinet and therefore involve the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in that capacity.

Individual policies and programs within the ESD strategy rest with the portfolio Minister and his or her Department. In this instance, the responsibility for this area rests with the portfolio Minister for DASET and her Department. That is why it is dealt with by it. There is a broader coordinating function, which is the responsibility of PM and C. In this instance, they are individual legislative matters. But other policy matters come up which may be the responsibility of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories or some other Minister. They deal with those. We are not doing it twice, nor is PM and C, but there is an overall framework within which those individual activities are undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan has mentioned the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I want to get it on the record once and for all so that we know exactly who the players are. Perhaps Senator McMullan would like to tell us what other departments are involved in this coordinated approach that we hear so much about.

—I want to get it clear. From the way the question was expressed initially, I thought that Senator O'Chee was asking who was involved in the coordination of this piece of legislation. I think he was asking a broader question. There is not a role with regard to the coordination of this Bill. We have established that that is the responsibility of DASET.

PARA.TAB: With regard to ESD overall—which is as I understood the question—a number of departments are involved. The core ones are Prime Minister and Cabinet; the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories; Primary Industries and Energy; Industry, Technology and Commerce; Transport and Communications, Treasury and Finance. It may be that another Department would be involved with regard to a particular aspect of an issue, but I understand that those are the core departments that are primarily coordinated within this process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan said that the carriage of the wet tropics management legislation is now being handled solely by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I assume, therefore, that that means that Minister Kelly is the Minister who is happy at a Commonwealth level for the Wet Tropics Management Authority to be delegated power under the Bill to deal on its own behalf with foreign organisations and bodies. Is that what Senator McMullan is telling me, or was not anybody else in Cabinet advised about the fact that the Wet Tropics Management Authority Bill proposes to give to the Wet Tropics Management Authority the power to deal, negotiate and liaise with foreign organisations and foreign bodies?

PARA.TAB: A reasonable construction of that Bill would have one believe that the Wet Tropics Management Authority can go off and do whatever it wants and make its own arrangements, for example, with the United Nations environment program. Under the construction of that Bill, it is not unreasonable to say that the Wet Tropics Management Authority could attend in its own right an earth summit, if we were to have another such summit. It has the power to deal, negotiate and liaise in its own right with foreign organisations and bodies. Perhaps Senator McMullan could elucidate as to which Department was advised of this and who approved that from the Commonwealth point of view?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter that has anything to do with the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet Estimates, because it was not a matter dealt with by PM and C. I am not even sure whether people in the appropriate department would share Senator O'Chee's interpretation of the legislation. That is for others to be concerned about. I do not know the answer to that question. Certainly it does not come up under this heading.

—With due respect to Senator McMullan, it is a very important matter because this is the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. This is the Department which arguably is the premier Department within Cabinet. Its role is to advise the Prime Minister. One would certainly believe that the people who are advising the Prime Minister would want to know that this Bill extends to the Wet Tropics Management Authority's external affairs powers that are the prerogative of the Commonwealth. If that would not concern the Prime Minister, I do not know what would.

PARA.TAB: However, according to Senator McMullan, it has nothing to do with the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and we are to leave it in the hands of Minister Kelly. We have already seen what an abominable job Minister Kelly does when she tramps around the world stage. We are now to see a further derogation of those powers into the hands of the Minister for the Environment. If this is what Senator McMullan wants us to accept, I am afraid that he is asking us to accept the unacceptable.

There has to be some clear control exercised over this whole matter. Whilst it may be very good and proper in principle to talk about these things, necessary constraints must be placed on these bodies. I do not care whether Dr Hitchcock or somebody else heads the Wet Tropics Management Authority, but the general view of many people in the area affected—and I know that Mrs Kelly is not in the area affected—is that they do not want the Wet Tropics Management Authority to have unfettered power to deal with foreign bodies.

It is wholly unacceptable to have a body that can run rampant over the local authorities, because there is no responsibility on the Wet Tropics Management Authority to liaise with local councils.
