It can go off and do whatever deal it wants with whatever foreign organisation or body that it sees fit to deal with. That is unacceptable. I ask Senator McMullan why this has not been brought to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Why has it been given wholly into the realm of Minister Kelly, whom we have already seen is totally inadequate when it comes to dealing with these issues at an international level?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to pursue Senator O'Chee's rude remarks about Mrs Kelly. She can probably cope with those slings and arrows without too much pain. I have nothing to add to my other remarks.

—I am a little disturbed that Senator McMullan might consider those comments rude. If I want to be rude, I have not even started about Minister Kelly. I was merely repeating a comment which is made by many people in relation to her lamentable performance over the earth summit and her even more lamentable performance over the educational pack that was sent out to schools.

PARA.TAB: I remind this Committee that Minister Kelly not only endorsed the schools environment pack but also made sure her photograph was on it. However, when the flak came back about what an outrageous, lopsided and ill-informed document it was, she said she did not even know what was in it and her Department approved it all. These are not rude comments about Minister Kelly. Unfortunately they are very apposite comments.

What particularly concerns me is the fact that Senator McMullan refuses to say whether the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was advised of any of these consequences of the Bill. If the Commonwealth is going to foot half of the cost of the Wet Tropics Management Authority—and it would not be inappropriate to talk about the enormous cost of that body—then I believe there ought to be some decent restraint and supervision imposed over the body, particularly when there are these extensions of the power of the Wet Tropics Management Authority that one could arguably see as encroaching upon the external affairs powers of the Commonwealth.

We are pumping something in the vicinity of $8m or more into the Wet Tropics Management Authority every year and there is great dissatisfaction amongst the people in the affected areas as to exactly what they get for their money. Almost half of that money is taken up in corporate support and over half of the money is corporate support and public relations put together. Very little money seems to actually go into worthwhile projects on the ground.

If we are to continue to fund this body at that rate, I dread to think what will happen if these people are given unfettered powers to make arrangements with foreign organisations. Whilst Senator McMullan may think that is the end of the issue, I assure him it is not. At a later point in time and in another place we will have to pursue the Wet Tropics Management Authority, because quite clearly it has run amuck.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—We will proceed to subprogram 1.1.6, Northern Development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that a number of the issues that are currently being addressed in the area of Northern Australia will now take their genesis from two reports. I would hesitate to say `important' reports, because of the quality of the documents that have recently been produced.

PARA.TAB: One was a document prepared by the Centre for Applied Economic Research and Analysis earlier this year, which drew largely on the work of Professor Percy Harris from the James Cook University. That report was entitled Northern Australian Economic Development Strategy. In the last month or so the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has released an interim report entitled North Australia Social Justice Strategy.

Much of the preparation for the Northern Australia economic development strategy really did concentrate on three main areas that do impact in Northern Australia; firstly, the changes in the volume of economic activity; secondly, the changes in the level of living in the communities; and, thirdly, the changes in productive efficiency. However, the economic development report really only addressed the changes in the volume of economic activity or the growth over time in the area which we generally call Northern Australia.

I must express some profound disappointment and concern about the later report, the interim report on a social justice strategy. This document was recently released by the Minister for Northern Australia, Mr Ben Humphreys, and is of some 40-odd pages. I really do question what will form the basis for the subsequent report that is alluded to in the interim report itself, and in what we would come to consider to be the activity that would flow from this.

My reason for saying that is found on page 7 of the interim report where it states that it is acknowledged that the North Australia social justice strategy has an aim to achieve better services for Northern Australia. It goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Strategy has four related components, each vital to achieving the Government's overall aim. These components are:

PARA.TAB: 1.Improving consultation with communities to identify problems and take account of community suggestions for improvements in services.

2.Better planning, design and delivery of services to enable better matching of services to needs in North Australia, to make mainstream Commonwealth programs more adaptable to local circumstances, and to develop specifically targeted programs for exceptional locations or needs.
3.Improving information about what services are available and how to access them.
4.Developing foundations for the future, including finding more efficient and effective ways to provide services.

SPEECH.PARA: These are strong, pious but cobbled together words which talk about nothing more than consultation, planning, information and a future dream.

PARA.TAB: That is my major criticism of this entire report. All it is is a cobbling together of programs that are, should be and could be very properly performed by all of the various arms of functional government, no matter what political persuasion or no matter where. I find that there is no real emphasis on goals or strategies in the area of social justice. There is no statement even of this Government's philosophic commitment as to what it sees as social justice that we hear so much about in this particular report. The report does not go into any constructive or viable ways in which the Commonwealth will work with the State or Northern Territory Government to achieve what the Labor Government so often prides itself on achieving in the area of social justice.

I am sure that Senator McMullan will be aware that during the Estimates process I asked a number of questions of all of the functional departments as they operate in Northern Australia for the details of their consultancies. It is very interesting to look at the consultancies that were given in the current financial year by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet portfolio. Over a quarter of a million dollars worth of consultancies were given and what do they achieve?

The first one was from the Office of the Status of Women, which was a report on implementing the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women, particularly as it applied to the Northern Territory. The cost of that was $2,500. From the Aboriginal Reconciliation Unit to the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association there was a $45,000 consultancy to inform Aboriginal media, and through them the Aboriginal and Torres Strait communities, about the reconciliation process. That is already going on and is well known. That report cost $45,000.

From the Office of Multicultural Affairs there was a consultancy of $10,660 and the subject was the representation of cultural diversity in the media. In addition, there was a $2,800 consultancy for group discussions with people of non-English speaking backgrounds to determine the extent of the participant's experience of and views on access to Commonwealth services and programs.

An amount of $155,510 is allocated to the Centre for Applied Economic Research and Analysis to study the economy of northern Australia and to prepare the economic strategy options for developing policies in the development of northern Australia. As we know, that report came down well before this Budget, yet nothing can be identified as having properly flowed from that economic strategy into this year's Budget. Also, from the Office of Northern Development, $23,524 is paid to the Australian Science and Technology Council for the development of a north Australian research compendium. But then of course one goes into that body itself, the Australian Science and Technology Council, and finds that there is an additional $30,000 for the development of this compendium. So there is a total cost of some $53,000 odd dollars for further research.

This Labor Government is good at research. It is good at passing out consultancies to its mates all throughout Australia and keeping academics and various people writing reports. This can be seen in any department—the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the minerals area, the CSIRO, the whole lot of them. During the Estimates, I will be producing a document which sets out every single one of the consultancies produced by every Federal department as it applies to the Northern Territory. It will be a staggering document and it will be an indictment that none of the results of all of those reports—whether they be on national parks and wildlife services or on the environment—end up being commented on in an interim report on social justice.

I would have thought social justice was about jobs, about employment of people in the community. As I said earlier, in this report on social justice there is no acknowledgment that the underlying principles of social justice depend almost entirely on the provision of employment. Instead, one gets the impression from reading this that northern Australia is an underprivileged or Third World country. That is not the case.

There is no linkage between the two reports, namely, the social justice strategy and the economic development strategy which was brought down earlier in the year. In the March Estimates I asked a question of the head of the Office of Northern Development, Mr Gray:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the coordination between the social justice strategy and the economic strategy?
Mr Gray's response then was:

The coordination is in the form of the secretariat having had discussions with those who are conducting the economic strategy at James Cook University. There is clearly going to be reference in the economic strategy to those schemes, if you like, or those processes which will impact upon economic development in the north so far as the various services provided by government agencies impact upon it. There is communication and consultation between the two groups who have the responsibility for putting those two strategies together.

Fine pious words in March, but where are they now? Why is it not commented on in the interim report? Where is the coordination? There is no drawing together of the two in any way that would properly sustain a community in northern Australia. It makes me mad that this Government is running around throwing out millions of dollars of largesse in consultancies and economic studies, but not on the programs that will assist people living in remote parts of Australia or in the northern part of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is very important also to look at a number of the areas where we would expect the various departments to pull together. I find this interim report of the social justice strategy to be so transparent in that it is obviously written by someone who is used to doing academic reports for universities or someone else. The only new jobs I can see being created through it are going to be in the production of more reports in more areas. Whether it is the Department of Industrial Relations and ATSIC combining to fund a half a million dollar establishment and first year operational costs of a national Aboriginal employer association, why has there not been a cooperation of bringing the Aboriginal people and the general community together in the employment agencies that already exist?

There is a $36m allocation over the next four years to supplement the phased implementation of award coverage to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations funded wholly or partly by ATSIC. The report goes on and on in these particular areas. I would comment that the consultancy list from DEET is not yet in; the full list from ATSIC is not yet in for these considerations; the consultancy lists from the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council are not yet in. I am wondering why so many of the departments have not yet been able to respond. They are not alluded to in the social justice report, yet I know that the Government has missed hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not millions of dollars.

Instead, we get the pious words that would come out of various departments such as the Aboriginal student and parent awareness program, the national Aboriginal health strategy, the community-controlled health services, the community agents program, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander interpreter service, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander liaison officers, the rural affairs workshops, the rural health alliance, and the community relations program in the office of local government. The only jobs coming from this report are for these people to do more consulting and more gathering of information and not job creation.

I would point out that if anyone turns to Fightback and looks at the policy announcements that a number of us have made, he will see that our policies are all determined on eliminating taxes and on boosting the economy of the north with particular benefits for the families that live there, permitting the full potential of our vast resources to be developed and value added industries to be realised. Fightback also outlines the benefit for workers in northern Australia and the ensuring of full statehood of the Northern Territory as part of constitutional development processes. There is no mention of any of that in any of these reports from this Department. Is it any wonder that people in the north have lost confidence in the Labor Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —There was not a question in all of that, though I know Senator Tambling probably wanted to get it off his chest and I suppose it is better out than in. I simply say that there are two important documents. There is an interim social justice strategy document and there is an economic strategy document. They stand apart, but they will obviously be considered together by the Government when the final report on the social justice strategy comes in. That document is out there for public consultation; such documents make a contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I suspect, without joining in the rhetorical flights of Senator Tambling, that those reports put together make a slightly more positive contribution to the prospects of Aboriginal people and others than might Fightback, but we can have that debate a hundred times. This is not the place to do it. I did not drag Fightback in; I am just trying to kick it out of the debate. It is not what we are supposed to be talking about, but there was not a question in any of that.

I do not think one should disparage the document simply because Senator Tambling does not like some of the words in it. Let us judge it by the outcome when the two reports are considered, get a considered deliberation by the Government on the basis of those and get some decisions and some implementation. Senator Tambling may not like the implementation. That will be a proper subject for debate at the time and I am sure we will have it when it comes up. Apart from that, I think we welcome useful contributions to public debate, even those with which we sometimes disagree.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a couple of specific questions that I would ask Senator McMullan to respond to. Principally they relate to issues of timetabling. Why in the 1992-93 Budget were there no new initiatives identified for northern Australia, particularly those that had been alluded to and had been very obvious in the media earlier this year, were under the full consideration of the Centre for Applied Economic Research and Analysis, and those that were tabled earlier this year in the report to the Commonwealth Government entitled North Australia economic development strategy? That would be the first question of timetabling on those important economic strategies.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, why is the final consideration of the social justice strategy by this Labor Government not proposed until after the next Federal election? I would have thought that, particularly prior to an election, a Labor administration would have wanted to consider and would normally have been considering many of the appropriate goals and strategies of social justice on which I have commented and which I believe are so deficient in this particular report.

So really it is a question of why the social justice strategy football has been kicked well into 1993 where it will not be an issue until after the next election and probably will never be implemented by a Labor administration, but it is also a question of why none of the initiatives flagged in the various studies on economics was addressed in this year's Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, as you would know, Madam Temporary Chairman, this is not the place for a policy debate about whether—
—It has not stopped you at any other time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What was in the Budget and what was not is policy—p-o-l-i-c-y. Senator Tambling might not have heard of it.
—I said that it has not stopped you at any other time.

—It has actually, and with regard to Estimates committees it certainly will. I would be very happy to have the debate. I think there are a large number of things in One Nation, in the youth employment initiatives, and in the Budget that are of significant benefit to northern Australia, but I do not intend to get into that debate right now because it is off the subject.

PARA.TAB: That which was properly an Estimates committee question related to the timetable for the social justice strategy, and I have to say that I played no part in and cannot give the Senate detail about the reason for that particular debate. But quite clearly, with the interim report having come out only recently, if we are going to have any serious consideration of questions of consultation on the scale that I think Senator Tambling would agree would be appropriate with a document like that—and as the normal process of consultation takes quite a long time, and as we have a very geographically dispersed population whose responses are significant in such considerations—it is only appropriate that a few months be given.

I think the date is mid-1993 with 30 June being the last day that we expect it might be given, but hopefully it will be earlier. It does not seem to me to be an unreasonable time. I cannot give the Senate a particular reason why that time was chosen as others rather than I made that decision. But I think that it is the sort of timetable one would expect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned at Senator McMullan's answers because these issues were all raised here in the Senate in the Estimates committees. I refer in particular to the consideration that took place on 27 March 1992. I would have thought that in the preparation of this interim report the issues and the timetabling would have been well and truly flagged, and therefore the various issues should have been addressed in the Budget context. Certainly by now, 9 November, quite some considerable time has passed in which many of the discussions should have taken place.

PARA.TAB: I note that towards the end of the interim report there is basically a regurgitation of all of the programs of other departments and agencies, such as Telecom, Australia Post and various broadcasting areas. They are put forward as if they were major initiatives of the Government. But, of course, each and every one of the programs identified in that report had been flagged to Government in previous years' Budget considerations. There is nothing new in anything that is stated in this social justice strategy. It is merely a cobbling together of programs that the Government has been considering, has been funding, and has been carrying out for a number of years. There are no new orders of priority, there are no goals, there are no strategies, there are no reassessments that are so necessary in these particular areas if in fact social justice is to be addressed as having a priority in the community.

Similarly, the considerations of the economic development strategy were well known back before March. In fact, I believe that I raised these in the Estimates late last year and, therefore, I was looking in the context of the August Budget for some deliberate statement. Senator Collins had previously been appointed the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia, a position which has now been inherited, as part of the necessary government changes, by Mr Humphreys. But I would have thought that the fact that Senator Collins is also from northern Australia would have put more priority on and initiated more concern in this particular area.

But, very obviously, the Government has looked at the marginal seat strategy and I think has presumed that, because the seats of Kalgoorlie, Grey, the Northern Territory and Kennedy are all currently held by Labor, it really did not have to address any major new initiatives in those four or five principal northern seats. Let me tell you, Madam Temporary Chairman, I think those seats will be well worth watching at the Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That includes Kalgoorlie, too.
—Certainly Kalgoorlie, Grey, the Northern Territory, Kennedy—
—Leichhardt.

—Certainly Leichhardt. All of these electorates that fall into these important areas of consideration will be real tests on polling night and indictments of where the Government has failed the people that choose to live in these areas. Of course, most of the principal resource developments are in the area north of the twenty-sixth parallel. I remind the Senate that in this part of the country some 45 per cent of Australia's export wealth is generated, and yet that is done through the employment of a mere 1.5 per cent of our population.

PARA.TAB: So, whilst the Government has now come down with a lot of pious words, a lot of reports, a lot of economic strategies and studies in various government departments, nothing really is being achieved that is new, there are no new initiatives, and I can assure honourable senators that the people who live in those electorates understand that very well. It is, indeed, a major indictment that there has been no progress at all on either the social justice strategy or the economic development strategy of northern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned, as is Senator Tambling, about the things that are going on in the Office of Northern Development, in particular the money that seems to have been thrown at research. As Senator Tambling has pointed out, we find from the budget of the Office of Northern Development itself $23,524 plus—how much from ASTEC?
—Sixty thousand dollars over two years.
—Sixty thousand dollars over two years—
—Thirty thousand dollars over two years, I beg your pardon.
—Into what research is being done.
—A research compendium.

—A research compendium—which is research into what research is being done. That really is the absolute limit of the Government's bureaucratic shuffling. As Senator Tambling has quite rightly pointed out, there are very many areas where real and positive work can be done, but not while we throw money around paying consultants to do work on more consultancies.

PARA.TAB: I also have concerns in relation to some of the information that was provided to the Estimates Committee during the hearings. In particular at page 86 of the Hansard, I was assured by Mr Gray—who I assume was ill-informed by his junior officers—that the Office of Northern Development had close relations with the remote education unit at the James Cook University. So I asked him, upon notice, to advise of the nature of the discussions or contacts or work that had been had. The answer which came back was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Office of Northern Development has had no contact with the Remote Education Unit of James Cook University.

Whilst I am sure that Mr Gray did not mean to mislead the Estimates Committee, I would be grateful to know how the situation could arise that Mr Gray thought that the unit was doing very valuable work when nobody had contacted it, discussed anything with it or worked with it at all. What was the nature of the information that Mr Gray had when he said that it had been doing valuable work and that the Office appreciated the work it had been doing when it had never actually met with or discussed anything with these people and so obviously could not know what work they were doing at James Cook University?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee and I were both present when this discussion took place. We have both read pages 85 and 86 of the Hansard. But they seem to be saying quite different things. Mr Gray, when talking about remote education at James Cook University, said that he did not want to identify where any specific unit fits in. He said that it clearly has a source of knowledge and data which would be useful. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We would see them, as we would indeed see other institutions and units across northern Australia, as a source of competent data upon which to assist the Government in coming to certain policy conclusions.

I could say that about a number of academic institutions in Australia with which I have had no discussions at all. I know that they carry out work which could be useful in such an area. It would be very strange to say otherwise.

PARA.TAB: When specifically asked whether he had had any discussions, he said that he had not and that he was going to check whether anyone else had. I do not think I have seen Senator O'Chee's reservations. He is making an interpretation of the words which does not seem to me to fit. I was there but I did not get the impression that he has. Obviously he genuinely got a different impression from mine of the implication of Mr Gray's words. I do not see any contradiction and I am advised fairly forcefully that Mr Gray does not see any contradiction either. We have a different interpretation of the words and the context. I do not share Senator O'Chee's interpretation. So there is really nothing to add.

I do not see the contradiction between saying that a body has done competent work but I have not been to talk to them. There are hundreds of bodies doing competent work with which I have not had discussions. Fortunately there are a few with which I have. But not talking to them does not make me incapable of judging. The work that they have done may be useful for some inquiries which I may wish to make. Senator O'Chee has made his point. He is entitled to draw that conclusion but I do not share it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern is this: the Committee was told that the unit had done very valuable work. Yet, not only had Mr Gray not contacted it but nobody had contacted it. How the Office of Northern Development can draw the conclusion that the unit does very valuable work when nobody in the Office had contacted it is a very different question to whether Mr Gray personally had contacted it. It just so happens that Mr Gray was right—it had done very valuable work. But, of course, there is a problem. Here is Mr Gray saying that the remote education unit at James Cook University—Dr McSwan and his team—has done very valuable work, yet the Government is refusing to give it adequate funding to continue that work.

PARA.TAB: As you, Madam Temporary Chairman, very well know, one of the greatest problems facing people in rural areas is getting decent education for their children. We are not talking about whether they can get to the library. We are not talking about whether they can do science experiments. We are talking about basic education that people in city areas take for granted. An example of this is being taught to read and write by a competent teacher. You know, as I know, Madam Temporary Chairman, that in many rural areas of Queensland, in many areas of northern Queensland—for example, the peninsula and areas in the direction of Mount Isa and Camooweal and further south—there are massive educational problems. With all the best will in the world, unless parents are adequately backed up they can never give a standard of education remotely approaching the standard of education that these children could get if they had a proper teacher. The necessity, therefore, is to ensure that those parents get adequate support and that the educational programs that are in place are educational programs that give equity.

`Equity' is a word which this Government likes to bandy around quite a lot. The Government likes to talk about equity. It likes to talk about access and equity—about access to education and about equitable educational outcomes. We have a government that talks about social justice for northern Australia; a government that talks about access and equity in education. Yet what does it do? It refuses to give decent funding to this unit at James Cook University—the only unit in Australia that really researches this topic in particular; the only unit that can really provide the answers to the educational issues that people in remote areas have to battle with every day. What is more disturbing is that there has been no contact, no discussions and no work with the unit.

Clearly, not only are the people in remote and rural Australia crying out for somebody to address their educational needs but the people with the answers are crying out for the opportunity to talk to the Government. And all the while, as Senator Tambling has so ably said, the Government throws money willy-nilly all over the place. We are even paying for research into what research has been done. The Government is sitting on its hands although there are people who can help deliver the answers to the social problems facing people in remote and rural Australia.

I know that Senator McMullan would like us to continue. I conclude by saying that I would hope when we come to the Supplementary Estimates this matter might have been addressed in more detail. I hope that the Office of Northern Development might have had some detailed discussions with the remote education unit at James Cook University with a view to actually working alongside the unit and developing with it some comprehensive answers to those questions about equitable educational outcomes and equitable educational opportunities for people in northern Australia and for people in remote and rural Australia generally. I know that this is a burning question. I would hope that that would be done as soon as possible. Every month and year that goes by means that another group of remote students miss out on the opportunities of a decent education that their colleagues who sit in schools in cities get every day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to program 1.1.6? If not, we will move to program 3.3.1—Multicultural Affairs.

—I want to take the opportunity to note that again members of the Estimates Committee were perturbed at the enormous amount of money that is going into the Office of Multicultural Affairs. Some of us have said before, and I am quite happy to say it again, that we consider the Office of Multicultural Affairs to be somewhat superfluous, given that many of the tasks that it performs are in fact performed by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the real root of the existence of the Office of Multicultural Affairs lies in the fact that it was very political. Our previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, came from a seat that had a very high, shall we say, ethnic component. I do not think it would be unfair to say that the Office of Multicultural Affairs was a very convenient way to be seen to be doing something in this regard.

As Senator Bishop, Senator Tambling and I have pointed out, the Office of Multicultural Affairs has continued to offer large grants and consultancies. I do not wish to say any more than this: we believe that in a time of incredible hardship such as this the Government must trim back its spending. We must not forget that this year this Government will spend $13,400m that it does not have. We feel it is appropriate that the Government constrain its spending wherever possible so as to reduce that. When one looks at some of the spending that has been going on and some of the grants that have been made by this Department and other departments on so-called ethnic issues, one really does get very perturbed at how the Commonwealth is spending money.

We found something in excess of $30,000 given to trade union groups in Western Australia to run multicultural talkback radio programs about the benefits of union membership; $18,000 was given to another group of people to put together multicultural audio tapes on award restructuring and the benefits of belonging to a union. I actually took the time to listen to the audio tape, and every 20 or 30 seconds there was another plug for members of the Vietnamese community to join the union and to participate in the activities of the union and get politically involved. This is the sort of outrageous spending that is going on.

As a member of what some people describe as the ethnic community, I can say that many people in the ethnic community do not agree with the way this money is being spent and that many people in the ethnic community can see far better ways of allocating the Government's largess, if largess must be allocated at all. I would hope, speaking for myself, that very rapidly this Department will be truly superfluous. I think some 18 months or two years ago I asked officers of the Department what their prime objective was, and they said it was to have a more harmonious community where ethnic differences did not matter. I said to them, `When are you going to make yourselves redundant?'. It is interesting to note that they have not made themselves redundant yet. They are still spending the money. But, if the goals of the Office of Multicultural Affairs are truly to create a more harmonious Australian society, then one of the steps to that must be to make themselves redundant.

Whilst it gives people a nice, warm inner glow, we could do a lot to cut back spending and waste. Ultimately, I believe that it does make a more harmonious community, because I know there are many people who are resentful at money that they see to be thrown at this ethnic group or that ethnic group. In a time of recession this creates ethnic tension and differences. That is something that I do not want to see in this country. I do not want to see a return to some of the racist attitudes of the Cold War years. But, if the Government continues to throw money around like this, and is being seen to throw money around like this, of course that will be the only consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the genuineness of Senator O'Chee's concern that he does not want to see a return to the racist period of former times. I accept the genuineness with which he expresses that view, although I strongly disagree with him about his views on the appropriateness of the activities of the Office of Multicultural Affairs in enhancing the sort of society that he was outlining, at least with regard to racial discrimination, that he was seeking and to which we would all aspire.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we recognise not just that we live in a multicultural society but that we live in a constantly changing one. It is not a fixed body in which, once we have established harmonious relations between those people, we can then fold our tent and go, because there is a continuing inflow into Australia of people from diverse backgrounds with diverse needs and seeking from the Australian community, through their governments and community groups, a diverse range of assistance. It is appropriate that government should seek to provide to those people access to the same sort of information—as far as we can—and the same level of information, assistance and support that the rest of Australia takes for granted with regard to information and support that will facilitate them participating in society on the same basis and with the same capacity to be as effective as other elements in our society, including those from the more mainstream culture.

It is important that we are not afraid to say that we recognise and make special assistance to people who have special needs. It is not an act of equity to treat everybody equally when their requirements and demands from the society are different. But I accept the bona fides of Senator O'Chee's contribution. We do not share our views about the appropriate role of government in achieving the outcome. I do not think we are talking about large amounts of money that will impact upon the macro-economic policy of the nation, but he is entitled to articulate his view and this is the forum for doing so. I am sure he accepts that we have to agree to differ on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of the issues that Senator McMullan has raised are correct. There is always going to be a flux in the ethnic mix, but we are saying that there is no point in having two departments to do what could be done by one department. Whilst Senator McMullan, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, may feel that it does not matter whether this or that amount seems to be particularly large, it does matter at the end of day. It may not seem to Senator McMullan that it will damage the macro-economic settings, but I only need to remind him—and I hope he will bear this in mind as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer—that if one minds the pennies, the pounds will look after themselves.
—And the dollars and cents too.
—And it applies to dollars and cents too, as my colleague Senator Bishop says. She is far more up-to-date on some of these things than I am.
—That is an admission.
—Senator McMullan should not worry. He still has a long way to go to catch up to either of us. The important thing is that we have to be very careful in the way we scrutinise public spending.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we are on this program, I take the opportunity to address the issue of the Office of the Status of Women as well. One of the things that concerned me was the large amount of money that was given to the Manungka Women's Association—$19,700, in fact—that was intended to help establish a textile industry in the Kimberley desert. When I discussed this with a number of people, since the hearing, most of them were shocked that we would try to establish a textile industry in the Kimberley desert when the textile industry in places much closer to our population centres is dying at a great rate of knots. We are informed that approximately 50 women are expected to be trained—25 in each community.

One of the interesting things is that the money was allocated for the 1991-92 financial year but is not due to be acquitted until March 1993. If one reads the answer very closely, given that this answer was written some time in September-October, one will find it a little disturbing. The answer says that preparatory work on the project has been done and training will begin shortly. This money was allocated in the previous financial year. I am concerned that the money that has not been spent in that year will be spent in this year, or maybe the possibility is that further moneys are being allocated to this project. Perhaps Senator McMullan would be kind enough to provide us with advice on that concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Addressing the concern of timetable, I am advised that this grant is operating on the normal timetable of grant implementation and acquittal that would be the standard for grants of this sort under this program.
—We move to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, program 1, subprogram 1.8—policy and projects.

—My colleague Senator Macdonald wished attention to be drawn to the multifunction polis, in particular, the Multifunction Polis Development Corporation Board. For everybody's edification, I ask Senator Button whether he could supply us with the names of the people who are on that board.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a press release of 20 October which contains the names of the members of the board. I seek leave to have that incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: LEADING AUSTRALIANS APPOINTED TO STEER MFP

SPEECH.PARA: A group of eminent Australians will steer the development of the MFP.

The Federal Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, and the Premier of South Australia, Lynn Arnold, today announced that Mr Alex Morokoff AO would become the inaugural chair of the MFP Development Corporation.

Mr Morokoff is a senior and widely regarded Australian business leader. He is deputy chairman of Lend Lease Corporation Ltd and AOTC, and will bring to the position a wealth of experience in urban development, telecommunications and information technology.
He will head a board of prominent Australians with wide-ranging experience in industry, research, education, government, environmental management and the community.
Senator Button and Mr Arnold today commended the membership of the board as "a landmark in making the project a national and international success.
"The selection of such a strong board is a major step in demonstrating that the MFP is a viable project which will make a significant contribution to economic development in Australia," they said.
The board will be:

PARA.TAB: Mr Morokoff
Mr Ross Adler, Managing Director, Santos

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Will Bailey AO, Deputy Chairman of Coles Myer Ltd and former ANZ Chief Executive.
Ms Helen Disney, Director of Education and Community Services, Adelaide Central Mission.

PARA.TAB: Sir Llew Edwards, former Deputy Premier of Queensland
Professor Mal Logan, Vice-Chancellor of Monash University
Mr Richard Longes, Director of Lend Lease Corporation Ltd

SPEECH.PARA: Mr David Plumridge, President, Local Government Association of SA
Ms Kaye Schofield, Chief Executive Officer, SA Department of Employment and Technical and Further Education

PARA.TAB: Dr John Stocker, Chief Executive, CSIRO

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Robert Trenberth, Deputy Secretary, Commonwealth Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce
The names of the group will be presented to Her Excellency the Governor of South Australia, Dame Roma Mitchell, for appointment on Thursday.
The MFP Development Corporation is responsible for the marketing, planning, management and operation of the MFP.

The first tasks of the new board will include the appointment of a chief executive officer for the Corporation and establishing priorities for the development of the MFP. The chief executive officer will also be a member of the board.

Senator Button and Mr Arnold said the board would bring an ideal mix of abilities for the MFP's goals of generating investment in 21st century industries for Australia and creating a model urban development.
They said the skills of the board members highlighted the diverse aspects of the project and would give the MFP a broad national focus.

"The mix of people, backgrounds and talents will ensure that the project can be driven by the private sector with cooperation across Australia between industry, government, the education and research sectors, and the community," they said.

Mr Arnold and Senator Button said the board would work closely with the MFP's International Advisory Board, which consisted of outstanding business people and educationalists from Europe, North America and Asia, and would include some members of the Australian MFP board.
Mr Arnold said the South Australian membership of the Board was also significant, and said the board would work closely with the state's Economic Development Board.
Senator Button said the total Federal financial commitment to date for the MFP was up to $70 million. The State Government has allocated $37 million in the 1992-93 Budget for MFP-related activities.

Senator Button said the Japanese Government had reaffirmed its commitment to the project during the Prime Minister's visit to Japan in September and stated that special financial arrangements were available for Japanese investors wishing to become involved in the MFP.
Adelaide was selected as the MFP site in July 1990, and physical work is scheduled to begin next year. The core industries for the project are environmental management,
education and information technology and telecommunications.

—During the Estimates hearings with regard to the Australian Manufacturing Council, it came to our attention for the first time that Mr Mountford, who heads up—for want of a better word—the Australian Manufacturing Council has been employed as a consultant. The curious statement was made that it was thought he was not somehow a consultant. Then suddenly there was a change of mind and it was discovered this year that he was a consultant. This really shows that the Senate Committee was misled. No good reason has been provided as to why the report was made in the way it was for a number of years and then was suddenly changed. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Committee was told by Dr Bell, the Deputy Secretary of the Department, that Mr Mountford's contract was not listed in the earlier annual reports because the Department had not previously considered it to be a consultancy.

However, in processing the latest contract to re-engage Mr Mountford, the Department, as part of its new procedures, considered it was arguable whether it should be deemed a consultancy. It was then decided to err, as I said, on the side of caution and that was why the Mountford consultancy was included in the 1991-92 annual report. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak this evening on two matters which are of great importance to my constituents in Queensland. I do not expect to keep the Senate very long. The two matters are very closely interrelated and are constantly raised by many in the community. The first is the issue of truth in labelling with regard to Australian made produce, and the second is that we should encourage all Australians to buy Australian made produce.

PARA.TAB: When people shop at locally owned businesses, they are not only creating employment, they are also saving that business from going to the wall. Buying locally also helps to protect against higher prices in the future. We all remember that 20 years ago every town had one or two bakers, several butchers, a soft drink factory and several greengrocers, but now there are few, if any, left. People used to be able to buy their flour, meat, sugar and produce from several suppliers, but now the supply is limited to one or two companies and this has obviously affected the buying price.

The big supermarket chains have used a lot of imported goods and this has, in turn, closed the small shops and small manufacturers who employed a lot of people. Regrettably, those people are now on the dole. However, I must say that just recently there has been talk about how the supermarkets are trying to ensure that so many more of their goods are Australian-made and not imported. The supermarket chains control the manufacturers and the farmers, and if they do not sell at their price, they just import the goods. At the moment, four in every five sales are made in a chain-store. When five out of five are made in chain-stores, what will people be paying then?

The trend is plain for everyone to see. In 10 years time, there will be no fruit and vegetable market in Brisbane, only a handful of big buyers. In my local paper recently, in an article on this subject, Mr Ken Andersson, who owns a fruit market in Kingaroy, said that his eyes were opened on a recent trip to Denmark. He said that the little town where his mother used to live now had no shop.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's Hans Christian, is it?
—It was not Hans Christian Anderson, no; it was Mr Ken Andersson—it is spelt a little differently.
—Senator Button lives in fairytale land most of the time anyway.
—Now, now. People go to the next town, where there is only a supermarket. It is time all Australians stood up and said something.

PARA.TAB: The local bacon factory in Kingaroy is having to compete with imports, especially from Canada. Everything processed in the area is 100 per cent Australian—90 per cent of its meat would come from a 40 to 50 kilometre radius of Kingaroy and the rest would come from Dalby, Chinchilla, Jandowae or Monto. The company, which is currently employing 75 local people in jobs, has an annual payroll of $2.3m. This sort of enterprise certainly boosts the local economy. The bacon factory also handles about $13m worth of livestock a year.
Kingaroy, as all honourable senators would undoubtedly know, is the home of the peanut.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear.

—Senator O'Chee is right. It is a very important industry in our Kingaroy district. The Kingaroy Toasted Peanuts Co. also tries to promote our local products. Indeed, it uses all Australian grown peanuts, except for its supply of cashews, which are not available in Australia. The company tries to clearly mark its products with an Australian flag on the front of the packets, and `Made in Australia from Australian peanuts' and the Peanut Marketing Board logo. There can be no doubt in the buyer's mind that these products are definitely Australian grown and made, and I can recommend them very well indeed.

PARA.TAB: There are so many labels on items today that are deceptive. I believe that people are prepared to pay a premium for a good Australian product if they have to. The campaign by farmers and consumers for truth in labelling deserves the support of everyone. For too long, people have been importing junk from overseas and getting away with putting a `Produce of Australia' label on it. A letter to the editor in the South Burnett Times put it simply when the writer said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great deal that Labor governments in Brisbane and Canberra could do to stop this attack on our jobs and our health. The Federal Labor Government has passed up every opportunity to penalise dumping by imposing countervailing tariffs. It has also turned away from amending the labelling laws so cynically manipulated by the importers.
The writer also blamed the Queensland State Government when he wrote:

The State Government, too, has failed dismally by refusing to use its powers under health regulations. Labor has been in power in Brisbane and in Canberra during the period this invasion of sub-standard food has taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would never have happened in Joh's day, would it?
—Senator Button is exactly right and I am glad he has enough sense to know that. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The blame rests squarely on the shoulders of Wayne Goss and Paul Keating.

Finally, I would like to make mention of the decision by Coles and Woolworths to make it easier to identify Australian made products on store shelves. However, for the strategy to work there would need to be an urgent overhaul of Australia's food labelling laws to allow imported products to be clearly recognisable. The Queensland Grain Growers Association has led the truth in labelling debate for almost three years, with the association's stated policy being that imported food stuffs should carry large, visually dominant labels indicating that fact.

PARA.TAB: In many cases, consumers simply cannot determine whether they are really buying Australian product or not, as enough flexibility exists in current food labelling laws to allow importers to imply that their product was made in Australia. The laws are obviously inadequate when one can read on the front of food packets that the product contained within is Australian, yet when one turns it over, one finds it is actually made or grown overseas and merely packed or processed here. Surveys by Coles and Woolworths have clearly shown that shoppers are willing to purchase a genuinely Australian made product, even if it is more expensive.

As well as tightening up labelling laws, there is an urgent need for industry to take commercial action to protect itself from dumped and cheap imports. In the midst of the crisis currently hitting our rural community, Australia is importing more than $2 billion worth of food products every year. That is a tremendous amount.

Australian horticultural products are fast becoming an endangered species. The list is growing every week. First it was pineapples; now it is bananas, canned fruit, peanuts, navy beans, peas, beetroot, beans, potatoes and other vegetables, as well as apricots, dried vine fruits, rice, orange juice, apple juice, jams, mushrooms, dairy products and fresh meat.

One industry which is still suffering from dumped goods is the peanut industry. That is an industry that I know very well because many growers in my home district are centred on Kingaroy. This Federal Government has failed in its duty to protect Australia's peanut producers by rejecting a peanut industry application seeking the imposition of anti-dumping duties.

The peanut industry has been suffering from an influx of dumped overseas peanuts over the past three years, but the peanut industry has not been able to convince the Anti-Dumping Authority of its plight. In February this year I moved a motion condemning the Government for its refusal to implement anti-dumping and countervailing measures against the dumping of Chinese peanuts on the Australian market. Unfortunately, the Chinese peanuts have residue in them. That is one of the sad things that happened.

The Australian Customs inquiry into the importation of the Chinese peanuts established that these imports have increased 300 per cent in the past three years. It admitted that the cheaper imports were being dumped and that Australian producers were suffering as a result. It also admitted that these actions were having a serious impact on Queensland's $30m a year peanut industry. If it does not rain soon in the Kingaroy district, no peanuts will be planted so that we can have a really good year with our peanuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the fault of Wayne Goss?

—I cannot blame Wayne Goss for that. I can blame him for a lot of other things, but not that. Furthermore, tests on the Chinese peanuts have identified high levels of chemical residues which are illegal in the Australian industry. The thing that annoys me very much is that some of these imported Chinese peanuts are being mixed with good Australian peanuts by some firms which then try to promote them as being totally Australian peanuts, which is very wrong. The Minister who looks after Customs and the Government should take immediate action to halt the importation of these peanuts and thus provide a fair go for Australian peanut farmers instead of supporting those who live in China.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, a whole smorgasbord of imported food is entering our market as subsidised products. At the same time very often our farmers have to plough their products back into the soil. This problem is not just one for farmers. I can understand housewives who, under current economic circumstances, try to buy the cheapest products when shopping. And who can blame them when we have seen our household income seriously eroded since this Government came to power? Many of those households now face life on the dole as unemployment rises steadily.

Of course, any sensible shopper tries to cut costs by buying cheaper brands but with many of these dumped brands the products are not as tasty nor as nutritious as Australian grown fruit and vegetables. Many housewives would know that Australian grown and processed products guarantee the best quality in the world. When I go home at the weekend between the sittings of the Senate and do my shopping I certainly like to buy Australian products. I also like to buy them a bit cheaper if I can but it does not always work, of course. Our goods are grown under strict guidelines and processed under high standards of hygiene using the best and most advanced technology available.

However, it is not only the farmers who suffer from these dumped products. Almost every part of the Australian community, both in the city and the country, is affected. There is an entire support network servicing these farmers and their products which is also affected. I am talking about the rural communities—the transport workers, the processors, the cannery workers, the packers, the storemen, the factory workers and, of course, in the end all Australian consumers.

It is bad enough that Australian farmers are suffering because of the irresponsible policies of this Government and then having to compete in a corrupt and dishonest world trading market, but dumped products add another dimension to the problems of the rural industries. It means that farmers are having to compete on their home turf with inferior products which are deliberately dumped onto our domestic market.
Finally, I urge all Australian shopkeepers, housewives and legislators to look closely at this growing problem and help our own industry by buying Australian-made products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I am glad Senator Kemp agrees with me. I also urge the Australian Government to act now before we totally destroy our own industries by lack of action in providing adequate labelling laws.

—In brief, I should respond to what Senator Bjelke-Petersen has said. I share with her a concern that Australian consumers do get imports of genuine quality and are not put at risk by imports. I also share her concern that we not be dumped on. I ask her to note that all she says is really meaningless when one looks at the approach that her coalition leader, Dr Hewson, has embodied in his Fightback package. I ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen to look at one specific part of that package. If she does have the interests of Queenslanders at heart, I ask her to take that independent approach of which we are well versed as coming from her.

PARA.TAB: The policies of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's Leader mean that the Government laboratories will no longer have that community service obligation that means that they can conduct adequate testing of imports that come into this country. The approach to sell off those laboratories means that the people to whom those laboratories have an obligation—the Australian consumer—will no longer have that community service obligation—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are selling off the Commonwealth Bank. You are the greatest privatisers of the 1990s. What are you talking about?
—This mug over there interjects again.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That is unparliamentary and I suggest you ask him to withdraw it.
—Order! It will be withdrawn.

—I withdraw. Not only does Senator Bjelke-Petersen not appreciate what is in that policy but it is quite apparent that Senator Kemp does not either. In the next few months we will tell the Opposition all about it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 6 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the 3 year delay that was declared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, regarding the importation of irradiated food, expires in December 1992.
(2) What will be the Government's attitude and policy towards the importation of irradiated food once this delay expires.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) At the time that the National Food Standards Council adopted the moratorium the Government also agreed that there was a need to seek information on food irradiation from the World Health Organisation (WHO). In January 1991, the Government commissioned a detailed project from WHO to review and analyse the general chemistry of food irradiation, its toxicological and microbiological status, nutritional effects and functionality, and to provide information pertaining to the safety and nutritional value of irradiated foods under specified conditions of use.

The National Food Authority received a preliminary report from WHO on 19 October 1992. The report is presently being assessed in conjunction with a range of relevant Government bodies before advice is provided to the Government about appropriate regulation of food irradiation.

The National Food Authority has prepared a proposal to develop a standard regulating food which has been exposed to ionising radiation and/or which accidentally incorporates radionuclides (any substance which emits ionising radiation). Such a standard would apply equally to domestic or imported food.
The proposed standard may:
prohibit either generally or conditionally the use of ionising radiation to treat food or particular classes of food;
regulate the radionuclide contamination of food; and
prescribe test methods to be used to determine whether or not food complies with any requirements so imposed.
The proposal will enable the Authority to consider the issues involved in the irradiation of food in a formal manner which is comprehensive, open and publicly accountable.

The Authority has sought written submissions on the proposal from all interested parties as required in the National Food Authority Act 1991 by 1 March 1993. These may include individual constituents, consumer bodies, industry, professionals, and other government agencies.

In developing appropriate regulation for food irradiation, the Government will have to consider not only public health issues related to the food supply but also a wide range of issues relating to the environment, industry codes of practice, occupational health and safety, transport and storage and development of suitable testing for irradiated products.
